subparagraph.text: Meets the qualifications otherwise required by this title or their equivalent; and
Became licensed in the other state after passing in that or any other state an examination that is similar to the examination for which the applicant is seeking the waiver.

subsection.text: The Board shall issue a license to any applicant who:

paragraph.text: Pays a license fee set by the Board; and
Otherwise meets the requirements of this title.

subsection.text: The Board shall include on each license that it issues:

paragraph.text: Its seal; and
Designations that clearly distinguish between those licensees who may practice chiropractic and those who may practice chiropractic with the right to practice physical therapy.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this section, a license authorizes the licensee to practice chiropractic while the license is effective.
A license that includes the right to practice physical therapy authorizes the licensee to practice chiropractic and physical therapy while the license is effective.
A license does not authorize a licensee to execute or file a birth or death certificate.
A license expires on the date set by the Board, unless the license is renewed for an additional term as provided in this section. A license may not be renewed for a term of longer than 2 years.
At least 1 month before a license expires, the Board shall send to each licensee, by first-class mail to the last known address of the licensee, a renewal form and a renewal notice that states:

paragraph.text: The date on which the current license expires;
That the renewal application and fee must be received by the Board on or before the license expiration date; and
The amount of the renewal fee.

subsection.text: A licensee periodically may renew a license for an additional term if the licensee:

paragraph.text: Otherwise is entitled to be licensed;
Pays a renewal fee set by the Board; and
Submits to the Board:

subparagraph.text: A renewal application on the form that the Board requires; and
Satisfactory evidence of compliance with the continuing education requirements set by the Board under this section for license renewal.

paragraph.text: The Board may establish continuing education requirements as a condition to the renewal of licenses under this section.
Any requirements established under this subsection shall reflect current educational methods and chiropractic techniques.

subsection.text: The Board shall renew the license of and issue a renewal certificate to each licensee who meets the requirements of this section.

section.text: The Board shall reinstate a license that is expired only if the former licensee:

paragraph.text: Meets the renewal requirements of § 3-308; and
Pays to the Board a reinstatement fee set by the Board.

subsection.text: If a chiropractor fails for any reason to renew the license of the chiropractor, the Board shall reinstate the license if the chiropractor:

paragraph.text: Applies to the Board for reinstatement of the license within 5 years after the license expires;
Meets the renewal requirements of § 3-308 of this subtitle;
Pays to the Board the reinstatement fee set by the Board; and
Passes the law and regulations portion of the Board’s examination.

subsection.text: The Board may not reinstate the license of a chiropractor who fails to apply for reinstatement of the license within 5 years after the license expires. However, the chiropractor may become licensed by meeting the current requirements for obtaining a new license under this title.
The Board shall place a licensee on inactive status, if the licensee submits to the Board:

paragraph.text: An application for inactive status on the form required by the Board; and
The inactive status fee set by the Board.

subsection.text: A licensee on inactive status may reactivate the license at any time if the licensee:

paragraph.text: Complies with the continuing education requirements in effect for the renewal period in which the licensee seeks to reactivate the license; and
Pays the reinstatement fee set by the Board.

subsection.text: Unless the Board agrees to accept the surrender of a license, a licensed chiropractor may not surrender the license nor may the license lapse by operation of law while the licensee is under investigation or while charges are pending against the chiropractor.
The Board may set conditions on its agreement with the chiropractor under investigation or against whom charges are pending to accept surrender of the chiropractor’s license.

section.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 3-315 of this subtitle, the Board may deny a license to any applicant, reprimand any licensee, place any licensee on probation, with or without conditions, or suspend or revoke a license, or any combination thereof, if the applicant or licensee:

paragraph.text: Fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a license for the applicant or licensee or for another;
Fraudulently or deceptively uses a license;
Practices chiropractic under a false name;
Impersonates another practitioner;

Is convicted of or pleads guilty or nolo contendere to a felony or to a crime involving moral turpitude, whether or not any appeal or other proceeding is pending to have the conviction or plea set aside;
Provides professional services while:

subparagraph.text: Under the influence of alcohol; or
Using any narcotic or controlled dangerous substance, as defined in § 5-101 of the Criminal Law Article, or other drug that is in excess of therapeutic amounts or without valid medical indication;

paragraph.text: Solicits or advertises in a false or misleading manner or in any other manner not approved by the Board;
Is unethical in the conduct of the practice of chiropractic;
Is professionally incompetent;
Abandons a patient;
Misrepresents the effectiveness of any treatment, drugs, devices, appliances, or goods to a patient so as to exploit the patient for financial gain;
Makes or files a false report or record in the practice of chiropractic;
Fails to file or record any report as required by law;
Impedes or obstructs the filing or recording of the report, or induces another to fail to file or record the report;
Pays or agrees to pay any sum to any person for bringing or referring a patient;
Overutilizes health care services;

Is disciplined by a licensing or disciplinary authority of any other state or country or convicted by a court of any state or country for an act that would be grounds for disciplinary action under this section;
Practices chiropractic with an unauthorized person or supervises or aids an unauthorized person in the practice of chiropractic;
Violates any rule or regulation adopted by the Board;
Behaves immorally in the practice of chiropractic;
Commits an act of unprofessional conduct in the practice of chiropractic;
Grossly overutilizes health care services;
Is convicted of insurance fraud under § 27-801 of the Insurance Article;

Refuses, withholds from, denies, or discriminates against an individual with regard to the provision of professional services for which the licensee is licensed and qualified to render because the individual is HIV positive;
Submits false statements to collect fees for which services were not provided;
Misrepresents qualifications, education, training, or clinical experience;
Is physically or mentally impaired to the extent that it impairs the applicant’s or licensee’s ability to practice chiropractic safely; or
Violates any provision of this title.

subsection.text: If after a hearing under § 3-315 of this subtitle the Board finds that there are grounds under § 3-313 of this subtitle to suspend or revoke a license, the Board may impose a penalty not exceeding $5,000 for each violation:

paragraph.text: Instead of suspending the license; or
In addition to suspending or revoking the license.

subsection.text: If, after disciplinary procedures have been brought against a licensee, the licensee waives the right to a hearing required under this subtitle and if the Board finds that there are grounds under § 3-313 of this subtitle to reprimand the licensee, place the licensee on probation, or suspend or revoke a license, the Board may impose a penalty not exceeding $5,000 for each violation in addition to reprimanding, placing the licensee on probation or suspending or revoking the license.
The Board shall adopt rules and regulations to set standards for the imposition of penalties under this section.
The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this section into the General Fund of this State.

Except as otherwise provided in the Administrative Procedure Act, before the Board takes any action under § 3–313 of this subtitle or § 3–5A–11 of this title, it shall give the individual against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Board.
The Board shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with the Administrative Procedure Act.
The individual may be represented at the hearing by counsel.

Over the signature of an officer or the administrator of the Board, the Board may issue subpoenas and administer oaths in connection with any investigation under this title and any hearings or proceedings before it.

If, without lawful excuse, a person disobeys a subpoena from the Board or an order by the Board to take an oath or to testify or answer a question, then, on petition of the Board, a court of competent jurisdiction shall compel compliance with the subpoena and may punish the person as for contempt of court.
If after due notice the individual against whom the action is contemplated fails or refuses to appear, nevertheless the Board may hear and determine the matter.

If, after a hearing, a chiropractor or massage therapist is found in violation of § 3–313 of this subtitle or § 3–5A–11 of this title, the chiropractor or massage therapist shall pay to the Board the costs for court reporting services.

Except as provided in this section for an action under § 3–313 of this subtitle or § 3–5A–11 of this title, any person aggrieved by a final decision of the Board in a contested case, as defined in the Administrative Procedure Act, may:

paragraph.text: Appeal that decision to the Board of Review; and
Then take any further appeal allowed by the Administrative Procedure Act.

Any person aggrieved by a final decision of the Board under § 3–313 of this subtitle or § 3–5A–11 of this title may not appeal to the Secretary or Board of Review but may take a direct judicial appeal.
The appeal shall be made as provided for judicial review of final decisions in the Administrative Procedure Act.

subsection.text: An action may be maintained in the name of this State or the Board to enjoin:

paragraph.text: The unauthorized practice of chiropractic or massage therapy; or
Conduct that is a ground for disciplinary action under § 3–313 of this subtitle or § 3–5A–11 of this title.

subsection.text: An action under this section may be brought by:

paragraph.text: The Board, in its own name;
The Attorney General, in the name of this State; or
A State’s Attorney, in the name of this State.

subsection.text: An action under this section shall be brought in the county where the defendant:

paragraph.text: Resides; or
Engages in the acts sought to be enjoined.
Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, an action under this section may not be brought against an individual who is authorized to practice a health occupation under this article.
An action under this section may be brought against an individual who is authorized to practice chiropractic or massage therapy under this title.

subsection.text: Proof of actual damage or that any person will sustain any damage if an injunction is not granted is not required for an action under this section.
An action under this section is in addition to and not instead of criminal prosecution for:

paragraph.text: The unauthorized practice of chiropractic under § 3–501 of this title or disciplinary action under § 3–313 of this subtitle; or
The unauthorized practice of massage therapy under § 3–501 of this title or disciplinary action under § 3–5A–11 of this title.

subsection.text: The Board shall adopt rules and regulations to establish standards for advertising or soliciting by chiropractors.
For purposes of this section, notices mailed to patients to inform them of times for periodic examinations are not advertising or soliciting.

The Board shall approve those schools of chiropractic that provide a curriculum, teaching standards, and facilities that the Board determines are adequate to prepare a license applicant to practice chiropractic under this title.
To be approved under this section, a school shall offer a program that:

paragraph.text: Is 4 academic years that total at least 4,000 60-minute hours of resident study; and
Leads to a degree of Doctor of Chiropractic.

subsection.text: The Board may inspect any school of chiropractic to determine whether it meets the standards required by this section.
The Board may approve a school in another state on the recommendation of:

paragraph.text: The chiropractic licensing authority of that state; or
The Council on Chiropractic Education.

section.text: The provisions of § 13-402 of this article do not prohibit a chiropractor who is licensed to practice chiropractic with the right to practice physical therapy from representing that the licensee holds that license.

A licensed chiropractor may delegate duties to an assistant to the extent permitted by the rules and regulations of the Board if the assigned duties do not require the professional skill and judgment of a licensed chiropractor. The rules and regulations shall also establish qualifications for the position of chiropractic assistant.

A licensed chiropractor shall have the immunity from liability described under § 5-636 of the Courts and Judicial Proceedings Article for reviewing the fees or charges for services of another licensed chiropractor in this or any other state.

subsection.text: In this section, “chiropractor rehabilitation committee” means a committee that:

paragraph.text: Is defined in subsection (b) of this section; and
Performs any of the functions listed in subsection (d) of this section.

subsection.text: For purposes of this section, a chiropractor rehabilitation committee is a committee of the Board or a committee of the Maryland Chiropractic Association that:

paragraph.text: Is recognized by the Board; and
Includes but is not limited to chiropractors.

subsection.text: A rehabilitation committee of the Board or recognized by the Board may function:

paragraph.text: Solely for the Board; or
Jointly with a rehabilitation committee representing another board or boards.

subsection.text: For purposes of this section, a chiropractor rehabilitation committee evaluates and provides assistance to any chiropractor, chiropractic assistant, and any other individual regulated by the Board in need of treatment and rehabilitation for alcoholism, drug abuse, chemical dependency, or other physical, emotional, or mental condition.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, the proceedings, records, and files of the chiropractor rehabilitation committee are not discoverable and are not admissible in evidence in any civil action arising out of matters that are being or have been reviewed and evaluated by the chiropractor rehabilitation committee.

Paragraph (1) of this subsection does not apply to any record or document that is considered by the chiropractor rehabilitation committee and that otherwise would be subject to discovery or introduction into evidence in any arbitration or civil proceeding.
For purposes of this subsection, civil action does not include a proceeding before the Board or judicial review of a proceeding before the Board.

subsection.text: A person who acts in good faith and within the scope of jurisdiction of a chiropractor rehabilitation committee is not civilly liable for any action as a member of the chiropractor rehabilitation committee or for giving information to, participating in, or contributing to the function of the chiropractor rehabilitation committee.

section.text: A licensed chiropractor may use a trade name in connection with the practice of chiropractic provided that:

paragraph.text: The use of the trade name is not deceptive or misleading;

The advertisement in which the trade name appears includes the name of the licensed chiropractor or the name of the business entity providing the chiropractic services being advertised as long as the advertisement includes the name of a licensed chiropractor;
The name of the licensed chiropractor providing chiropractic services appears on the billing invoices, stationery, and on any receipt given to a patient;
Treatment records are maintained that clearly identify the licensed chiropractor who has performed the chiropractic service for the patient; and
The use of a trade name is preapproved by the Board before use.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 3–404 of this title, a person may not practice, attempt to practice, or offer to practice chiropractic in this State unless licensed by the Board.

Except as otherwise provided in this title, an individual may not practice, attempt to practice, or offer to practice massage therapy, massage, myotherapy, or any synonym or derivation of these terms in this State unless licensed or registered by the Board.

paragraph.text: Unless authorized to practice chiropractic under this title, a person may not represent to the public by title, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the person is authorized to practice chiropractic in this State.

Unless authorized to practice under this title, a person may not use the title “chiropractor”, or “D.C.”, or any other term or title with the intent to represent that the person practices chiropractic.

An individual who is not a licensed massage therapist or registered as a massage practitioner under this title may not advertise or claim by title, abbreviation, sign, card, or any other representation that the individual practices massage, massage therapy, myotherapy, or any synonym or derivation of these terms.

Unless authorized to practice under this title, a person may not use the title “massage therapist”, “MT”, “licensed massage therapist”, “LMT”, “massage practitioner”, “MP”, “registered massage practitioner”, “RMP”, or any other term or title with the intent to represent that the person practices massage therapy.

subsection.text: An individual who is a registered massage practitioner under this title or a business entity that employs registered massage practitioners under this title may not advertise to the public that the individual or business entity provides health–related therapeutic massage services.

paragraph.text: In Charles County and Washington County, an individual may not perform a massage or offer to perform a massage on another person for compensation unless the individual who performs the massage or offers to perform a massage is a licensed massage therapist or registered massage practitioner.
A law enforcement officer in Charles County or Washington County may demand proof of licensure or registration.

section.text: A person may not buy, sell, or fraudulently obtain:

paragraph.text: A license; or
Any diploma or degree required under § 3–302 or § 3–5A–06 of this title.

subsection.text: A person who practices or attempts to practice chiropractic or massage therapy without a license in violation of § 3–501 of this subtitle or represents to the public in violation of § 3–502 of this subtitle that the person is authorized to practice chiropractic or massage therapy is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to:

paragraph.text: For a first offense, a fine not exceeding $2,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 6 months; or
For a subsequent offense, a fine not exceeding $6,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year.

subsection.text: A person who is convicted under the provisions of this section shall reimburse the Board for the direct costs of the Board, including court reporting services and expert witness fees, incurred as a result of a prosecution under this section.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the State Board of Chiropractic and Massage Therapy Examiners.
“Health care facility” has the meaning stated in § 19–114(d) of the Health – General Article.
“License” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a license issued by the Board to practice massage therapy.
“Licensed massage therapist” means an individual who is licensed by the Board to practice massage therapy.

paragraph.text: “Massage therapy” means the use of manual techniques on soft tissues of the human body including effleurage (stroking), petrissage (kneading), tapotement (tapping), stretching, compression, vibration, and friction, with or without the aid of heat limited to hot packs and heating pads, cold water, or nonlegend topical applications, for the purpose of improving circulation, enhancing muscle relaxation, relieving muscular pain, reducing stress, or promoting health and well–being.
“Massage therapy” does not include:

subparagraph.text: The diagnosis or treatment of illness, disease, or injury;
The adjustment, manipulation, or mobilization of any of the articulations of the osseous structures of the body or spine; or

Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, the laying on of hands, consisting of pressure or movement on a fully clothed individual, to specifically affect the electromagnetic energy or energetic field of the human body.

paragraph.text: “Massage therapy” includes the laying on of hands, consisting of pressure or movement on a fully clothed individual, to specifically affect the electromagnetic energy or energetic field of the human body if this practice includes use of the manual techniques set forth in paragraph (1) of this subsection.
In paragraph (2)(iii) of this subsection, “fully clothed” does not require the wearing of footwear.
The provisions of paragraph (2) of this subsection do not preclude the application of the modalities described in paragraph (1) of this subsection to an individual who has an injury.

subsection.text: “Practice massage therapy” means to engage professionally and for compensation in massage therapy.
“Practice non–therapeutic massage” means to engage professionally and for compensation in massage therapy in a setting that is not a health care facility.
“Registered massage practitioner” means an individual who is registered by the Board to practice non–therapeutic massage.
“Registration” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a registration issued by the Board to practice non–therapeutic massage.

section.text: The Board shall adopt regulations for the:

paragraph.text: Licensure and practice of massage therapists; and
Registration and practice of massage practitioners.
The Board shall set reasonable fees for the issuance and renewal of licenses and registrations and the other services it provides to massage therapists.
The fees charged shall be set so as to produce funds to approximate the cost of maintaining the licensure program, registration program, and the other services provided to massage therapists.
The Board shall pay all fees collected under the provisions of this subtitle to the Comptroller of the State.
The Comptroller shall distribute all fees to the State Board of Chiropractic and Massage Therapy Examiners Fund established under § 3–206 of this title.

subsection.text: The fees shall be used exclusively to cover the actual documented direct and indirect costs of fulfilling the statutory and regulatory duties of the Board as provided by the provisions of this subtitle.

section.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, an individual shall be:

paragraph.text: Licensed by the Board before the individual may practice massage therapy in this State; or
Registered by the Board before the individual may practice non–therapeutic massage in this State.

section.text: This subtitle does not apply to:

paragraph.text: A student enrolled in an approved education program as determined by the Board while practicing massage therapy in that program;

An individual permitted to practice massage therapy under regulations adopted by the Board, if the individual otherwise has qualified to practice massage therapy in any other state or country that has substantially similar requirements for authorization to practice massage therapy and the individual is in this State for no more than 7 days;
A family member practicing massage therapy on another family member;
An athletic trainer while functioning in the course of the athletic trainer’s professional capacity;
An individual employed by the federal government to practice massage therapy while practicing within the scope of the individual’s employment; or
An individual working in a beauty salon:

subparagraph.text: For which the person who operates the beauty salon has obtained a permit from the State Board of Cosmetology as required under § 5–501 of the Business Occupations and Professions Article; and
In which the individual is providing cosmetology and esthetic services, including the application and removal of skin or skin care products.

subsection.text: To qualify for a license, an applicant shall be an individual who:

paragraph.text: Is of good moral character;
Is at least 18 years old;

Has satisfactorily completed at least 60 credit hours of education at an institution of higher education as defined in § 10–101 of the Education Article and as approved by the Board and the Maryland Higher Education Commission;
Has completed 500 hours of education in a Board approved program for the study of massage therapy that includes the following areas of content:

subparagraph.text: Anatomy and physiology;
Massage theory, techniques, and practice;
Contraindications to massage therapy; and
Professional ethics; and

paragraph.text: Has passed an examination approved by the Board.

subsection.text: To qualify for registration, an applicant shall be an individual who:

paragraph.text: Is of good moral character;
Is at least 18 years old;
Has completed 500 hours of education in a Board approved program for the study of massage therapy that includes the following areas of content:

subparagraph.text: Anatomy and physiology;
Massage theory, techniques, and practice;
Contraindications to massage therapy; and
Professional ethics; and

paragraph.text: Has passed an examination approved by the Board.

subsection.text: Subject to the provisions of this section, the Board may waive any requirement of this subtitle for an applicant who is registered, certified, or licensed to practice massage therapy in another state.
The Board may grant a waiver under this section only if the applicant:

paragraph.text: Pays the application fee set by the Board; and
Provides adequate evidence that the applicant:

subparagraph.text: Has completed educational requirements that the Board determines to be equivalent to the Board approved educational requirements in this State; and

sub-subparagraph.text: At the time the applicant became certified, registered, or licensed in the other state, passed in that state or any other state an examination that the Board determines to be equivalent to the examination required in this State; or
Passed an examination approved by the Board; and

paragraph.text: Is of good moral character.

section.text: An individual who is registered to practice non–therapeutic massage under § 3–5A–06 of this subtitle may not practice in a medical health care provider’s office, hospital, or other health care facility for the purpose of providing massage.
To apply for a license or registration, an applicant shall:

paragraph.text: Submit to the Board an application on the form that the Board requires;
Submit to the Board evidence of compliance with the requirements of § 3–5A–05 of this subtitle; and
Pay the application fee set by the Board.
A license or registration expires on the date set by the Board, unless the license or registration is renewed for a 1–year term as provided in this section.
A license or registration may not be renewed for a term of longer than 2 years.

subsection.text: At least 1 month before the license or registration expires, the Board shall send to the licensee or registration holder, by first–class mail to the last known address of the licensee or registration holder, a renewal notice that states:

paragraph.text: The date on which the current license or registration expires;
The date by which the renewal application must be received by the Board for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the license or registration expires; and
The amount of the renewal fee.

subsection.text: Before a license or registration expires, the licensee or registration holder periodically may renew it for an additional term, if the licensee or registration holder:

paragraph.text: Otherwise is entitled to be licensed or registered;
Submits to the Board a renewal application on the form that the Board requires; and
Pays to the Board a renewal fee set by the Board.
Each licensee or registration holder shall notify the Board in writing of any change in the name or address of the licensee or registration holder within 60 days after the change occurred.

If a licensee or registration holder fails to notify the Board within the time required under this subsection, subject to the hearing provisions of § 3–315 of this title, the Board may impose an administrative penalty of $100.

subsection.text: The Board shall renew the license of each licensee and the registration of each registration holder who meets the requirements of this section.

Subject to the hearing provisions of § 3–315 of this title, the Board may deny a license or registration to any applicant, reprimand any licensee or registration holder, place any licensee or registration holder on probation, or suspend or revoke the license of a licensee or the registration of a registration holder if the applicant, licensee, or registration holder:

paragraph.text: Fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a license or registration for the applicant or for another;
Fraudulently or deceptively uses a license or registration;

Is disciplined by a licensing, certifying, or disciplinary authority of any other state or country or convicted or disciplined by a court of any state or country for an act that would be grounds for disciplinary action under this section;

Is convicted of or pleads guilty or nolo contendere to a felony or to a crime involving moral turpitude, whether or not any appeal or other proceeding is pending to have the conviction or plea set aside;
Willfully and knowingly:

subparagraph.text: Files a false report or record of an individual under the care of the license holder or registration holder; or
Gives any false or misleading information about a material matter in an employment application;

paragraph.text: Knowingly does any act that has been determined by the Board, in its regulations, to exceed the scope of practice authorized to the individual under this subtitle;
Provides professional services while:

subparagraph.text: Under the influence of alcohol; or
Using any narcotic or controlled dangerous substance, as defined in § 5–101 of the Criminal Law Article, or other drug that is in excess of therapeutic amounts or without valid medical indication;

paragraph.text: Does an act that is inconsistent with generally accepted professional standards in the practice of massage therapy;
Is negligent in the practice of massage therapy;
Is professionally incompetent;
Has violated any provision of this subtitle;
Submits a false statement to collect a fee;
Is physically or mentally incompetent;
Knowingly fails to report suspected child abuse in violation of § 5–704 of the Family Law Article;

Refuses, withholds from, denies, or discriminates against an individual with regard to the provision of professional services for which the licensee or registration holder is qualified to render because the individual is HIV positive;
Except in an emergency life–threatening situation where it is not feasible or practicable, fails to comply with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s guidelines on universal precautions;
Is habitually intoxicated;
Is addicted to, or habitually abuses, any narcotic or controlled dangerous substance as defined in § 5–101 of the Criminal Law Article;
Fails to cooperate with a lawful investigation conducted by the Board;
Engages in conduct that violates the professional code of ethics; or
Knowingly does an act that has been determined by the Board to be a violation of the Board’s regulations.

subsection.text: If, after a hearing under § 3–315 of this title, the Board finds that there are grounds under subsection (a) of this section to suspend or revoke a license to practice massage therapy or registration to practice non–therapeutic massage, to reprimand a licensee or registration holder, or place a licensee or registration holder on probation, the Board may impose a penalty not exceeding $5,000 in lieu of or in addition to suspending or revoking the license or registration, reprimanding the licensee or registration holder, or placing the licensee or registration holder on probation.

paragraph.text: An individual whose license or registration has been suspended or revoked by the Board shall return the license or registration to the Board.
If the suspended or revoked license or registration has been lost, the individual shall file with the Board a verified statement to that effect.

subsection.text: The Board shall file a notice for publication in the earliest publication of the Maryland Register of each revocation or suspension of a license or registration under this section within 24 hours of the revocation or suspension.

section.text: This subtitle does not limit the right of an individual to practice or advertise an occupation that the individual is otherwise authorized to practice under the Maryland Annotated Code.

subsection.text: The Board shall adopt rules and regulations to establish standards for advertising or soliciting by licensed massage therapists or registered massage practitioners.
For purposes of this section, notices mailed to patients to inform them of times for periodic appointments are not advertising or soliciting.
A licensed massage therapist or a registered massage practitioner may use a trade name in connection with the practice of massage therapy provided that:

paragraph.text: The use of the trade name is not deceptive or misleading;

The advertisement in which the trade name appears includes the name of the licensed massage therapist or registered massage practitioner or the name of the business entity providing the massage therapy services being advertised, as long as the advertisement includes the name of a licensed massage therapist or registered massage practitioner;
The name of the licensed massage therapist or registered massage practitioner providing massage therapy services appears on the billing invoices, stationery, and on any receipt given to a patient;
Treatment records are maintained that clearly identify the licensed massage therapist or registered massage practitioner who has performed the massage therapy service for the patient; and
The use of a trade name is preapproved by the Board before use.

section.text: A health care provider licensed or certified under this article may not refer patients to a person who is not a licensed massage therapist.

Notwithstanding the fact that these services are provided within the scope of their licensed practice, nothing in this subtitle requires a nonprofit health service plan, insurer, health maintenance organization, or person acting as a third party administrator to reimburse a licensed massage therapist or registered massage practitioner for any services rendered.

subsection.text: In Charles County and Washington County, the County Commissioners may adopt ordinances or regulations relating to massage establishments and the practices of massage therapists, massage practitioners, and any other individuals who provide massage for compensation.

paragraph.text: The Charles County Commissioners shall provide that the Director of the Charles County Health Department and the Office of the Sheriff for Charles County have the authority to carry out the provisions of the ordinances or regulations adopted under subsection (a) of this section.

The Washington County Commissioners shall provide that the Washington County Health Officer and the Office of the Sheriff for Washington County have the authority to carry out the provisions of the ordinances or regulations adopted under subsection (a) of this section.

section.text: This title may be cited as the “Maryland Chiropractic Act”.

Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act, this title and all rules and regulations adopted under this title shall terminate and be of no effect after July 1, 2022.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the State Board of Dental Examiners.
“Dental appliance” means any:

paragraph.text: Oral prosthesis;
Orthodontic appliance;
Regulatory appliance;
Supportive appliance; or
Other intraoral appliance or restoration.

subsection.text: “Dental hygienist” means an individual, other than a dentist, who practices dental hygiene.
“Dental laboratory” means any commercial laboratory or workroom in which a person engages in dental laboratory work.
“Dental laboratory work” means making, repairing, or altering a dental appliance extraorally.
“Dentist” means an individual who practices dentistry.

paragraph.text: “License” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a license issued by the Board to:

subparagraph.text: Practice dentistry; or
Practice dental hygiene.

paragraph.text: “License” includes, unless the context requires otherwise:

subparagraph.text: A general license to practice dentistry;
A limited license to practice dentistry;
A teacher’s license to practice dentistry;
A general license to practice dental hygiene;
A teacher’s license to practice dental hygiene;
A retired volunteer dentist’s license to practice dentistry;
A retired volunteer dental hygienist’s license to practice dental hygiene;
A volunteer dentist’s license to practice dentistry;
A volunteer dental hygienist’s license to practice dental hygiene;
A temporary volunteer dentist’s license to practice dentistry; and
A temporary dental hygienist’s license to practice dental hygiene.

paragraph.text: “Licensed dental hygienist” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a dental hygienist who is licensed by the Board to practice dental hygiene.
“Licensed dental hygienist” includes, unless the context requires otherwise, a holder of:

subparagraph.text: A general license to practice dental hygiene;
A teacher’s license to practice dental hygiene;
A retired volunteer dental hygienist’s license to practice dental hygiene;
A volunteer dental hygienist’s license to practice dental hygiene; or
A temporary volunteer dental hygienist’s license to practice dental hygiene.

paragraph.text: “Licensed dentist” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a dentist who is licensed by the Board to practice dentistry.
“Licensed dentist” includes, unless the context requires otherwise, a holder of:

subparagraph.text: A general license to practice dentistry;
A limited license to practice dentistry;
A teacher’s license to practice dentistry;
A retired volunteer dentist’s license to practice dentistry;
A volunteer dentist’s license to practice dentistry; or
A temporary volunteer dentist’s license to practice dentistry.

subsection.text: “Practice dental hygiene” means to:

paragraph.text: Perform a preliminary dental examination;
Perform a complete prophylaxis, including the removal of any deposit, accretion, or stain from the surface of a tooth or a restoration;
Polish a tooth or a restoration;
Chart cavities, restorations, missing teeth, periodontal conditions, and other features observed during preliminary examination, prophylaxis, or polishing;
Apply a medicinal agent to a tooth for a prophylactic purpose;
Take a dental X ray;
Perform a manual curettage in conjunction with scaling and root planing;
Administer local anesthesia in accordance with § 4–206.1 or § 4–206.3 of this title;
Monitor, in accordance with § 4–206.2 of this title, a patient to whom nitrous oxide is administered; or
Perform any other intraoral function that the Board authorizes by a rule or regulation adopted under § 4–206 of this title.

subsection.text: “Practice dentistry” means to:

paragraph.text: Be a manager, a proprietor, or a conductor of or an operator in any place in which a dental service or dental operation is performed intraorally;
Perform or attempt to perform any intraoral dental service or intraoral dental operation;

Diagnose, treat, or attempt to diagnose or treat any disease, injury, malocclusion, or malposition of a tooth, gum, or jaw, or structures associated with a tooth, gum, or jaw if the service, operation, or procedure is included in the curricula of an accredited dental school or in an approved dental residency program of an accredited hospital or teaching institution;
Perform or offer to perform dental laboratory work;
Place or adjust a dental appliance in a human mouth; or
Administer anesthesia for the purposes of dentistry and not as a medical specialty.

subsection.text: Except as provided in § 4–308(f)(2) of this title, “supervision” means supervision of a dental hygienist by a dentist, where the dentist may or may not be present when the dental hygienist performs the dental hygiene procedures but is available on the premises.

“Temporary dental clinic permit” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a temporary permit issued by the Board to a bona fide charitable organization to provide dental services to the poor, elderly, or disabled at a dental clinic.
“Third party” means any person who collects premiums, assumes financial risks, pays claims, or provides administrative services relating to any:

paragraph.text: Insurance policy;
Insurance contract;
Health prepayment contract;
Health care plan; or
Nonprofit health service plan contract.

Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, this title does not limit the right of an individual to practice a health occupation that the individual is authorized to practice under this article.
The provisions of this title do not affect a physician while practicing medicine, unless the physician practices dentistry as a specialty.

subsection.text: This title does not prohibit an educational program broadcast on radio or television by the Department or by the health department of a political subdivision of this State.
This title does not apply to a clinic maintained by a public school, a State institution, or charitable institution, or a business corporation, for its pupils, inmates, or employees if:

paragraph.text: The school or institution, or corporation does not advertise concerning dentistry; and
Notwithstanding the provisions of this subsection:

subparagraph.text: Each dental hygienist, dental assistant, dental technician, or other dental auxiliary employed by the clinic shall be subject to the provisions of this title; and
Each dentist employed by the clinic shall be licensed and shall be subject to the provisions of Subtitle 3 of this title.

section.text: There is a State Board of Dental Examiners in the Department.

paragraph.text: The Board consists of 16 members.
Of the 16 Board members:

subparagraph.text: 9 shall be licensed dentists;
4 shall be licensed dental hygienists; and
3 shall be consumer members.
Subject to subsection (b)(1) of this section, the Governor shall appoint the dentist Board members, with the advice of the Secretary, from a list of names submitted to the Governor by the Board.

The number of names on the list for one vacancy shall be at least four names, for two vacancies at least three names for each vacancy, and for three or more vacancies at least two names for each vacancy.

Subject to subsection (b)(2) of this section, the Governor shall appoint the dental hygienist Board members, with the advice of the Secretary, from a list of names submitted to the Governor by the Board.
The number of names on the list shall be four times the number of vacancies.

paragraph.text: The Governor shall appoint the consumer members with the advice of the Secretary and the advice and consent of the Senate.
To the extent practicable, the members appointed to the Board shall reasonably reflect the geographic, racial, ethnic, cultural, and gender diversity of the State.
For each licensed dentist vacancy, the Board shall:

subparagraph.text: Send by electronic mail or regular mail a solicitation for nominations to fill the vacancy to:

sub-subparagraph.text: Each dentist licensed by the Board; and
Each State dental organization affiliated with a national organization; and

subparagraph.text: Conduct a balloting process by which each dentist licensed by the State is eligible to vote to select the names of the licensed dentists to be submitted to the Governor.

paragraph.text: For each licensed dental hygienist vacancy, the Board shall:

subparagraph.text: Send by electronic mail or regular mail a solicitation for nominations to fill the vacancy to:

sub-subparagraph.text: Each dental hygienist licensed by the Board; and
Each State dental hygienist organization affiliated with a national organization; and

subparagraph.text: Conduct a balloting process by which each dental hygienist licensed by the State is eligible to vote to select the names of the licensed dental hygienists to be submitted to the Governor.

paragraph.text: The Board shall develop guidelines for the solicitation of nominations and balloting process that to the extent possible will result in the overall composition of the Board reasonably reflecting the geographic, racial, ethnic, and gender diversity of the State.

subsection.text: Each dentist Board member:

paragraph.text: Shall be an individual of recognized ability and honor;
Shall be a practicing holder of a general license to practice dentistry who has practiced dentistry actively in this State for at least 5 years immediately before appointment;
Shall be a resident of this State; and
In the case of a Board member belonging to an association whose members are regulated by the Board, may not be:

subparagraph.text: An officer of the association;
A member of the association’s governing board or committee;
A member of the association’s house of delegates; or
A voting member of a committee of the association that contributes to the establishment of governmental, regulatory, or legislative policy objectives of the association.

subsection.text: Each dental hygienist Board member:

paragraph.text: Shall be a practicing holder of a general license to practice dental hygiene who has practiced dental hygiene actively in this State for at least 3 years immediately before appointment;
Shall be a resident of this State;
In the case of a Board member belonging to an association whose members are regulated by the Board, may not be:

subparagraph.text: An officer of the association;
A member of the association’s governing board or committee;
A member of the association’s house of delegates; or
A voting member of a committee of the association that contributes to the establishment of governmental, regulatory, or legislative policy objectives of the association.

subsection.text: Each consumer member of the Board:

paragraph.text: Shall be a member of the general public;
May not be or ever have been a dentist or dental hygienist or in training to become a dentist or dental hygienist;
May not have a household member who is a dentist or dental hygienist or in training to become a dentist or dental hygienist;
May not participate or ever have participated in a commercial or professional field related to dentistry;
May not have a household member who participates in a commercial or professional field related to dentistry; and
May not have had within 2 years before appointment a substantial financial interest in a person regulated by the Board.

subsection.text: While a member of the Board, a consumer member may not have a substantial financial interest in a person regulated by the Board.
Before taking office, each appointee to the Board shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 4 years.
The terms of the members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on October 1, 2006.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member may not be appointed for more than 2 consecutive full terms.
To the extent practicable, the Governor shall fill any vacancy on the Board within 60 days of the date of the vacancy.
The Governor may remove a member for incompetence, misconduct, continued neglect of duties imposed by this subtitle, unprofessional conduct, or dishonorable conduct.
The Governor shall remove a member whom the Governor finds to have been absent from 2 successive Board meetings without adequate reason.

subsection.text: From among its members, the Board shall elect a president and a secretary.
The Board shall determine:

paragraph.text: The manner of election of officers;
The term of office of each officer; and
The duties of each officer.
The Board shall meet at least twice a year, at the times and places that it determines.
The Board shall hold special meetings, at the places it determines, when:

subparagraph.text: The Secretary requests a meeting; or
The Board considers a meeting necessary.

paragraph.text: After giving due notice, the president or Board secretary shall call meetings. However, the Board may meet at any time and place without notice if each member of the Board either consents in writing or attends the meeting.

subsection.text: Each member of the Board is entitled to:

paragraph.text: Compensation in accordance with the budget of the Board; and
Reimbursement for expenses at a rate determined by the Board.

subsection.text: The Board may employ a staff in accordance with the budget of the Board.
In addition to the powers set forth elsewhere in this title, the Board may:

paragraph.text: Adopt regulations governing:

subparagraph.text: The administration of general anesthesia by a licensed dentist;
The administration of sedation by a licensed dentist;
The use of a dental assistant by a licensed dentist in performing intraoral procedures;
Subject to subsection (b) of this section, the issuance of a permit to a facility not otherwise regulated where a dentist administers or has general anesthesia or sedation administered;
Subject to subsection (b) of this section, the issuance of a permit to a dentist who administers or has general anesthesia or sedation administered;

Reasonable requirements for the training and evaluation of a dentist before the dentist may administer general anesthesia or sedation other than nitrous oxide administered alone and not in conjunction with:

sub-subparagraph.text: Another method of diminishing or eliminating pain; or
Medication used for diminishing or eliminating anxiety;

subparagraph.text: Reasonable requirements for:

sub-subparagraph.text: The education, training, evaluation, and examination of a dental hygienist before the dental hygienist may perform manual curettage in conjunction with scaling and root planing; and
Performance by a dental hygienist of manual curettage in conjunction with scaling and root planing;

subparagraph.text: Reasonable requirements for:

sub-subparagraph.text: The education, training, evaluation, and examination of a dental hygienist before the dental hygienist may administer local anesthesia under § 4–206.1 of this subtitle; and
Administering by a dental hygienist of local anesthesia under § 4–206.1 of this subtitle;

subparagraph.text: Reasonable requirements for:

sub-subparagraph.text: The education, training, evaluation, and examination of a dental hygienist before a dental hygienist may monitor a patient to whom nitrous oxide is being administered, subject to § 4–206.2 of this subtitle; and
Monitoring by a dental hygienist, in accordance with § 4–206.2 of this subtitle, of a patient to whom nitrous oxide is being administered;

subparagraph.text: Reasonable requirements for the education, training, evaluation, and examination of a dental hygienist before a dental hygienist may administer local anesthesia by inferior alveolar nerve block under § 4–206.3 of this subtitle;
The discipline of a holder of any facility or administration permit for the administration of general anesthesia or sedation; and
The release of patient dental records;

paragraph.text: After consulting with the State Board of Pharmacy, adopt regulations regarding the dispensing of prescription drugs by a licensed dentist;
On receipt of a written and signed complaint, investigate an alleged violation of this title;
After consulting with the Maryland Dental Hygienists’ Association, adopt regulations establishing continuing education requirements for licensed dental hygienists;
Adopt regulations establishing continuing education requirements for licensed dentists;

On receipt of a written and signed complaint, including a referral from the Commissioner of Labor and Industry, conduct an unannounced inspection of the office of a dentist, other than an office of a dentist in a hospital, related institution, freestanding medical facility, or a freestanding birthing center, to determine compliance at that office with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s guidelines on universal precautions; and

Establish committees from among its members to facilitate and assist the Board in discharging its duties and responsibilities under this title by evaluating, reviewing, and making recommendations to the Board on matters referred to the committees by the Board. The committees established shall include, but may not be limited to:

subparagraph.text: A nominations committee;
A regulations committee;

A committee on dental hygiene composed of 3 dental hygienists, 1 dentist, and 1 consumer to which the Board shall refer all matters within the Board’s jurisdiction under this title relating to or affecting the practice of dental hygiene for the committee’s evaluation, review, and recommendation;
A disciplinary committee; and
Such other committees as the Board considers appropriate.

subsection.text: The Board may not require a facility or a dentist to obtain a permit if a dentist:

paragraph.text: Administers nitrous oxide that is not administered in conjunction with:

subparagraph.text: Another method of diminishing or eliminating pain; or
Medication used for diminishing or eliminating anxiety; or

paragraph.text: Prescribes or administers oral medication to a patient within the maximum recommended dosage for that patient for the sole purpose of diminishing or eliminating anxiety that is not prescribed in conjunction with:

subparagraph.text: Another method of diminishing or eliminating pain; or
The administration of nitrous oxide.

subsection.text: In addition to the duties set forth elsewhere in this title, the Board shall:

paragraph.text: Keep a record of each license and each action taken under § 4–315 of this title;
Have an official seal; and
Adopt rules, regulations, and bylaws as may be necessary to carry out the provisions of this title.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this section, the Board may adopt rules and regulations that authorize a licensed dental hygienist to perform additional intraoral functions.
The Board may not authorize a licensed dental hygienist to:

paragraph.text: Perform a diagnosis;
Perform an extraction;
Repair a cavity;
Correct tooth placement;
Perform a surgical procedure; or
Administer anesthesia other than the following:

subparagraph.text: Topical anesthesia; or
Local anesthesia in accordance with § 4–206.1 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Subject to the requirements of subsections (b) and (c) of this section, a dental hygienist may administer local anesthesia by infiltration for the purpose of anesthetizing soft tissue to facilitate the performance of dental hygiene procedures, but not as a medical specialty, provided the administration of local anesthesia is under the supervision of a dentist who:

paragraph.text: Is physically present on the premises; and
Prescribes the administration of local anesthesia by the dental hygienist.

subsection.text: Before a dental hygienist may administer local anesthesia under subsection (a) of this section, the dental hygienist shall successfully complete the following:

paragraph.text: Any educational requirements established by the Board; and
A written and clinical examination as required by the Board.

subsection.text: A dental hygienist shall obtain the educational requirements established by the Board under subsection (b)(1) of this section from an accredited dental hygiene program.
