Using any narcotic or controlled dangerous substance, as defined in § 5–101 of the Criminal Law Article, or other drug that is in excess of therapeutic amounts or without valid medical indication;

paragraph.text: Practices dentistry in a professionally incompetent manner or in a grossly incompetent manner;
Has had a license to practice dentistry revoked or suspended in any other state;
Uses another person as an in–person solicitor of business;
Practices or offers to practice dentistry under a name other than that on the license;
Uses in connection with the practice of dentistry a business entity name or a trade name that is not authorized by law;
Permits an unauthorized individual to practice dentistry under the supervision of the applicant or licensee;
Permits a dental hygienist to practice dental hygiene:

subparagraph.text: In an unauthorized place; or
Without being supervised by a licensed dentist as required by § 4–308 of this subtitle;

paragraph.text: Violates any restriction on advertising in § 4–503 of this title;
Suggests, requests, or in any way directs that a patient appear at a dental laboratory;
Violates any provision in Subtitle 4 of this title, which relates to work authorizations for dental laboratory work;
Behaves dishonorably or unprofessionally, or violates a professional code of ethics pertaining to the dentistry profession;
Is mentally or physically incompetent to practice dentistry;
Violates any rule or regulation adopted by the Board;

Is disciplined by a licensing or disciplinary authority of any other state or country or convicted or disciplined by a court of any state or country for an act that would be grounds for disciplinary action under the Board’s disciplinary statutes;
Willfully makes or files a false report or record in the practice of dentistry;
Willfully fails to file or record any report as required by law, willfully impedes or obstructs the filing or recording of the report, or induces another to fail to file or record the report;

Knowingly submits to a third party any claim form, bill, or statement which contains any misleading, deceptive, false, incomplete, or fraudulent representation asserting a fee which is greater than the fee that the dentist usually accepts as payment in full for any given dental appliance, procedure, or service;

Abrogates or forgives the copayment provisions of any insurance policy, insurance contract, health prepayment contract, health care plan, or nonprofit health service plan contract by accepting the payment received from a third party as full payment, unless the dentist discloses to the third party that the patient’s payment portion will not be collected;
Uses or promotes or causes the use of any misleading, deceiving, or untruthful advertising matter, promotional literature, or testimonial;

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, divides a fee with another dentist if the division is not in proportion to the services performed and the responsibility assumed by each dentist;
A dentist may divide a fee with another dentist who is a partner or an associate in the same dental practice if dividing the fee does not increase the fee for the service charged to the patient;

paragraph.text: Fails to comply with the provisions of § 12–102 of this article;

Refuses, withholds from, denies, or discriminates against an individual with regard to the provision of professional services for which the licensee is licensed and qualified to render because the individual is HIV positive;
Except in an emergency life–threatening situation where it is not feasible or practicable, fails to comply with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s guidelines on universal precautions;
Fails to display the notice required under § 4–313(d) of this subtitle;

Fails to begin to fulfill a public service requirement within 1 year of when the assignment is to begin that was a condition of the applicant or licensee receiving State or federal loans or scholarships for the applicant’s or licensee’s dental education;
Fails to comply with any Board order; or
Willfully and without legal justification, fails to cooperate with a lawful investigation conducted by the Board.

subsection.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 4–318 of this subtitle, the Board may deny a general license to practice dental hygiene, a teacher’s license to practice dental hygiene, or a temporary license to practice dental hygiene to any applicant, reprimand any licensed dental hygienist, place any licensed dental hygienist on probation, or suspend or revoke the license of any licensed dental hygienist, if the applicant or licensee:

paragraph.text: Fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a license for the applicant or licensee or for another;
Fraudulently or deceptively uses a license;
Behaves unprofessionally or in a grossly immoral way, or violates a professional code of ethics pertaining to the dental hygiene profession;
Practices dental hygiene in an unauthorized place;
Practices dental hygiene in a professionally incompetent manner or in a grossly incompetent manner;

Is disciplined by a licensing or disciplinary authority of any other state or country or convicted or disciplined by a court of any state or country for an act that would be grounds for disciplinary action under the Board’s disciplinary statutes;
Performs intraoral functions not authorized by statute or the rules and regulations of the Board;
Violates the requirements of § 4–313 of this subtitle that relate to display of licenses and renewal certificates;
Violates any rule or regulation adopted by the Board;
Is mentally or physically incompetent to practice dental hygiene;

Is convicted of or pleads guilty or nolo contendere to a felony or to a crime involving moral turpitude, whether or not any appeal or other proceeding is pending to have the conviction or plea set aside;
Provides professional services while:

subparagraph.text: Under the influence of alcohol; or
Using any narcotic or controlled dangerous substance, as defined in § 5–101 of the Criminal Law Article, or other drug that is in excess of therapeutic amounts or without valid medical indication;

paragraph.text: Willfully makes or files a false report or record in the practice of dental hygiene;
Willfully fails to file or record any report as required by law, willfully impedes or obstructs the filing or recording of the report, or induces another to fail to file or record the report;

Refuses, withholds from, denies, or discriminates against an individual with regard to the provision of professional services for which the licensee is licensed and qualified to render because the individual is HIV positive;
Except in an emergency life–threatening situation where it is not feasible or practicable, fails to comply with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s guidelines on universal precautions;
Fails to comply with any Board order; or
Willfully and without legal justification, fails to cooperate with a lawful investigation conducted by the Board.

subsection.text: On its own initiative or on a written complaint filed with the Board by any person, the Board may commence proceedings under § 4-315 of this subtitle.
If a person who is not a member of the Board files a complaint, the complaint shall:

paragraph.text: Be in writing;
Be verified by a person who is familiar with the alleged facts;
Request Board action; and
Be filed with the secretary of the Board.
The Board shall investigate each complaint filed with the Board if the complaint:

subparagraph.text: Alleges facts that are grounds for action under § 4-315 of this subtitle; and
Meets the requirements of this section.

paragraph.text: If the Board begins action on its own initiative or if after investigation it elects to substitute its own complaint for one filed by a person who is not a member of the Board, the Board shall prepare a written complaint.

subsection.text: If, after performing any preliminary investigation, the Board determines that an allegation involving fees for professional or ancillary services does not constitute grounds for discipline or other action, the Board may refer the allegation concerning a member of a professional society or association composed of providers of dental care to a committee of the Society for Mediation.

If after a hearing under § 4-318 of this subtitle the Board finds that there are grounds under § 4-315 of this subtitle to suspend or revoke a general license to practice dentistry, a limited license to practice dentistry, or a teacher’s license to practice dentistry, or to reprimand a licensed dentist, the Board may impose a penalty not exceeding $5,000:

paragraph.text: Instead of suspending the license; or
In addition to suspending or revoking the license or reprimanding the licensee.

subsection.text: The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this section into the General Fund of this State.

Except as otherwise provided in the Administrative Procedure Act, before the Board takes any action under § 4-315 of this subtitle, it shall give the individual against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Board.
The Board shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with the Administrative Procedure Act.
In accordance with the State budget, the Board may authorize payment of fees and travel expenses of witnesses who testify in a proceeding under this section.
The individual may be represented at the hearing by counsel.
The Board may administer oaths and take depositions of witnesses in any proceeding under this section.

paragraph.text: Over the signature of an officer or the administrator of the Board, the Board may issue subpoenas and administer oaths to witnesses in connection with any investigation under this title and any hearings or proceedings before it.
The Board shall issue subpoenas on behalf of the individual if the individual requests in writing that the Board do so.

If, without lawful excuse, a person disobeys a subpoena from the Board or an order by the Board to take an oath or to testify or answer a question, then, on petition of the Board, a court of competent jurisdiction may punish the person as for contempt of court.

If, without lawful excuse, an individual disobeys a subpoena from the Board or an order by the Board to take an oath, testify, or answer a question, on petition of the Board, a court of competent jurisdiction may compel compliance with the subpoena.

subsection.text: If after due notice the individual against whom the action is contemplated fails or refuses to appear, nevertheless the Board may hear and determine the matter.

Except as provided in this section for an action under § 4-315 of this subtitle, a person aggrieved by a final decision of the Board in a contested case, as defined in the Administrative Procedure Act, may:

paragraph.text: Appeal that decision to the Board of Review; and
Then take any further appeal allowed by the Administrative Procedure Act.
Any person aggrieved by a final decision of the Board under § 4-315 of this subtitle may not appeal to the Secretary or Board of Review but may take a direct judicial appeal.
The appeal shall be made as provided for judicial review of final decisions in the Administrative Procedure Act.

subsection.text: An action may be maintained in the name of this State or the Board to enjoin:

paragraph.text: Unauthorized practice of dentistry or dental hygiene;
Conduct that is a ground for disciplinary action under § 4-315(a) of this subtitle;
Conduct that violates any prohibition in Subtitle 4 of this title, which relates to dental laboratory work; or
Conduct that violates the practice limitations of § 4-603 of this title.

subsection.text: An action under this section may be brought by:

paragraph.text: The Board, in its own name;
The Attorney General, in the name of this State; or
A State’s Attorney, in the name of this State.

subsection.text: An action under this section shall be brought in the county where the defendant:

paragraph.text: Resides; or
Engages in the acts sought to be enjoined.

subsection.text: Proof of actual damage or that any person will sustain any damage if an injunction is not granted is not required for an action under this section.

An action under this section is in addition to and not instead of criminal prosecution for unauthorized practice of dentistry under § 4-601 of this title or disciplinary action under § 4-315 of this subtitle.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Dental technician” means an individual who does dental laboratory work.
“Subcontracted work authorization” means a written request for subcontracted dental laboratory work.
“Work authorization” means a written request for dental laboratory work.
Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, a person other than a licensed dentist may not do dental laboratory work unless the person:

paragraph.text: Works under a work authorization that meets the requirements of § 4-403 of this subtitle; and
Uses casts or models made from impressions taken by a licensed dentist.

subsection.text: The requirements of this subtitle that relate to work authorizations do not apply to:

paragraph.text: A dental laboratory on the premises of a dental office that is used only by the licensed dentists practicing in the office; or
A dental student, dental technician, or student dental technician while doing dental laboratory work at the educational institution, hospital, or clinic with which the individual is associated.

subsection.text: The work authorization required by § 4-402 of this subtitle for dental laboratory work shall:

paragraph.text: Be on the form that the Board requires;
Be signed by a licensed dentist who requests the work; and
Contain the information required by this section.

subsection.text: The work authorization shall be prepared in duplicate and contain:

paragraph.text: The name and address of the dental laboratory to do the work;
Identification of the patient by name or number;
The date on which the work authorization form was completed;
A description of the work to be done, including diagrams if necessary;
A specification of the type of dental materials to be used; and
The name and license number of the dentist who requests the work.

subsection.text: A dental laboratory named in a work authorization may subcontract dental laboratory work, if that dental laboratory:

paragraph.text: Completes in duplicate the subcontracted work authorization form that the Board requires; and
Complies with the record keeping requirements of § 4-404 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Board shall publish:

paragraph.text: An approved standard work authorization form; and
An approved standard subcontracted work authorization form that is of a color different from the standard work authorization form.

subsection.text: A dental laboratory in this State may do dental laboratory work on the request of a dentist licensed and practicing in any other state or a foreign country if the request:

paragraph.text: Is on the form that the Board requires or a reasonably equivalent form; and
Otherwise meets the requirements of this subtitle.
The dentist who signs a work authorization shall:

subparagraph.text: Send the original to the dental laboratory named on the work authorization; and
Keep the copy.

paragraph.text: The dental laboratory named in the original work authorization shall:

subparagraph.text: Send the original of a subcontracted work authorization to the dental laboratory that is to do the subcontracted work; and
Keep the copy.

paragraph.text: The person who keeps or receives the original or copy of a work authorization or subcontracted work authorization shall keep it for at least 1 year.

If a subcontracted work authorization is issued, the dental laboratory named in the original work authorization shall attach the original work authorization form to the copy of the subcontracted work authorization form and keep the two together in the files of the dental laboratory for at least 1 year.

subsection.text: If a dentist uses a patient identification number instead of a name on a work authorization, the dentist shall keep in the dentist’s office a cross reference that translates the number to the name of the specific patient.

section.text: A dental laboratory may make dental appliances for research, technique samples, or training purposes:

paragraph.text: Without a work authorization if the dental laboratory annually secures permission from the Board to use plastic typdont or dentoform type models for this fabrication; or
Under a work authorization signed by a licensed dentist that gives the dental laboratory permission to use the dentist’s cast of a particular patient and that contains:

subparagraph.text: The name and address of the dental laboratory;
Patient identification by name or number;
The date on which the written work authorization form was completed; and
The name and license number of the dentist who signs the form.

subsection.text: A dental laboratory may not accept a request for dental laboratory work unless the request meets the requirements of this subtitle.
A licensed dentist may not:

paragraph.text: Suggest, request, or in any way direct that a patient appear at a dental laboratory; or
Sign a work request that does not contain all the information required by this subtitle.
To determine compliance with this subtitle, the Board may inspect, at random, the work authorization forms and files kept by a licensed dentist or dental laboratory.
The Board may appoint any person, including a dental technician, to conduct the inspection permitted by this subsection.

subsection.text: Doing dental laboratory work while not in possession of a work authorization or a subcontracted work authorization that meets the requirements of this subtitle is prima facie evidence of a violation of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Dental review committee” means a committee or board that:

subparagraph.text: Is within one of the categories described in subsection (b) of this section; and
Performs any of the functions listed in subsection (c) of this section.

paragraph.text: “Provider of dental care” means any person who is licensed by law to provide dental care to individuals.

subsection.text: For purposes of this section, a dental review committee is:

paragraph.text: A regulatory board or agency established by State or federal law to license, certify, or discipline any provider of dental care;
A committee of the Maryland State Dental Association or any of its component societies, including a dentist rehabilitation committee as defined in § 4–501.1 of this subtitle;
A committee of the Maryland Dental Society or any of its component societies;
A committee of the Maryland Dental Hygienists’ Association, or any of its component societies, including a dental hygienist rehabilitation committee as defined in § 4–508 of this subtitle;
A committee of any professional society or association composed of providers of dental care;

A committee of the medical staff or other committee of a hospital or related institution, if the governing board of the hospital or related institution forms and approves the committee or approves the written bylaws under which the committee operates;

Any person, including a professional standard review organization, that contracts with an agency of this State or of the federal government to perform any of the functions listed in subsection (c) of this section; or

Any person that contracts with a provider of dental care to perform any of those functions listed in subsection (c) of this section that are limited to the review of services provided by the provider of dental care.

subsection.text: For purposes of this section, a dental review committee:

paragraph.text: Evaluates and seeks to improve the quality of dental care provided by providers of dental care;
Evaluates the need for and the level of performance of dental care provided by providers of dental care;
Evaluates the qualifications, competence, and performance of providers of dental care;
Evaluates and acts on matters that relate to the discipline of any provider of dental care; or

Evaluates and provides assistance to any provider of dental care in need of treatment and rehabilitation for alcoholism, drug abuse, chemical dependency, or other physical, emotional, or mental condition.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this section, the proceedings, records, and files of a dental review committee are not discoverable and are not admissible in evidence in any civil action arising out of matters that are being reviewed and evaluated by the dental review committee.
Subsection (d) of this section does not apply to:

paragraph.text: A civil action brought by a party to the proceedings of the dental review committee who claims to be aggrieved by the decision of the dental review committee; or
Any record or document that is considered by the dental review committee and that otherwise would be subject to discovery and introduction into evidence in a civil trial.

subsection.text: A person who acts in good faith and within the scope of jurisdiction of a dental review committee is not civilly liable for any action as a member of the dental review committee or for giving information to, participating in, or contributing to the function of the dental review committee.

In this section, “Dental Well–Being Committee” means the committee of the Maryland State Dental Association that evaluates and provides assistance to any provider of dental care in need of treatment and rehabilitation for alcoholism, drug abuse, chemical dependency, or other physical, emotional, or mental condition.

paragraph.text: Subject to the provisions of paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Maryland State Dental Association shall appoint the members of the Dental Well–Being Committee.
At least one member of the Dental Well–Being Committee shall be a member of the Maryland Dental Society.

subsection.text: The Board shall fund the budget of the Dental Well–Being Committee as provided in § 4–207 of this title.
The Legislative Auditor shall audit the accounts and transactions of the Dental Well–Being Committee as provided in § 2–1220 of the State Government Article.

In accordance with the federal Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 1986, the State elects not to be governed by the provisions of the Act that provide limitations on damages for suits brought under State law against dental review bodies and to individuals participating in professional peer review activities.
For suits brought under State law, the State shall be governed by this title.
A licensed dentist may not advertise:

paragraph.text: To guarantee any dental work;
Making an undifferentiated claim to do dental work painlessly;
To do dental work in a superior manner; or
Falsely or in a manner that tends to deceive or mislead the public.
A licensed dentist may not:

subparagraph.text: Use the designation “Dental Surgeon” on a sign that bears the name of the licensee; or
Include a specialty designation in a card, letterhead, sign, telephone directory listing, or other printed matter that bears the name of the licensee, unless:

sub-subparagraph.text: The licensee is identified by the Board as a specialist in the designated field under § 4-504 of this subtitle; and
The language used to refer to the specialty is approved by the Board.

paragraph.text: A licensed dentist may use the designations “Dr.”, “dentist”, “D.D.S.”, or “D.M.D.” on a sign that bears the licensee’s name.

subsection.text: A person who is not a licensed dentist may not solicit or advertise to the general public in any manner that the person alters, constructs, duplicates, repairs, or supplies a dental appliance.
A licensed dentist may use a trade name in connection with the practice of dentistry provided that:

paragraph.text: The use of the trade name is not deceptive or misleading;

The advertisement in which the trade name appears includes the name of the licensed dentist or the name of the business entity providing the dental services being advertised as long as the advertisement includes the name of a licensed dentist;
The name of the licensed dentist providing dental services shall appear on the billing invoices, and on the receipts if any are given to patients; and
Treatment records are maintained that clearly identify the licensed dentist who has performed the dental service for any patient.

subsection.text: A licensed dentist may not represent to the public that the licensee is a specialist in any field of specialized dental practice unless identified as a specialist in that field by the Board.
If a licensed dentist requests, the Board shall determine whether the licensee qualifies for Board identification as a specialist.
The Board may approve any area of specialty recognized by the Commission on Dental Accreditation or its successor organization.

paragraph.text: The Board shall adopt rules and regulations concerning application procedures, fees, and required qualifications for identification as a specialist.
The qualifications required of applicants for Board identification as a specialist may include:

subparagraph.text: The requirements established by various specialty certifying boards of the American Dental Association;
Education;
Professional experience; and
Whether, before July 1, 1979, the applicant represented to the public, in an ethical manner, that the applicant was a specialist.

subsection.text: In approving additional specialties, the Board may consider those fields recognized and approved by the American Dental Association.
The Board is a depository for and the arbitrator of the specialty qualification standards of the American Dental Association in this State.
The Board of Dental Examiners shall:

paragraph.text: Define, for the purpose of this section, the terms “dental radiation technologist” and “practice dental radiation technology”;
Adopt rules and regulations concerning qualifications, training, certification, monitoring of, and enforcement requirements for a dental radiation technologist; and
Provide for a requirement to ensure competency in new safety and technological advances.

subsection.text: The qualifications required of applicants for Board certification as a dental radiation technologist shall include requirements established by:

paragraph.text: The American Dental Association; or
Any applicable federal standards for training and certification.

subsection.text: After July 1, 1988, an individual must be certified by the Board as a dental radiation technologist before a licensed dentist may employ the individual to practice dental radiation technology.
After July 1, 1988, an individual may not practice dental radiation technology unless certified by the Board.

section.text: When using radiation for the purposes of dental diagnosis a patient’s body shall be protected under the supervision of a licensed dentist. The State Board of Dental Examiners shall adopt rules and regulations of patient protection to be applied during the use of radiation.

A dentist who has successfully completed a physical evaluation program or course at an accredited hospital or teaching institution, who is qualified and identified by the Board as a specialist in oral surgery, and who admits to a hospital any patient without known medical problems, if the dentist is deemed by the hospital to be qualified to do so:

paragraph.text: May complete a hospital admission history and a physical examination of that patient; and
Shall assess the medical risks of the proposed procedures to that patient.

subsection.text: In this section, “Dental Hygiene Well–Being Committee” means the committee of the Maryland Dental Hygienists’ Association that evaluates and provides assistance to any dental hygienist, dental radiation technologist, or dental assistant in need of treatment and rehabilitation for alcoholism, drug abuse, chemical dependency, or other physical, emotional, or mental condition.
The Maryland Dental Hygienists’ Association shall appoint the members of the Dental Hygiene Well–Being Committee.
The Board shall fund the budget of the Dental Hygiene Well–Being Committee as provided in § 4–207 of this title.
The Legislative Auditor shall audit the accounts and transactions of the Dental Hygiene Well–Being Committee as provided in § 2–1220 of the State Government Article.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, the proceedings, records, and files of the Dental Hygiene Well–Being Committee are not discoverable and are not admissible in evidence in any civil action arising out of matters that are being or have been reviewed and evaluated by the Dental Hygiene Well–Being Committee.

Paragraph (1) of this subsection does not apply to any record or document that is considered by the Dental Hygiene Well–Being Committee and that otherwise would be subject to discovery or introduction into evidence in a civil action.
For purposes of this subsection, civil action does not include a proceeding before the Board or judicial review of a proceeding before the Board.

subsection.text: A person who acts in good faith and within the scope of jurisdiction of a Dental Hygiene Well–Being Committee is not civilly liable for any action as a member of the Dental Hygiene Well–Being Committee or for giving information to, participating in, or contributing to the function of the Well–Being Committee.

Except as otherwise provided in this title, a person may not practice, attempt to practice, or offer to practice dentistry or dental hygiene on a human being in this State unless licensed by the Board.
A person may not aid or abet unauthorized practice of dental hygiene in this State.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in this section, unless authorized to practice dentistry under this title, a person may not represent to the public by title, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the person is authorized to practice dentistry in this State.

Unless authorized to practice dental hygiene under this title, a person may not represent to the public by title, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the person is authorized to practice dental hygiene in this State.

subsection.text: This title does not affect the right of a holder of a dental degree who does not directly or indirectly practice or attempt to practice dentistry in this State to use the degree or an abbreviation for the degree in connection with the name of the holder.
Except as otherwise provided by law, a licensed dentist may not practice dentistry:

paragraph.text: Under a name other than the name of the licensee;
As a business entity; or
Under the name of a business entity.

subsection.text: A licensed dentist may practice, under the name of the licensee, as an employee of a health maintenance organization that is certified by the State Insurance Commissioner.
A licensed dentist may practice, under the name of the licensee, as a member of a limited liability company.

section.text: The clerk of each district and circuit court shall:

paragraph.text: Report to the Board each conviction of or entry of a plea of guilty or nolo contendere by a dentist or a dental hygienist for any felony or crime involving moral turpitude; and
Submit the report within 10 working days of the conviction or entry of the plea.

section.text: A dental hygienist may not own or operate a dental practice or a dental hygiene practice.

subsection.text: A person who practices or attempts to practice dentistry without a license in violation of § 4-601(a) of this subtitle or represents to the public in violation of § 4-602 of this subtitle that the person is authorized to practice dentistry is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to:

paragraph.text: For a first offense, a fine not exceeding $2,000 or imprisonment in jail not exceeding 6 months; or
For a subsequent offense, a fine not exceeding $6,000 or imprisonment in the State penitentiary not exceeding 1 year.

subsection.text: A person who practices or attempts to practice dental hygiene without a license in violation of § 4-601(a) of this subtitle, aids or abets unauthorized practice of dental hygiene in violation of § 4-601(b) of this subtitle, or represents to the public in violation of § 4-602 of this subtitle that the person is authorized to practice dental hygiene is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000.

A person who violates any provision of Subtitle 4 of this title, which relates to dental laboratory work, or who advertises a dental appliance in violation of § 4-503(c) of this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $2,000 or imprisonment in jail not exceeding 6 months.

section.text: This title may be cited as the “Maryland Dentistry Act”.

Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Program Evaluation Act, this title and all rules and regulations adopted under this title shall terminate and be of no effect after July 1, 2021.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the State Board of Dietetic Practice.
“Certified nutrition specialist” means an individual certified by the Certification Board for Nutrition Specialists, the accrediting body of the American College of Nutrition.
“Dietitian-nutritionist” means, unless the context requires otherwise, an individual who is licensed by the Board to practice dietetics.
“License” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a license issued by the Board to practice dietetics.

paragraph.text: “Medical device” means a health care product used in the diagnosis, treatment, or prevention of disease.
“Medical device” does not mean:

subparagraph.text: A drug;
A surgical or dental instrument;
Physical therapy equipment;
X-ray apparatus; or
A component part or accessory of any of the items listed in this paragraph.

subsection.text: “Medical nutrition” means the nutritional advice or counsel provided to an individual by a licensee in their professional capacity that is designed for an individual to alleviate a specific physiological complaint, condition, or symptom.

paragraph.text: “Practice dietetics” means to apply the principles derived from integrating knowledge of food, biochemistry, physiology, management science, behavioral science, and social science to human nutrition.
“Practice dietetics” includes:

subparagraph.text: Assessing individual and community food practices and nutritional status using anthropometric, biochemical, clinical, dietary, and demographic data, for clinical, research, and program planning purposes;
Developing, establishing, and evaluating nutritional care plans that establish priorities, goals, and objectives for meeting nutrient needs for individuals or groups;
Nutrition counseling and education as a part of preventive or restorative health care throughout the life cycle;
Determining, applying, and evaluating standards for food and nutrition services; and
Applying scientific research to the role of food in the maintenance of health and the treatment of disease.

subsection.text: “Registered dietitian” means an individual registered with the Commission on Dietetic Registration, the accrediting body of the American Dietetic Association.
“Supervision” means the management of an individual who aids in the practice of dietetics by a licensed dietitian-nutritionist who may or may not be on the premises.

section.text: The purpose of this title is to protect the lives and health of the people of this State by:

paragraph.text: Setting standards for the practice of dietetics; and
Limiting the use of the title “licensed dietitian-nutritionist” to individuals who meet those standards.

subsection.text: This title does not limit the right of an individual to practice a health occupation that the individual is authorized to practice under this article.
This title does not limit the right of an individual or group to provide services and information related to nonmedical nutrition while:

paragraph.text: Employed by or operating a health, weight loss, or fitness program;
Employed by or operating a health food store;

Employed by or operating a business that sells health products including dietary supplements, food, or food materials, or provides nonmedical nutritional information or distributes nutritional literature; or
Conducting classes or disseminating information related to nonmedical nutrition.

subsection.text: This title does not limit the right of an individual to provide services related only to the purchasing, preparation, and service of food to groups of people.
This title does not limit the right of an individual to provide nonmedical nutritional information or to distribute nutritional literature.

section.text: There is a State Board of Dietetic Practice in the Department.

paragraph.text: The Board consists of nine members.
Of the nine Board members:

subparagraph.text: Seven shall be dietitian-nutritionists licensed on or after July 1, 2004 to practice dietetics in Maryland, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: One member who is engaged primarily in clinical dietetic practice;
One member who is engaged primarily in community or public health dietetic practice;
One member who is engaged primarily in administrative dietetic practice;
One member who is engaged primarily in consulting dietetic practice;
One member who is a faculty member in the field of dietetics or nutritional science; and
Two members who are certified nutrition specialists and who may not be registered dietitians; and

subparagraph.text: Two shall be consumer members.

paragraph.text: The Governor shall appoint the licensed dietitian-nutritionist members with the advice of the Secretary and with the advice and consent of the Senate from a list submitted as provided in subsection (b) of this section.
The Governor shall appoint the consumer members with the advice of the Secretary and the advice and consent of the Senate.

For each licensed dietitian-nutritionist vacancy, the Board shall compile a list of names to be submitted to the Secretary in accordance with this subsection, including at least three names for each of the vacancies.
The Board shall notify all licensed dietitian-nutritionists in the State of the vacancy to solicit nominations to fill the vacancy.

The Maryland Dietetic Association or the Maryland Nutritionists Association shall nominate qualified individuals to fill the vacancy within 30 days after the notice required in paragraph (2) of this subsection is given.

The Maryland Dietetic Association may comment on an individual nominated by the Maryland Nutritionists Association under paragraph (3) of this subsection within 30 days after the nomination and before the list is submitted to the Secretary.

The Maryland Nutritionists Association may comment on an individual nominated by the Maryland Dietetic Association under paragraph (3) of this subsection within 30 days after the nomination and before the list is submitted to the Secretary.
Each licensed dietitian-nutritionist member of the Board shall:

subparagraph.text: Be a citizen of the United States;
Be a resident of the State; and
Have practiced dietetics for at least 5 of the last 10 years.

paragraph.text: The consumer member of the Board:

subparagraph.text: Shall be a citizen of the United States;
Shall be a resident of this State;
May not be a licensed dietitian-nutritionist or have a household member who is a licensed dietitian-nutritionist;
May not have a financial interest in the provision of goods or services to licensed dietitian-nutritionists; and
May not have a financial interest in the provision of dietary goods or services to consumers.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 4 years.
The terms of the members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on July 1, 1985.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
To the extent practicable, the Governor shall fill any vacancy on the Board within 75 days of the date of the vacancy.
A member may not serve more than 2 consecutive full terms.

subsection.text: Upon the recommendation of the Secretary, the Governor may remove a member whom the Secretary finds to have been absent from 2 successive Board meetings without adequate reason.
From among its members, the Board annually shall elect a chairman, a vice chairman, and a secretary.
The Board shall determine:

paragraph.text: The manner of election of officers; and
The duties of each officer.

subsection.text: A majority of the members then serving on the Board is a quorum.
The Board shall determine the times and places of its meetings.
A member of the Board:

paragraph.text: Is entitled to compensation in accordance with the budget of the Board; and
Is entitled to reimbursement for expenses at a rate determined by the Board.

subsection.text: The Board may employ a staff in accordance with the budget of the Board.
In addition to the powers set forth elsewhere in this subtitle, the Board may:

paragraph.text: Adopt regulations to carry out the provisions of this subtitle;
Sue to enforce any provision of this subtitle by injunction; and
Issue subpoenas, summon witnesses, administer oaths, take affidavits, and take testimony about matters that relate to the jurisdiction of the Board.

subsection.text: In addition to the duties set forth elsewhere in this subtitle, the Board shall:

paragraph.text: Keep a list of all dietitian-nutritionists who are currently licensed;
Keep a record of its proceedings; and
Submit an annual report of its transactions for the previous fiscal year to the Governor by September 30 of each year.

subsection.text: There is a State Board of Dietetic Practice Fund.

paragraph.text: The Board may set reasonable fees for the issuance and renewal of licenses.
The fees charged shall be set so as to approximate the cost of maintaining the Board.
Funds to cover the expenses of the Board members shall be generated by fees set under this section.
The Board shall pay all funds collected under this title to the Comptroller of the State.
The Comptroller shall distribute the funds to the State Board of Dietetic Practice Fund.
The Fund shall be used to cover the actual documented direct and indirect costs of fulfilling the statutory and regulatory duties of the Board as provided by the provisions of this article.
The Fund is a continuing, nonlapsing fund, not subject to § 7-302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
Any unspent portions of the Fund may not be transferred or revert to the General Fund of the State, but shall remain in the Fund to be used for the purposes specified in this article.
Except as otherwise provided by law, no other State money may be used to support the Fund.
A designee of the Board shall administer the Fund.
Moneys in the Fund may be expended only for any lawful purpose authorized under the provisions of this article.

subsection.text: The Legislative Auditor shall audit the accounts and transactions of the Fund as provided in § 2-1220 of the State Government Article.
Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, an individual shall be licensed by the Board before the individual may practice dietetics in the State.
The following individuals may practice dietetics without a license:

paragraph.text: A student or trainee, working under the supervision of a licensed dietitian-nutritionist while fulfilling an experience requirement or pursuing a course of study to meet requirements for licensure, for a limited period of time as determined by the Board;
An individual employed by the United States government to practice dietetics, while practicing within the scope of that employment; and
An individual who aids in the practice of dietetics, if the individual works under the supervision of a licensed dietitian-nutritionist or licensed physician.

subsection.text: To qualify for a license, an applicant shall be an individual who meets the requirements of this section.
The applicant must be of good moral character.
The applicant must be at least 18 years old.
The applicant for licensure as a dietitian-nutritionist shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: Have satisfactorily completed academic requirements for the field of dietetics as approved by the Board; and
Have received a baccalaureate degree from a college or university accredited by an educational accrediting association recognized by the Council on Higher Education and Accreditation; or

subparagraph.text: Have received a master’s or doctoral degree from a college or university accredited by an educational accrediting association recognized by the Council on Higher Education and Accreditation in nutritional sciences (with emphasis in human nutrition), food and nutrition, dietetics, human nutrition, community nutrition, public health nutrition, or equivalent training approved by the Board;

paragraph.text: Have satisfactorily completed a program of supervised clinical experience approved by the Board; and

subparagraph.text: Submit to the Board proof of certification by the Certification Board for Nutritional Specialists; or
Submit to the Board proof of registration with the Commission on Dietetic Registration of the American Dietetic Association.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, the applicant must pass an examination approved by the Board under this subtitle.
The applicant shall meet any other qualifications or requirements that the Board establishes for license applicants.
An applicant for a license shall:

paragraph.text: Submit an application to the Board on the form that the Board requires;
Pay the application fee set by the Board; and
Provide proof of passing an examination approved by the Board.

subsection.text: In addition to any other requirements of this section, an applicant who is or has been licensed to practice dietetics in another state or country shall submit proof of good standing in that state or country or proof of eligibility for a license in good standing in that state or country.

section.text: The Board shall determine the passing score for the examination approved.

subsection.text: Subject to the provisions of this section, the Board may waive an examination requirement of this title for an individual who:

paragraph.text: Is licensed to practice dietetics in another state or country;
Is registered to practice dietetics by the Commission on Dietetic Registration of the American Dietetic Association; or
Is certified by the Certification Board for Nutrition Specialists.

subsection.text: The Board may grant a waiver under this section only if the applicant:

paragraph.text: Pays the application fee set by the Board under § 5-206 of this title; and
Provides adequate evidence that the applicant:

subparagraph.text: Meets the qualifications otherwise required by this subtitle; and

sub-subparagraph.text: Became licensed in the other state or country after passing, in that state or country, an examination that the Board determines to be comparable to the examination for which the applicant is seeking the waiver;
Became registered by the Commission on Dietetic Registration of the American Dietetic Association after meeting the examination waiver requirements of that Commission or its predecessor; or
Became certified by the Certification Board for Nutrition Specialists after meeting the examination waiver requirements of that Certification Board or its predecessor.

subsection.text: If an applicant qualifies for a license under this subtitle, the Board shall send the applicant a notice that specifies that:

paragraph.text: The applicant has qualified for a license; and
On receipt of the license fee set by the Board, the Board will issue a license to the applicant.

subsection.text: On payment of the license fee, the Board shall issue a license to any applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle.
The Board shall include on each license that the Board issues:

paragraph.text: The full name of the licensee;
A serial number assigned by the Board to the licensee; and
The signature of the chairman of the Board, under seal of the Board.

section.text: A license authorizes the licensee to practice dietetics while the license is effective.

paragraph.text: Unless the license is renewed for an additional term as provided in this section, a license expires on the date set by the Board.
A license may not be renewed for a term longer than 2 years.

subsection.text: At least 1 month before the license expires, the Board shall send to the licensee, by first-class mail to the last known address of the licensee, a renewal notice that states:

paragraph.text: The date on which the current license expires;
The date by which the Board must receive the renewal application for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the license expires; and
The amount of the renewal fee.

subsection.text: Before the license expires, the licensee may renew it for an additional 2-year term, if the licensee:

paragraph.text: Otherwise is entitled to be licensed;
Pays to the Board a renewal fee set by the Board; and
Submits to the Board:

subparagraph.text: A renewal application on the form that the Board requires; and
Satisfactory evidence of compliance with the continuing education requirements for license renewal set by the Board under this section.

subsection.text: In addition to any other qualifications and requirements established by the Board, the Board shall establish continuing education requirements as a condition to the renewal of licenses under this section.
The Board shall renew the license of each licensee who meets the requirements of this section.

paragraph.text: The Board shall place a licensee on inactive status if the licensee:

subparagraph.text: Submits to the Board an application for inactive status on the form required by the Board; and
Pays to the Board the inactive status fee set by the Board.

paragraph.text: The Board shall reactivate the license of an individual placed on inactive status if the individual:

subparagraph.text: Satisfies the continuing education requirements established by the Board; and
Pays to the Board a reactivation fee set by the Board.

subsection.text: The Board, in accordance with its regulations, shall reinstate the license of an individual who failed to renew a license for any reason if the individual:

paragraph.text: Otherwise is entitled to be licensed;
Satisfies the continuing education requirements established by the Board;
Pays to the Board a reinstatement fee set by the Board; and
Applies to the Board for reinstatement of a license within 5 years after the expiration of the license.
The Board may not reinstate the license of an individual who fails to apply for reinstatement of the license within 5 years after the expiration of the license.

An individual who fails to apply for reinstatement of a license within 5 years after the expiration of the license may become licensed by meeting the requirements for obtaining an initial license under this title.

subsection.text: Each licensee shall produce a valid license when requested to do so by an existing or potential employer or client.
Each licensee shall give the Board written notice of any change of address within 30 days of any change of address.

Unless the Board agrees to accept the surrender of a license, a licensed dietitian-nutritionist may not surrender the license nor may the license lapse by operation of law while the licensee is under investigation or while charges are pending against the licensee.
The Board may set conditions on its agreement with the licensee under investigation or against whom charges are pending to accept surrender of the license.

section.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 5-312 of this subtitle, the Board, on the affirmative vote of a majority of its members then serving, may deny a license to any applicant, reprimand any licensee, or suspend or revoke a license if the applicant or licensee:

paragraph.text: Fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a license for the applicant or licensee or for another;
Fraudulently or deceptively uses a license;
Violates any provision of this title or any regulations adopted under this title;

Refuses, withholds from, denies, or discriminates against an individual with regard to the provision of professional service for which the licensee is licensed and qualified to render because the individual is HIV positive;
Commits fraud or deceit in the practice of dietetics;
Is convicted of or pleads nolo contendere to a felony or to a crime involving moral turpitude, whether or not any appeal or other proceeding is pending to have the conviction or plea set aside;
Obtains or attempts to obtain a fee through fraud or misrepresentation;
Employs any person to practice dietetics whose license or certificate to practice a health occupation under this article has been suspended;

Uses or promotes or causes the use of any misleading, deceiving, or untruthful advertising matter, or promotional literature, testimonial, guarantee, warranty, label, brand, insignia, or other representation;
Commits any act of unprofessional conduct, as defined by the rules and regulations of the Board, or violates the code of ethics adopted by the Board;
Provides professional services while:

subparagraph.text: Under the influence of alcohol; or
Using any narcotic or controlled dangerous substance, as defined in § 5-101 of the Criminal Law Article, or other drug that is in excess of therapeutic amounts or without valid medical indication;

paragraph.text: Is disciplined by a licensing or disciplinary authority of any other state or country or convicted or disciplined by a court of any other state or country for an act that would be grounds for disciplinary action under this section;
Practices dietetics with an unauthorized person or supervises or aids an unauthorized person in the practice of dietetics;

Fails to file or record any report or record as required by law in the practice of dietetics, impedes or obstructs the filing or recording of the report or record, or induces another to fail to file or record the report or record;
Submits a false statement to collect a fee;
Is professionally, physically, or mentally incompetent;
Promotes the sale of devices, appliances, or goods to a patient so as to exploit the patient for financial gain; or
Fails to cooperate with a lawful investigation conducted by the Board.

subsection.text: If after a hearing under § 5-312 of this subtitle the Board finds that there are grounds under § 5-311 of this subtitle to suspend or revoke a license, the Board may impose a penalty not exceeding $5,000:

paragraph.text: Instead of suspending the license; or
In addition to suspending or revoking the license or reprimanding the licensee.

subsection.text: The Board shall adopt regulations to set standards for the imposition of penalties under this section.
The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this section into the General Fund of the State.

Except as otherwise provided in § 10-226 of the State Government Article, before the Board takes any action under § 5-311 of this subtitle, it shall give the individual against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Board.
The Board shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.

Over the signature of an officer or the administrator of the Board, the Board may issue subpoenas and administer oaths in connection with any investigation under this title and any hearings or proceedings before it.

If, without lawful excuse, a person disobeys a subpoena from the Board, an order by the Board to take any oath or to testify, or answer a question, then, on petition of the Board, a court of competent jurisdiction may punish the person for contempt of court.
If after due notice the individual against whom the action is contemplated fails or refuses to appear, the Board may hear and determine the matter.
The hearing notice to be given to the individual shall be sent by certified mail to the last known address of the individual at least 14 days before the hearing.
The individual may be represented at the hearing by counsel.

Except as otherwise provided in this section for an action under § 5-311 of this subtitle, any person aggrieved by a final decision of the Board in a contested case, as defined in the Administrative Procedure Act, may:

paragraph.text: Appeal that decision to the Board of Review; and
Then take any further appeal allowed by the Administrative Procedure Act.
Any person aggrieved by a final decision of the Board under § 5-311 of this subtitle may not appeal to the Secretary or the Board of Review but may take a direct judicial appeal.
The appeal shall be made pursuant to the provisions on judicial review of final decisions in Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.

subsection.text: An order of the Board may not be stayed pending review.
In this section, “dietetic rehabilitation committee” means a committee that:

paragraph.text: Is defined in subsection (b) of this section; and
Performs any of the functions listed in subsection (d) of this section.

subsection.text: For purposes of this section, a dietetic rehabilitation committee is a committee of the Board or a committee of an association representing licensed dietitian-nutritionists that:

paragraph.text: Is recognized by the Board; and
Includes but is not limited to dietitian-nutritionists.

subsection.text: A rehabilitation committee of the Board or recognized by the Board may function:

paragraph.text: Solely for the Board; or
Jointly with a rehabilitation committee representing another board or boards.

subsection.text: For purposes of this section, a dietetic rehabilitation committee evaluates and provides assistance to any dietitian-nutritionist and any other individual regulated by the Board in need of treatment and rehabilitation for alcoholism, drug abuse, chemical dependency, or other physical, emotional, or mental condition.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, the proceedings, records, and files of the dietetic rehabilitation committee are not discoverable and are not admissible in evidence in any civil action arising out of matters that are being or have been reviewed and evaluated by the dietetic rehabilitation committee.

Paragraph (1) of this subsection does not apply to any record or document that is considered by the dietetic rehabilitation committee and that otherwise would be subject to discovery or introduction into evidence in a civil action.
For purposes of this subsection, civil action does not include a proceeding before the Board or judicial review of a proceeding before the Board.

subsection.text: A person who acts in good faith and within the scope of jurisdiction of a dietetic rehabilitation committee is not civilly liable for any action as a member of the dietetic rehabilitation committee or for giving information to, participating in, or contributing to the function of the dietetic rehabilitation committee.

section.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, a person may not practice, attempt to practice, or offer to practice dietetics in the State unless licensed by the Board.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided under this title, a person may not represent or imply to the public by use of the title “licensed dietitian-nutritionist”, by other title, by description of services, methods, or procedures that the person is authorized to practice dietetics in the State.

Unless authorized to practice dietetics under this title, a person may not use the words or terms “dietitian-nutritionist”, “licensed dietitian-nutritionist”, “LDN”, “dietitian”, “licensed dietitian”, “D”, “LD”, “nutritionist”, “licensed nutritionist”, or “LN”.

section.text: A person who violates § 5-401 or § 5-402 of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.
This title may be cited as the “Maryland Licensed Dietitian-Nutritionists Act”.

Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act, this title and all regulations adopted under this title shall terminate and be of no effect after July 1, 2015.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.

“Apprentice” means an individual licensed by the Board who assists a licensed mortician or funeral director in the practice of mortuary science or funeral direction, under direct supervision of a licensed mortician or funeral director.
“Apprentice sponsor” means a person who:

paragraph.text: Is a licensed mortician or funeral director practicing mortuary science as a licensed mortician or funeral director in Maryland at least 1 year immediately prior to accepting the applicant as an apprentice; and
Provides direct supervision to an apprentice.

subsection.text: “Board” means the Maryland State Board of Morticians and Funeral Directors.

paragraph.text: “Business of operating a crematory” means controlling or managing a crematory.
“Business of operating a crematory” does not include:

subparagraph.text: The practice of funeral direction or the practice of mortuary science; or

sub-subparagraph.text: Assistance in making decisions and filling out forms that are not directly related to cremation;
Obtaining vital statistics, signatures, and other information necessary to complete a death certificate;
Transportation of a body to the place of disposition; or
Any other services regarding the disposition of a body that are not directly related to cremation.

paragraph.text: “Corporation” means a mortuary science business whose articles of incorporation are in good standing with the Maryland State Department of Assessments and Taxation, or its successor, the initial business for which the license is issued must have been incorporated on or before June 1, 1945 and have “Incorporated”, “Inc.”, or “Corporation” in its name.
“Corporation” does not include, for purposes of issuing a corporation license, a “professional association” (P.A.) or a “professional corporation” (P.C.).

subsection.text: “Courtesy card” means a license issued by the Board to licensed practitioners of mortuary science in other states, to make a removal of a dead human body in this State and to return the body to another state or country, to return dead bodies from another state or country to this State, to fill out the family history portion of the death certificate, and to sign the death certificate in the holder’s capacity as a licensed practitioner of mortuary science.
“Cremation” means the process of reducing human remains to bone fragments through intense heat and evaporation, including any mechanical or thermal process.
“Crematory” means a building, portion of a building, or structure that houses the necessary appliances and facilities for cremation.
“Funeral director” means an individual who is licensed by the Board to practice all aspects of mortuary science except for embalming.
“Funeral establishment” means any building, structure, or premises from which the business of practicing mortuary science is conducted.

paragraph.text: “Human remains” means:

subparagraph.text: The body of a deceased person; or
A part of a body or limb that has been removed from a living person.

paragraph.text: “Human remains” includes the body or part of a body or limb in any state of decomposition.
“License” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a license issued by the Board.
“License” includes, unless otherwise indicated:

subparagraph.text: A mortician license;
An apprentice license;
A funeral director license;
A surviving spouse license;
A corporation license;
A funeral establishment license; and
A courtesy card.

subsection.text: “Licensed apprentice” means, unless the context requires otherwise, an apprentice who is licensed by the Board to assist a licensed mortician or funeral director in the practice of mortuary science or funeral direction.
“Licensed funeral director” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a funeral director who is licensed by the Board to practice funeral direction.
“Licensed funeral establishment” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a funeral establishment that is licensed by the Board.
“Licensed mortician” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a mortician who is licensed by the Board under this title to practice mortuary science.
“Licensee” means an individual or entity licensed by the Board to practice mortuary science to the extent determined by the Board.
“Mortician” means an individual who practices mortuary science.

paragraph.text: “Practice funeral direction” means:

subparagraph.text: To operate a funeral establishment;
For compensation, to prepare a dead human body for disposition; or
For compensation, to arrange for or make final disposition of a dead human body.

paragraph.text: “Practice funeral direction” does not include:

subparagraph.text: For compensation, disinfecting or preserving a dead human body or any of its parts by arterial or cavity injection or any other type of preservation; or
The business of operating a crematory.

paragraph.text: “Practice mortuary science” means:

subparagraph.text: To operate a funeral establishment;
For compensation, to prepare a dead human body for disposition; or
For compensation, to arrange for or make final disposition of a dead human body.

paragraph.text: “Practice mortuary science” includes:

subparagraph.text: The practice of funeral direction; and
Disinfecting or preserving a dead human body or any of its parts by arterial or cavity injection.

paragraph.text: “Practice mortuary science” does not include:

subparagraph.text: The pickup, removal, or transportation of a dead human body, if the unlicensed individual is acting under the direction of a licensed mortician or funeral director; or
The business of operating a crematory.

subsection.text: “Pre–need contract” means an agreement between a consumer and a licensed funeral director, licensed mortician, or surviving spouse to provide any goods and services purchased prior to the time of death. Goods and services shall include:

paragraph.text: A service, including any form of preservation and disposition or cremation, that a mortician normally provides in the ordinary course of business; or
Merchandise, including a casket, vault, or clothing, that a mortician normally provides in the ordinary course of business.

subsection.text: “Surviving spouse” means the legal widow or widower of a licensed funeral director or licensed mortician, whose license was in good standing at the time of death, and who at the time of death, wholly or partly owned and operated a mortuary science business.
This title does not limit the right of an individual to practice a health occupation that the individual is authorized to practice under this article.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “registrant or permit holder” means a person regulated under Title 5 of the Business Regulation Article as a registered cemeterian, registered seller, or holder of a permit to operate a cemetery or burial goods business.
This title does not apply to:

subparagraph.text: The business of operating a cemetery, including the sale of cemetery lots, grave sites, mausoleums, monuments, lawn crypts, or vaults;
The ownership of a crematory or the business of operating a crematory in which:

sub-subparagraph.text: A registrant or permit holder owns a greater percentage of the crematory than a person licensed under this title;
Ownership is equal between a registrant or permit holder and a person licensed under this title; or
Neither a registrant, permit holder, or person licensed under this title has an ownership interest in the crematory; or

subparagraph.text: The ownership of a crematory or the business of operating a crematory or incinerator at a licensed medical facility or educational institution.

section.text: The purpose of this title is to protect the health and welfare of the public.
There is a State Board of Morticians and Funeral Directors in the Department.

paragraph.text: The Board consists of 11 members.
Of the 11 Board members:

subparagraph.text: 6 shall be licensed morticians or licensed funeral directors; and
5 shall be consumer members.

paragraph.text: All Board members shall be residents of the State.
The Governor shall appoint each member with the advice of the Secretary, and with the advice and consent of the Senate.

The Board may not have more than one member who is employed by or affiliated with, directly or indirectly, the same corporation, professional association, or other entity, that owns, directly or through a subsidiary corporation, professional association, or other entity, one or more funeral homes.
Each mortician member shall:

subparagraph.text: Be a licensed mortician whose license is in good standing with the Board; and
Have practiced mortuary science actively for at least 5 years immediately before appointment.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “good standing” means that the Board has not reprimanded the licensee, suspended, or revoked the mortician’s license or placed the licensee on probation within 5 years’ time prior to or after confirmation to the Board.
To qualify for appointment to the Board, the licensee must meet all other qualifications required for renewal of a mortician license under this title.
Each funeral director member shall:

subparagraph.text: Be a licensed funeral director whose license is in good standing with the Board; and
Have practiced funeral direction actively for at least 5 years immediately before appointment.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “good standing” means that the Board has not reprimanded the licensee, suspended, or revoked the funeral director’s license or placed the licensee on probation within 5 years’ time prior to or after confirmation to the Board.
To qualify for appointment to the Board, the licensee must meet all other qualifications required for renewal of a funeral director license under this title.

subsection.text: Each consumer member of the Board:

paragraph.text: Shall be a member of the general public;
May not be or ever have been a mortician, funeral director, or apprentice;
May not have a household member who is a mortician, funeral director, or apprentice;
May not participate or ever have participated in a commercial or professional field related to the practice of mortuary science;
May not have a household member who participates in a commercial or professional field related to the practice of mortuary science; and
May not have had within 2 years before appointment a substantial financial interest in a person regulated by the Board.

subsection.text: While a member of the Board, a consumer member may not have a substantial financial interest in a person regulated by the Board.
Before taking office, each member of the Board shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The term of an appointed member is 4 years, except that the initial term of 1 of the consumer members is 3 years.
The terms of appointed members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on July 1, 1981.
At the end of a term, an appointed member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
To the extent practicable, the Governor shall fill any vacancy on the Board occurring during the term of an appointed member within 60 days of the date of the vacancy.
A member may not serve more than 2 consecutive full terms.
The Governor may remove an appointed member:

subparagraph.text: For incompetence or misconduct; or
Who, because of events that occur after the member’s appointment or reappointment to the Board, causes the Board to be in violation of the prohibition set forth in subsection (a)(5) of this section.

paragraph.text: Upon the recommendation of the Secretary, the Governor may remove an appointed member whom the Secretary finds to have been absent from 2 successive Board meetings without adequate reason.

subsection.text: From among its members, the Board shall elect a president, a first vice president, and a second vice president.
The Board shall determine:

paragraph.text: The manner of election of officers;
The term of office of each officer; and
The duties of each officer.

subsection.text: A majority of the full authorized membership of the Board is a quorum to do business.

paragraph.text: The Board shall meet at least once a year, at the times and places that it sets in its bylaws and rules and regulations.
The Board shall hold special meetings that:

subparagraph.text: It considers necessary; or
The Secretary directs.

subsection.text: Each appointed member of the Board is entitled to:

paragraph.text: Compensation in accordance with the budget of the Board for each meeting that the member attends; and
Reimbursement for expenses at a rate determined by the Board.
The Board may appoint a Board secretary, who may be a member of the Board.
The Board may employ inspectors and other staff in accordance with the budget of the Board.

subsection.text: In addition to the powers and duties set forth elsewhere in this title, the Board has the following powers and duties:

paragraph.text: To adopt bylaws, rules, and regulations to carry out the provisions of this title;
To adopt a seal;
To establish procedures for licensing apprentices;
To keep a list of all individuals currently licensed by the Board;
To investigate any alleged violation of this title;
To enforce this title;
To adopt rules and regulations regarding false and misleading advertising and misrepresentation;
To inspect licensed funeral establishments;

On receipt of a written and signed complaint, including a referral from the Commissioner of Labor and Industry, to conduct an unannounced inspection of the funeral establishment to determine compliance at that funeral establishment with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s guidelines on universal precautions;
To establish standards for the practice of mortuary science; and
To establish standards for sanitation and waste disposal in connection with the practice of mortuary science.

subsection.text: The Board may conduct an audit of a licensee that:

paragraph.text: Receives pre-need funds;
Places pre-need funds in a trust; or
Enters into a pre-need contract.

subsection.text: In conjunction with the Office of Cemetery Oversight, the Board shall:

paragraph.text: Establish a process for regulating crematories that provides for:

subparagraph.text: Registration or licensure and renewal;
Applications, including certification of ownership and identification of individuals who will perform cremation;
Registration or licensure fees;
Inspections and oversight;
Grounds for discipline and penalties; and
Complaints and hearings; and

paragraph.text: Adopt regulations that are identical to regulations adopted by the Director of the Office of Cemetery Oversight to:

subparagraph.text: Implement item (1) of this subsection; and
Ensure public health and safety.

subsection.text: There is a State Board of Morticians and Funeral Directors Fund.

paragraph.text: The Board may set reasonable fees for its services.
The fees charged shall be set so as to approximate the cost of maintaining the Board.
Funds to cover the compensation and expenses of the Board members shall be generated by fees set under this section.
The Board shall pay all funds collected under this title to the Comptroller of the State.
The Comptroller shall distribute the fees to the State Board of Morticians and Funeral Directors Fund.
The Fund shall be used to cover the actual documented direct and indirect costs of fulfilling the statutory and regulatory duties of the Board as provided by the provisions of this article.
The Fund is a continuing, nonlapsing fund, not subject to § 7-302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
Any unspent portions of the Fund may not be transferred or revert to the General Fund of the State, but shall remain in the Fund to be used for the purposes specified in this article.
No other State money may be used to support the Fund.
A designee of the Board shall administer the Fund.
Moneys in the Fund may be expended only for any lawful purpose authorized under the provisions of this article.

subsection.text: The Legislative Auditor shall audit the accounts and transactions of the Fund as provided in § 2-1220 of the State Government Article.

section.text: A person shall have the immunity from liability described under § 5-707 of the Courts and Judicial Proceedings Article for giving information to the Board or otherwise participating in its activities.

subsection.text: The Board may require an applicant or licensee to submit to a mental or physical examination by a health care practitioner designated by the Board, if:

paragraph.text: When investigating an allegation brought against an applicant or licensee under this title, the Board finds reasonable evidence indicating that the applicant or licensee cannot practice mortuary science or funeral direction competently;
The Board:

subparagraph.text: Makes a written request for the applicant or licensee to submit to the examination;
Provides the applicant or licensee with a list of three health care practitioners from which the applicant may choose a health care practitioner to conduct the examination; and
Pays the cost of the examination in accordance with subsection (c) of this section; and

paragraph.text: The applicant or licensee:

subparagraph.text: Consents to submit to the examination; and
Waives any claim or privilege as to the examination report.

subsection.text: An evaluation report of a health care practitioner designated by the Board is confidential except as to contested case proceedings as defined by the Administrative Procedure Act.

subparagraph.text: Subject to subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, an applicant who does not hold a valid license with the Board shall pay the reasonable cost of any examination made under this section.

If the applicant is deemed competent to practice mortuary science or funeral direction as a result of the evaluation, the Board shall reimburse the applicant for the reasonable cost of the evaluation that was performed.

paragraph.text: The Board shall pay the reasonable cost of an examination made under this section for a licensee of the Board.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, an individual shall be licensed by the Board before the individual may practice mortuary science in this State.
This section does not:

paragraph.text: Limit the right of a school of medicine or dentistry to use and dispose of a dead human body or its parts;
Limit the right of any person who is authorized by law to handle or dispose of a dead human body or its parts, if the person acts within the scope of that authorization;
Affect the right of an authorized officer or employee of the United States or the District of Columbia to practice mortuary science in the course of that individual’s duties;
