“Health maintenance organization” has the meaning stated in § 19–701(g) of the Health – General Article.

paragraph.text: “Institutional facility” means a facility other than a nursing home whose primary purpose is to provide a physical environment for patients to obtain inpatient or emergency care.
“Institutional facility” does not include an urgent care facility that is not part of a facility.

subsection.text: “Licensed physician” means an individual who is licensed to practice medicine under Title 14 of this article.
“Physician–pharmacist agreement” means an agreement between a licensed physician and a licensed pharmacist that is disease–state specific and specifies the protocols that may be used.

“Protocol” means a course of treatment predetermined by the licensed physician and licensed pharmacist according to generally accepted medical practice for the proper completion of a particular therapeutic or diagnostic intervention.

paragraph.text: “Therapy management contract” means a voluntary, written arrangement that is disease–state specific signed by each party to the arrangement between:

subparagraph.text: One licensed pharmacist and the licensed pharmacist’s designated alternate licensed pharmacists;
One licensed physician and alternate designated licensed physicians involved directly in patient care; and
One patient receiving care from a licensed physician and a licensed pharmacist pursuant to a physician–pharmacist agreement and protocol under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: A therapy management contract shall be related to treatment using drug therapy, laboratory tests, or medical devices, under defined conditions or limitations for the purpose of improving patient outcomes.

section.text: A therapy management contract is not required for the management of patients in an institutional facility or in a group model health maintenance organization.

subsection.text: A licensed physician and a licensed pharmacist who wish to enter into therapy management contracts shall have a physician–pharmacist agreement.

paragraph.text: A licensed physician who has entered into a physician–pharmacist agreement shall submit to the Board of Physicians a copy of the physician–pharmacist agreement and any subsequent modifications made to the physician–pharmacist agreement or the protocols specified in the physician–pharmacist agreement.

A licensed pharmacist who has entered into a physician–pharmacist agreement shall submit to the Board of Pharmacy a copy of the physician–pharmacist agreement and any subsequent modifications made to the physician–pharmacist agreement or the protocols specified in the physician–pharmacist agreement.

section.text: A pharmacist is authorized to enter into a physician–pharmacist agreement if the pharmacist:

paragraph.text: Is a licensed pharmacist;
Has a Doctor of Pharmacy Degree or equivalent training as established in regulations adopted under this subtitle;
Is approved by the Board to enter into a physician–pharmacist agreement with a licensed physician in accordance with this subtitle; and
Meets the requirements that are established by regulations adopted under this subtitle.

subsection.text: Subject to the regulations adopted under this subtitle, a licensed pharmacist may enter into a therapy management contract initiated by a licensed physician.
A licensed pharmacist may not employ or provide economic incentives to a licensed physician for the purpose of entering into a physician–pharmacist agreement or a therapy management contract.
A protocol under this subtitle:

paragraph.text: May authorize:

subparagraph.text: The modification, continuation, and discontinuation of drug therapy under written, disease–state specific protocols;
The ordering of laboratory tests; and
Other patient care management measures related to monitoring or improving the outcomes of drug or device therapy; and

paragraph.text: May not authorize acts that exceed the scope of practice of the parties to the therapy management contract.

subsection.text: A protocol shall prohibit the substitution of a chemically dissimilar drug product by the pharmacist for the product prescribed by the physician, unless permitted in the therapy management contract.

A therapy management contract shall apply only to conditions for which protocols have been agreed to by a licensed physician and a licensed pharmacist in accordance with the regulations adopted under this subtitle.
A therapy management contract shall terminate 1 year from the date of its signing, unless renewed by the licensed physician, licensed pharmacist, and patient.
A therapy management contract shall include:

paragraph.text: A statement that none of the parties involved in the therapy management contract have been coerced, given economic incentives, excluding normal reimbursement for services rendered, or involuntarily required to participate;
Notice to the patient indicating how the patient may terminate the therapy management contract;
A procedure for periodic review by the physician, of the drugs modified pursuant to the agreement or changed with the consent of the physician; and
Reference to a protocol, which will be provided to the patient upon request.

subsection.text: Any party to the therapy management contract may terminate the contract at any time.
The Board of Pharmacy may assess a fee, as established in regulation, for approval of a pharmacist to enter into a physician–pharmacist agreement.
The physician shall maintain complete patient records with respect to the therapy management contract.
The licensed physician’s patient record shall be fully updated in writing by the licensed pharmacist in a timely manner, as provided in the physician–pharmacist agreement.

section.text: Nothing in this subtitle supersedes the provisions of § 5–902 of the Criminal Law Article.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section, the Board of Pharmacy, together with the Board of Physicians, shall jointly develop and adopt regulations to implement the provisions of this subtitle.
The regulations adopted under subsection (a) of this section:

paragraph.text: Shall include provisions that:

subparagraph.text: Define the criteria for physician–pharmacist agreements; and
Establish guidelines concerning the use of protocols, including communication, documentation, and other relevant factors; and

paragraph.text: May not require the Board of Physicians or the Board of Pharmacy to approve a physician–pharmacist agreement or the protocols specified in a physician–pharmacist agreement.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, on or after January 1, 2007, an individual shall be registered and approved by the Board as a pharmacy technician before the individual may perform delegated pharmacy acts.
This section does not apply to:

paragraph.text: A pharmacy student performing delegated pharmacy acts under the direct supervision of a licensed pharmacist and in accordance with regulations adopted by the Board;
A pharmacy technician trainee under the direct supervision of a licensed pharmacist provided that the individual does not perform delegated pharmacy acts for more than 6 months; or
An applicant for a license to practice pharmacy under the direct supervision of a licensed pharmacist provided that the applicant does not perform delegated pharmacy acts for more than 10 months.

subsection.text: To qualify for registration an applicant shall be an individual who:

paragraph.text: Is currently certified by a national pharmacy technician certification program and complies with subsection (b)(6) of this section; or
Meets the requirements of this section.

subsection.text: The applicant shall:

paragraph.text: Be of good moral character;
Be at least 17 years old;

sub-subparagraph.text: Be a high school graduate or have attained a high school equivalency; or
Be enrolled and in good standing at a high school; or

subparagraph.text: Meet the requirements in subsection (d) of this section;

paragraph.text: Have successfully passed an examination approved by the Board;
Complete a pharmacy technician training program approved by the Board that:

subparagraph.text: Includes 160 hours of work experience; and
Is no longer than 6 months’ duration; and

paragraph.text: Submit a request for a State criminal history records check.

subsection.text: The Board may not approve an application until the State criminal history records check is completed.
If an applicant does not meet the requirements of subsection (b)(3) through (5) of this section, the applicant qualifies for registration if:

paragraph.text: The applicant has worked in the pharmacy area of a pharmacy operated by the same pharmacy permit holder since January 1, 2006;

The pharmacy permit holder for whom the applicant works attests in writing that the applicant has worked in the pharmacy area operated by the pharmacy permit holder continuously since January 1, 2006;
A pharmacist who has supervised the applicant for at least 6 months attests in writing that the individual has performed competently; and
The applicant otherwise meets the requirements of subsection (b) of this section.

subsection.text: An individual, at least 16 years and 6 months old, may begin fulfilling the pharmacy technician registration requirements under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: Subject to the provisions of this subsection, the Board may waive any requirement of this subtitle for an individual who is registered as or has worked as a pharmacy technician in another state.
The Board may grant a waiver under this subsection only if the applicant:

subparagraph.text: Pays the application fee required under § 12-6B-03 of this subtitle; and

sub-subparagraph.text: Provides sufficient evidence that the applicant was registered in a state with registration or licensing requirements that are substantially similar to the registration requirements of this subtitle; or
Has worked as a pharmacy technician in another state and satisfies any additional requirements established by the Board in regulation.

subsection.text: An applicant for registration shall:

paragraph.text: Submit an application to the Board on the form that the Board requires;
Unless otherwise qualified under § 12-6B-02(a) or (d) of this subtitle, provide documentation of the completion of a pharmacy technician training program under § 12-6B-02(b)(5) of this subtitle;
Unless otherwise qualified under § 12-6B-02(a) or (d) of this subtitle, provide documentation of having successfully completed an examination approved by the Board;
Submit to a request for a State criminal history records check; and
Pay the application fees set by the Board.

subsection.text: The application shall be signed by the applicant.
The Board shall register as a pharmacy technician any applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The Board may set reasonable fees for the issuance and renewal of registrations and other services.
The fees charged shall be set so as to approximate the cost of registering pharmacy technicians.

subsection.text: A registered pharmacy technician shall notify the Board of each plea of guilty for, conviction of, or entry of a plea of nolo contendere for a felony or a crime involving moral turpitude, regardless of whether:

paragraph.text: An adjudication of guilt or sentencing or imposition of sentence is withheld; or
Any appeal or other proceeding is pending regarding the matter.

subsection.text: The registered pharmacy technician shall notify the Board within 7 days of the conviction or entry of the plea.
Registration authorizes a registered pharmacist technician to perform delegated pharmacy acts as defined in § 12–101 of this title while the registration is effective.
A registered pharmacy technician or a pharmacy technician trainee may not:

paragraph.text: Act within the parameters of a therapy management contract as provided under Subtitle 6A of this title;
Administer an influenza vaccination in accordance with § 12–508 of this title;
Delegate a pharmacy act that was delegated to the registered pharmacy technician or individual engaging in a Board approved technician training program; or
Perform other functions prohibited by regulations adopted by the Board.
Unless the registration is renewed for an additional term as provided in this section, registration expires on the date set by the Board.
The ability of a registered pharmacy technician to function as a pharmacy technician terminates on the date of expiration of the pharmacy technician’s registration unless renewed.
Registration may not be renewed for a term longer than 2 years.

Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Board shall send to each registered pharmacy technician, at least 1 month before a registration expires, a renewal notice by first–class mail to the last known address of the registered pharmacy technician.

If requested by a registered pharmacy technician, the Board shall send to the registered pharmacy technician, at least two times within the month before a pharmacy technician registration expires, a renewal notice by electronic means to the last known electronic address of the registered pharmacy technician.

If a renewal notice sent by electronic means under paragraph (2) of this subsection is returned to the Board as undeliverable, the Board shall send the registered pharmacy technician a renewal notice by first–class mail to the last known address of the registered pharmacy technician.
A renewal notice sent under this subsection shall state:

subparagraph.text: The date on which the current registration expires;
The date by which the renewal application must be received by the Board for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the registration expires; and
The amount of the renewal fee.

subsection.text: A registered pharmacy technician periodically may renew a pharmacy technician’s registration for an additional 2-year term, if the registered pharmacy technician:

paragraph.text: Otherwise is entitled to be registered as a pharmacy technician;
Submits to the Board a renewal application on the form that the Board requires;
Meets the continuing education requirements set by the Board under this section; and
Pays to the Board a renewal fee set by the Board.

subsection.text: In addition to any other qualifications and requirements established by the Board, the Board shall establish continuing education requirements as a condition to the renewal of registrations under this section.
The Board shall renew the registration of each pharmacy technician who meets the requirements of this section.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the registration of a pharmacy technician who qualified for registration under § 12-6B-02(d) of this subtitle permanently expires on the date the registered pharmacy technician’s employment terminates with the pharmacy permit holder that made the attestation required under § 12-6B-02(d) of this subtitle.
Paragraph (1) of this subsection does not apply to the registration of a pharmacy technician who:

subparagraph.text: At the time of termination, notifies the Board of the termination date;
Resumes working as a pharmacy technician within 1 year of the termination date; and
Notifies the Board of the date the registered pharmacy technician begins employment after the termination date.

subsection.text: Each registered pharmacy technician shall:

paragraph.text: Display the pharmacy technician’s registration in the office or place of business in which the pharmacy technician is working; or
Have the registration on the pharmacy technician’s person available for viewing.

subsection.text: When performing delegated pharmacy acts, the registered pharmacy technician shall wear identification that conspicuously identifies the registered pharmacy technician as a registered pharmacy technician.

section.text: Subject to the hearing provision of § 12-315 of this title, the Board may deny a pharmacy technician’s registration to any applicant, reprimand a registered pharmacy technician, place any pharmacy technician’s registration on probation, or suspend or revoke a pharmacy technician’s registration if the applicant or pharmacy technician registrant:

paragraph.text: Performs an act that is restricted to a licensed pharmacist;

Fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a pharmacy technician’s registration for the applicant or assists or attempts to assist another in fraudulently or deceptively obtaining a pharmacy technician’s registration;
Fraudulently uses a pharmacy technician’s registration;
Knowingly aids an unauthorized individual to practice pharmacy or to represent that the individual is a licensed pharmacist or registered pharmacy technician;
Performs delegated pharmacy acts while:

subparagraph.text: Under the influence of alcohol; or
Using any narcotic or controlled dangerous substance, as defined in § 5-101 of the Criminal Law Article, or other drug that is in excess of therapeutic amounts or without valid medical indication;

paragraph.text: Submits a false statement to collect a fee;
Willfully makes or files a false report or record as part of the registered pharmacy technician’s duties or employment;
Willfully fails to file or record any report that is required by law;
Willfully impedes or obstructs the filing or recording of any report that is required by law;
Willfully induces another to fail to file or record any report that is required by law;
Provides or causes to be provided to any authorized prescriber prescription forms that bear the name, address, or other means of identification of a pharmacist or pharmacy;

Provides remuneration to an authorized prescriber for referring an individual to a licensed pharmacist, registered pharmacy technician, or pharmacy for a product or service to be provided by that licensed pharmacist, registered pharmacy technician, or pharmacy;
Agrees with an authorized prescriber or pharmacist to prepare or dispense a secret formula prescription;

Except as to an association that has remained in continuous existence since July 1, 1963, associates as a partner, co-owner, or employee of a pharmacy that is owned wholly or substantially by an authorized prescriber or group of authorized prescribers;

Knowingly aids a pharmacist in dispensing any drug, device, or diagnostic for which a prescription is required without a written, oral, or electronically transmitted prescription from an authorized prescriber;
Unless an authorized prescriber authorizes the refill, refills a prescription for any drug, device, or diagnostic for which a prescription is required;
Violates any labeling requirements in this title;
Violates any provision of § 12-603 of this title, which concerns the home dialysis distribution program;
Advertises or otherwise publicly claims to dispense prescriptions in a superior manner;
Advertises in a manner that tends to deceive or defraud the public;
Is physically or mentally incompetent;
Pleaded guilty or nolo contendere to, or has been found guilty of, a felony or a crime involving moral turpitude, regardless of whether:

subparagraph.text: An adjudication of guilt or sentencing or imposition of sentence is withheld; or
Any appeal or other proceeding is pending regarding the matter;

paragraph.text: Violates any provision of this title;

Is disciplined by a licensing, registering, or disciplinary authority of any state or country or convicted or disciplined by a court of any state or country for an act that would be grounds for disciplinary action under the Board’s disciplinary statutes;
Violates any regulation adopted by the Board;

Refuses, withholds from, denies, or discriminates against an individual with regard to the provision of professional services for which the registered pharmacy technician is registered and qualified to render because the individual is HIV positive;
Participates in any activity that is grounds for Board action under § 12-313 or § 12-409 of this title;

Provides or causes to be provided confidential patient information to any person without first having obtained the patient’s consent, as required by § 12-403(b)(13) of this title and by Title 4, Subtitle 3 of the Health - General Article;
Fails to cooperate with a lawful investigation conducted by the Board or the Division of Drug Control;
Performs delegated pharmacy acts in an incompetent manner; or
Performs delegated pharmacy acts that are inappropriate based on the registered pharmacy technician’s education, training, and experience.

subsection.text: If after a hearing under § 12-315 of this title, the Board finds that there is a ground under § 12-6B-09 of this subtitle to reprimand a registered pharmacy technician, place a pharmacy technician’s registration on probation, or suspend or revoke a pharmacy technician’s registration, the Board may impose a penalty not exceeding $2,500:

paragraph.text: Instead of reprimanding the registered pharmacy technician, placing the registered pharmacy technician on probation, or suspending or revoking the pharmacy technician’s registration; or
In addition to reprimanding the registered pharmacy technician, placing the registered pharmacy technician on probation, or suspending or revoking the pharmacy technician’s registration.

subsection.text: The Board shall adopt regulations to set standards for the imposition of penalties under this section.
The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this section into the General Fund of this State.

Unless the Board agrees to accept the surrender of a pharmacy technician’s registration, a registered pharmacy technician may not surrender the pharmacy technician’s registration nor may the pharmacy technician’s registration lapse by operation of law while the registered pharmacy technician is under investigation or while charges are pending against the registered pharmacy technician.

The Board may set conditions on its agreement with the registered pharmacy technician under investigation or against whom charges are pending to accept the surrender of the pharmacy technician’s registration.

section.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, an individual may not work, attempt to work, or offer to work as a registered pharmacy technician in this State unless registered with the Board.

subsection.text: An individual may not obtain a pharmacy technician’s registration by making a false representation.
On conviction of an individual for making a false representation to the Board in order to register as a pharmacy technician, the pharmacy technician’s registration is void.

Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, an individual may not represent to the public by title, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the individual is registered to work as a registered pharmacy technician unless registered in accordance with this subtitle.

Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, an individual may not use the terms “registered pharmacy technician” or “pharmacy technician” with the intent to represent that the individual is authorized to work as a registered pharmacy technician unless registered as a pharmacy technician under this subtitle.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Authenticate” means to affirmatively verify, before any wholesale distribution of a prescription drug occurs, that each transaction listed on the pedigree for the prescription drug has occurred.
“Authorized distributor of record” means a wholesale distributor with whom a manufacturer has established an ongoing relationship to distribute the manufacturer’s prescription drug.

“Co–licensed partner” means a person in a relationship in which two or more persons have the right to engage in the manufacturing or marketing of a prescription drug, consistent with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration’s implementation of the federal Prescription Drug Marketing Act.
“Co–licensed product” means a product of co–licensed partners.
“Designated representative” means an individual who:

paragraph.text: Is designated by a wholesale distributor;
Serves as the primary contact of the wholesale distributor with the Board; and
Is actively involved in and aware of the daily operation of the wholesale distributor.

subsection.text: “Drop shipment” means the sale of a prescription drug:

paragraph.text: To a wholesale distributor by:

subparagraph.text: The manufacturer of the prescription drug; or
The manufacturer’s co–licensed partner, third party logistics provider, or manufacturer’s exclusive distributor; and

paragraph.text: Through which:

subparagraph.text: The wholesale distributor or a pharmacy warehouse takes title to but not physical possession of the prescription drug;
The wholesale distributor invoices the pharmacy, pharmacy warehouse, or other person authorized by law to dispense or administer the prescription drug to a patient; and
The pharmacy, pharmacy warehouse, or other authorized person receives delivery of the prescription drug directly from:

sub-subparagraph.text: The manufacturer; or
The manufacturer’s third party logistics provider or the manufacturer’s exclusive distributor.

subsection.text: “Facility” means a facility of a wholesale distributor where prescription drugs are stored, handled, repackaged, or offered for sale.
“Intracompany sales” means a:

paragraph.text: Transaction or transfer of prescription drugs between a division, subsidiary, parent, or affiliated or related company under common ownership and control of a corporate entity; or
Transaction or transfer of a co–licensed product between co–licensed partners.

subsection.text: “Manufacturer” means a person licensed or approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration to engage in the manufacture of prescription drugs or prescription devices, consistent with the definition of “manufacturer” under the U.S. Food and Drug Administration’s regulations and guidelines implementing the Prescription Drug Marketing Act.
“Manufacturer’s exclusive distributor” means a person who:

paragraph.text: Contracts with a manufacturer to provide or coordinate warehousing, distribution, or other services on behalf of the manufacturer; and
Takes title to the manufacturer’s prescription drug, but does not have general responsibility to direct the sale or disposition of the manufacturer’s prescription drug.

subsection.text: “Normal distribution channel” means a chain of custody for a prescription drug that, directly or by drop shipment, goes:

paragraph.text: From:

subparagraph.text: A manufacturer of the prescription drug; or
The manufacturer’s co–licensed partner, third party logistics provider, or manufacturer’s exclusive distributor; and

paragraph.text: To:

subparagraph.text: A pharmacy or other designated person authorized by law to dispense or administer the prescription drug to a patient;
A wholesale distributor to a pharmacy or other designated person authorized by law to dispense or administer the prescription drug to a patient;

A wholesale distributor to a pharmacy warehouse to the pharmacy warehouse’s intracompany pharmacy or other designated person authorized by law to dispense or administer the prescription drug to a patient;
A pharmacy warehouse to the pharmacy warehouse’s intracompany pharmacy or other designated person authorized by law to dispense or administer the prescription drug to a patient; or

An authorized distributor of record to another authorized distributor of record solely for distribution to an office–based health care practitioner authorized by law to dispense or administer the prescription drug to a patient.

subsection.text: “Ongoing relationship” means a relationship that exists between a wholesale distributor, including any affiliated group of the wholesale distributor, as defined in § 1504 of the Internal Revenue Code, and a manufacturer when the wholesale distributor:

paragraph.text: Has a written agreement currently in effect with the manufacturer evidencing the ongoing relationship; and
Is listed on the manufacturer’s current list of authorized distributors of record.

subsection.text: “Pedigree” means a document or electronic file containing information that records each wholesale distribution of a prescription drug.
“Pharmacy warehouse” means a physical location for storage of prescription drugs that:

paragraph.text: Serves as a central warehouse; and
Performs intracompany sales or transfers of the prescription drugs to a group of pharmacies that are under common ownership and control with the pharmacy warehouse.

subsection.text: “Prescription device” means any device required by federal law or regulation to be dispensed only by a prescription.

paragraph.text: “Prescription drug” means any drug required by federal law or regulation to be dispensed only by a prescription.
“Prescription drug” includes:

subparagraph.text: A biological product; and
Finished dosage forms and bulk drug substances subject to § 503(b) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act.

paragraph.text: “Prescription drug” does not include blood and blood components intended for transfusion or biological products that are also medical devices.
“Repackage” means to repackage or otherwise change the container, wrapper, or labeling of a prescription drug to further the distribution of the prescription drug.
“Repackage” does not include changes to a container, wrapper, or labeling of a prescription drug completed by the pharmacist responsible for dispensing the prescription drug to a patient.

subsection.text: “Repackager” means a person who repackages prescription drugs.
“Third party logistics provider” means a person who:

paragraph.text: Contracts with a manufacturer to provide or coordinate warehousing, distribution, or other services on behalf of the manufacturer; but
Does not take title to the prescription drug or have general responsibility to direct the prescription drug’s sale or disposition.
“Wholesale distribution” means the distribution of prescription drugs or prescription devices to persons other than a consumer or patient.
“Wholesale distribution” does not include:

subparagraph.text: Intracompany sales;
The sale, purchase, distribution, trade, or transfer of a prescription drug or an offer to sell, purchase, distribute, trade, or transfer a prescription drug for emergency medical reasons;
The sale, purchase, distribution, trade, or transfer of a prescription drug or prescription device by the Department for public health purposes;
The distribution of samples of a prescription drug by a manufacturer’s representative;
Prescription drug returns conducted by a hospital, health care entity, or charitable institution in accordance with 21 C.F.R. § 203.23;
The sale of minimal quantities of prescription drugs by retail pharmacies to licensed health care practitioners for office use;
The sale, purchase, or trade of a prescription drug, an offer to sell, purchase, or trade a prescription drug, or the dispensing of a prescription drug in accordance with a prescription;
The sale, transfer, merger, or consolidation of all or part of the business of a pharmacy to or with another pharmacy, whether accomplished as a purchase and sale of stock or business assets;
The sale, purchase, distribution, trade, or transfer of a prescription drug from one authorized distributor of record to one additional authorized distributor of record if:

sub-subparagraph.text: The manufacturer has stated in writing to the receiving authorized distributor of record that the manufacturer is unable to supply the prescription drug; and
The supplying authorized distributor of record states in writing that the prescription drug being supplied had until that time been exclusively in the normal distribution channel;

subparagraph.text: The delivery of, or offer to deliver, a prescription drug by a common carrier solely in the common carrier’s usual course of business of transporting prescription drugs, if the common carrier does not store, warehouse, or take legal ownership of the prescription drug; or
The sale or transfer from a retail pharmacy or pharmacy warehouse of expired, damaged, returned, or recalled prescription drugs to the original manufacturer or to a third party returns processor.

paragraph.text: “Wholesale distributor” means a person that is engaged in the wholesale distribution of prescription drugs or prescription devices.
“Wholesale distributor” includes:

subparagraph.text: A manufacturer;
A repackager;
An own–label distributor;
A private–label distributor;
A jobber;
A broker;
A warehouse, including a manufacturer’s or distributor’s warehouse;
A manufacturer’s exclusive distributor or an authorized distributor of record;
A drug wholesaler or distributor;
An independent wholesale drug trader;
A third party logistics provider;
A retail pharmacy that conducts wholesale distribution, if the wholesale distribution business accounts for more than 5% of the retail pharmacy’s annual sales; and
A pharmacy warehouse that conducts wholesale distribution.

subsection.text: “Wholesale distributor permit” means a permit issued by the Board under this subtitle to distribute prescription drugs or prescription devices into, out of, or within the State as a wholesale distributor.

section.text: This subtitle does not affect any person while distributing:

paragraph.text: Feed for livestock or poultry;
Fertilizers;
Fungicides;
Insecticide;
Land plaster;
Lime;
Seeds; or
Devices, drugs, or supplies of any kind for the treatment, care, or cure of farm animals.

subsection.text: A wholesale distributor shall hold a permit issued by the Board before the wholesale distributor engages in wholesale distribution in the State.

paragraph.text: A manufacturer engaged in wholesale distribution shall hold a wholesale distributor permit issued under this subtitle.
Notwithstanding paragraph (1) of this subsection, the information and qualification requirements for obtaining a permit under this subtitle, beyond that required by federal law, do not apply to:

subparagraph.text: A manufacturer that distributes its own prescription drugs that are approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration; or
A manufacturer that distributes its own prescription devices that are approved or authorized by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration.

subsection.text: A manufacturer’s exclusive distributor and a third–party logistics provider shall hold a wholesale distributor permit issued under this subtitle.
A wholesale distributor permit shall be displayed conspicuously in the place of business for which the permit is issued.
A wholesale distributor permit is not transferable.

Subject to any other restriction provided by law, a person may not purchase or obtain a prescription drug or prescription device unless the prescription drug or prescription device is purchased or obtained from a person who holds a wholesale distributor permit, a licensed pharmacist, or an authorized prescriber.
The Department may purchase and distribute prescription drugs and prescription devices for public health purposes.
The Department shall adopt regulations, in consultation with the Board, to implement this section.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Accreditation organization” means a private entity that:

subparagraph.text: Is recognized by the Board; and
Conducts inspections and surveys of wholesale distributors based on nationally recognized and developed standards.

paragraph.text: “Deemed status” means a status under which a wholesale distributor may be exempt from initial and routine inspection requirements under this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Board may only grant deemed status to a wholesale distributor that is:

paragraph.text: Currently accredited by an accreditation organization, wherever the wholesale distributor is located; or
Located in a state that has requirements that:

subparagraph.text: Are substantially equivalent to the requirements of this State; and
Include pedigrees, routine inspections of wholesale distributors, operation of wholesale distributors in a commercial nonresidential facility, and security measures.

paragraph.text: The Board may issue a wholesale distributor permit by reciprocity to a wholesale distributor who holds a license or permit under the laws of another state if the Board determines that the requirements of that state are substantially equivalent to the requirements of this State.
A wholesale distributor that receives a permit by reciprocity shall comply with the requirements of § 12–6C–05(e) and (f) of this subtitle.
In addition to meeting the requirements under this subtitle, a wholesale distributor located out–of–state that is not eligible for reciprocity shall be accredited by an accreditation organization.
The Board shall grant deemed status to a wholesale distributor that:

subparagraph.text: Is currently accredited by an accreditation organization; or
Has been granted reciprocity by the Board.

subsection.text: The Board or its designee may inspect a wholesale distributor who is accredited or has been issued a permit by reciprocity to:

paragraph.text: Determine compliance with any permit requirement under this subtitle; or
Investigate a complaint.

subsection.text: To apply for a wholesale distributor permit, an applicant shall:

paragraph.text: Pay to the Board an application fee set by the Board; and
Submit an application to the Board on the form that the Board requires.

subsection.text: The application shall include the following:

paragraph.text: The name, full business address, and telephone number of the applicant;
All trade or business names used by the applicant;
Addresses, telephone numbers, and the names of contact persons for the facility used by the applicant for the storage, handling, and distribution of prescription drugs;
The type of business form under which the applicant operates, such as partnership, corporation, or sole proprietorship;
The name of each owner and operator of the applicant, including:

subparagraph.text: If an individual, the name of the individual;
If a partnership, the name of the partnership and of each partner;
If a corporation, the name of the corporation, the name and title of each corporate officer and director, and the state of incorporation; and
If a sole proprietorship, the full name of the sole proprietor and the name of the sole proprietor’s business entity;

paragraph.text: A list of all licenses and permits issued to the applicant by any other state that authorizes the applicant to purchase or possess prescription drugs;
For the designated representative and the immediate supervisor of the designated representative at the applicant’s place of business, the following:

subparagraph.text: Name;
Places of residence for the past 7 years;
Date and place of birth;
The name and address of each business where the individual was employed during the past 7 years, and the individual’s job title or office held at each business;

A statement of whether, during the past 7 years, the individual has been the subject of any proceeding for the revocation of any professional or business license or any criminal violation and, if so, the nature and disposition of the proceeding;

A statement of whether, during the past 7 years, the individual has been enjoined, either temporarily or permanently, by a court of competent jurisdiction from violating any federal or state law regulating the possession, control, or distribution of prescription drugs, together with details concerning the event;

A description of any involvement, including any investments other than the ownership of stock in a publicly traded company or mutual fund, by the individual during the past 7 years with any business that manufactures, administers, prescribes, distributes, or stores prescription drugs, and any lawsuits in which the business was named as a party;

sub-subparagraph.text: A description of any misdemeanor or felony offense of which the individual, as an adult, was found guilty, regardless of whether adjudication of guilt was withheld or whether the individual pled guilty or nolo contendere; and

If the individual indicates that a criminal conviction is under appeal and submits a copy of the notice of appeal, within 15 days after the disposition of the appeal, a copy of the final written order of disposition; and

subparagraph.text: A photograph of the individual taken in the previous 180 days.

subsection.text: The information required under subsection (b) of this section shall be provided under oath.
The Board may not issue a wholesale distributor permit to an applicant unless the Board or its designee:

paragraph.text: If the applicant holds prescription drugs or devices, conducts a physical inspection of the applicant’s place of business, including any facility of the applicant;
Finds that the place of business and facility, if any, meets the Board’s requirements;
Determines that the designated representative of the applicant meets the following qualifications:

subparagraph.text: Is at least 21 years of age;

Has been employed full time for at least 3 years in a pharmacy or with a wholesale distributor in a capacity related to the dispensing and distribution of, and record keeping relating to, prescription drugs;
Is employed by the applicant full time in a managerial level position;
Is actively involved in and aware of the daily operation of the wholesale distributor;
Is physically present, except for an authorized absence such as sick leave or vacation leave, at the facility of the applicant during regular business hours;

Is serving as a designated representative for only one applicant at a time, or for two or more wholesale distributors who are located in the same facility and are members of an affiliated group, as defined in § 1504 of the Internal Revenue Code;
Does not have any convictions for a violation of any federal, state, or local laws relating to wholesale or retail prescription drug distribution or distribution of controlled substances; and
Does not have any convictions for a felony under federal, state, or local laws; and

paragraph.text: Determines that the immediate supervisor of the designated representative of the applicant meets the following qualifications:

subparagraph.text: Is at least 21 years of age;

Has been employed full time for at least 3 years in a pharmacy or with a wholesale distributor in a capacity related to the dispensing and distribution of, and record keeping relating to, prescription drugs;
Is employed by the applicant full time in a managerial level position;
Is actively involved in and aware of the daily operation of the wholesale distributor;
Does not have any convictions for a violation of any federal, state, or local laws relating to wholesale or retail prescription drug distribution or distribution of controlled substances; and
Does not have any convictions for a felony under federal, state, or local laws.

subsection.text: The designated representative and the immediate supervisor of the designated representative of an applicant shall submit to a criminal history records check in accordance with § 12–6C–05.1 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “gross receipts” means gross receipts from sales of prescription drugs and devices in the State.
This subsection does not apply to a pharmacy warehouse that is not engaged in wholesale distribution.

subparagraph.text: An applicant for a wholesale distributor permit shall submit a surety bond or other equivalent means of security acceptable to the State, such as an irrevocable letter of credit or a deposit in a trust account or financial institution, payable to the State Board of Pharmacy to be deposited into an account established by the State under paragraph (7) of this subsection.
The surety bond or other security shall be in the amount of:

sub-subparagraph.text: $100,000, if the annual gross receipts of the applicant for the previous tax year are $10,000,000 or more; or
$50,000, if the annual gross receipts of the applicant for the previous tax year are less than $10,000,000.

subparagraph.text: The Board may require by regulation documentation for the gross receipts of the wholesale distributor to qualify for a surety bond or other security in the amount of $50,000.

paragraph.text: The purpose of the surety bond is to secure payment of any fines or penalties imposed by the Board and any fees and costs incurred by the State relating to the permit that:

subparagraph.text: Are authorized under State law; and
Are not paid by the permit holder within 30 days after the fines, penalties, fees, or costs become final.

paragraph.text: The State may make a claim against the surety bond or other security until 2 years after the permit holder’s permit ceases to be valid.
A single surety bond shall cover all facilities operated by the applicant in the State.
The Board shall establish an account, separate from its other accounts, in which to deposit the applicant’s surety bond or other security.

subsection.text: If a wholesale distributor distributes prescription drugs or prescription devices from more than one facility, the wholesale distributor shall obtain a permit for each facility.

Within 30 days after the date the Board receives a completed application, including the results of all required criminal history records checks, the Board shall notify the applicant of the Board’s acceptance or rejection of the application.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “Central Repository” means the Criminal Justice Information System Central Repository of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services.
This subsection applies to applicants located in the State.

As part of an application to the Central Repository for a State and national criminal history records check, the designated representative and the immediate supervisor of the designated representative of an applicant shall submit to the Central Repository:

subparagraph.text: Two complete sets of legible fingerprints taken on forms approved by the director of the Central Repository and the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation;
The fee authorized under § 10–221(b)(7) of the Criminal Procedure Article for access to State criminal history records; and
The processing fee required by the Federal Bureau of Investigation for a national criminal history records check.

paragraph.text: In accordance with §§ 10–201 through 10–228 of the Criminal Procedure Article, the Central Repository shall forward the criminal history records information of the designated representative and the immediate supervisor of the designated representative of an applicant to the Board and the applicant.
The Board shall ensure that information obtained from the Central Repository under this subsection:

subparagraph.text: Is kept confidential;
Is not redisseminated; and
Is used only for the permitting purpose authorized by this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The subject of a criminal history records check under this subsection may contest the contents of the printed statement issued by the Central Repository as provided in § 10–223 of the Criminal Procedure Article.
This subsection applies to applicants located outside the State.

The designated representative and the immediate supervisor of the designated representative of an applicant shall submit to a criminal history records check by the applicant’s state of residence, in accordance with the laws of the applicant’s state of residence.
The criminal history records check shall consist of:

subparagraph.text: A state criminal history records check for the applicant’s state of residence; and
A national criminal history records check.

paragraph.text: The designated representative and the immediate supervisor of the designated representative of an applicant shall request the appropriate entity in the applicant’s state of residence to forward the results of the criminal history records check to the Board and the applicant.
The Board shall ensure that information obtained under this subsection:

subparagraph.text: Is kept confidential;
Is not redisseminated; and
Is used only for the permitting purpose authorized by this subtitle.

subsection.text: A wholesale distributor permit expires on May 31 after its effective date, unless the wholesale distributor permit is renewed for an additional 2–year term as provided in this section.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, at least 1 month before a wholesale distributor permit expires, the Board shall send to the wholesale distributor permit holder a renewal notice by first–class mail to the last known address of the permit holder.

If requested by a wholesale distributor permit holder, the Board shall send to the permit holder, at least two times within the month before a wholesale distributor permit expires, a renewal notice by electronic means to the last known electronic address of the permit holder.

If a renewal notice sent by electronic means under paragraph (2) of this subsection is returned to the Board as undeliverable, the Board shall send to the wholesale distributor permit holder a renewal notice by first–class mail to the last known address of the permit holder.
A renewal notice sent under this subsection shall state:

subparagraph.text: The date on which the current wholesale distributor permit expires;
The date by which the renewal application must be received by the Board for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the current wholesale distributor permit expires; and
The amount of the renewal fee.

paragraph.text: Before a wholesale distributor permit expires, a wholesale distributor permit holder periodically may renew it for an additional 2–year term, if the wholesale distributor permit holder:

subparagraph.text: Otherwise is entitled to a wholesale distributor permit;
Pays to the Board a renewal fee set by the Board; and
Submits to the Board a renewal application on the form that the Board requires.
The renewal application form shall set forth the information that the wholesale distributor provided under § 12–6C–05 of this subtitle.

Within 30 days after receiving the form, the wholesale distributor shall identify and state under oath to the Board all changes or corrections to the information that was provided under § 12–6C–05 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The Board shall renew the wholesale distributor permit of a wholesale distributor permit holder who meets the requirements of this subtitle and any regulations adopted under this subtitle.
The Board may deny, suspend, or revoke the permit of a wholesale distributor if the Board determines that the wholesale distributor no longer qualifies for a permit.

section.text: The Board:

paragraph.text: Shall adopt regulations that require routine inspections of wholesale distributor facilities; and
May adopt regulations establishing:

subparagraph.text: Minimum requirements for the receipt, storage, and handling of prescription drugs or prescription devices, security precautions, quality control, record keeping, and procedures, policy, and responsibilities of personnel; and
Education and experience requirements for personnel employed in positions responsible for carrying out the duties:

sub-subparagraph.text: Referenced in item (i) of this item; or
Related to State permit requirements under this subtitle.

section.text: Information provided by a wholesale distributor or an applicant for a wholesale distributor permit under this subtitle may not be disclosed to any person or entity except a State licensing or permitting authority, State board, or government agency that needs the information for licensing, permitting, monitoring, or law enforcement purposes.

paragraph.text: A wholesale distributor shall receive prescription drug returns or exchanges from a pharmacy or pharmacy warehouse according to the terms and conditions of the agreement between the wholesale distributor and the pharmacy or pharmacy warehouse.

Returns of expired, damaged, recalled, or otherwise nonsaleable prescription drugs shall be distributed by the receiving wholesale distributor only to either the original manufacturer or a third party returns processor.

Returns or exchanges of prescription drugs, saleable or otherwise, including any redistribution by a receiving wholesaler, are not subject to the pedigree requirements of § 12–6C–10 of this subtitle if they are exempt from the pedigree requirement of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration’s currently applicable Prescription Drug Marketing Act guidelines.
Wholesale distributors and pharmacies shall be accountable for:

subparagraph.text: Administering their returns process; and
Ensuring that the returns process is secure and does not permit the entry of adulterated and counterfeit product.

subsection.text: A wholesale distributor may supply prescription drugs only to a person authorized by law to dispense or receive prescription drugs.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a wholesale distributor may deliver prescription drugs only to:

subparagraph.text: The premises listed on the recipient’s license or permit; or
An authorized person or an agent of an authorized person at the premises of the wholesale distributor if:

sub-subparagraph.text: The identity and authorization of the person or agent is properly established; and
This method of delivery is employed only to meet the immediate needs of a particular patient of the authorized person.

subparagraph.text: Prescription drugs may be supplied to a hospital pharmacy receiving area if a pharmacist or authorized receiving personnel of the hospital pharmacy signs, at the time of delivery, a receipt showing the type and quantity of the prescription drug received.
Any discrepancy between the type and quantity of the prescription drug indicated on the receipt and the type and quantity of the prescription drug received:

sub-subparagraph.text: Shall be reported to the delivering wholesale distributor by the next business day after the delivery to the hospital pharmacy receiving area; and
May be reported to the Board for investigation.

paragraph.text: A wholesale distributor may not accept payment or allow the use of a person’s credit to establish an account for the purchase of prescription drugs from any person other than the owner of record, the chief executive officer, or the chief financial officer listed on the license or permit of a person legally authorized to receive prescription drugs.
Any account established for the purchase of prescription drugs shall bear the name of the license or permit holder.

subsection.text: A wholesale distributor may not operate out of a residence.

A person who is engaged in the wholesale distribution of a prescription drug that leaves, or has ever left, the normal distribution channel shall provide, before each wholesale distribution of the prescription drug, a pedigree to the person who receives the prescription drug.

A retail pharmacy or pharmacy warehouse shall comply with the requirements of this section only if the pharmacy or pharmacy warehouse engages in the wholesale distribution of a prescription drug in the State.

paragraph.text: To be considered part of the normal distribution channel, a wholesale distributor, a manufacturer’s exclusive distributor, and a manufacturer’s third party logistics provider also must be an authorized distributor of record.
Notwithstanding paragraph (1) of this subsection, a pharmacy warehouse that is not an authorized distributor of record shall be considered part of the normal distribution channel.

subsection.text: Each person who engages in the wholesale distribution of a prescription drug, including repackagers but excluding the original manufacturer of the finished form of the prescription drug, who is provided a pedigree for the prescription drug and attempts to further distribute the prescription drug, shall authenticate, before any distribution of the prescription drug occurs, that each transaction listed on the pedigree has occurred.
The pedigree shall include:

paragraph.text: All necessary identifying information relating to each sale in the chain of distribution of the prescription drug from the manufacturer or the manufacturer’s third party logistics provider, co–licensed partner, or manufacturer’s exclusive distributor, through acquisition and sale by any wholesale distributor or repackager, until final sale to a pharmacy or other person dispensing or administering the prescription drug, including:

subparagraph.text: The name, address, telephone number, and if available, electronic mail address, of each owner and each wholesale distributor of the prescription drug;
The name and address of each location from which the prescription drug was shipped, if different from the owner’s;
Transaction dates; and
Certification that each recipient has authenticated the pedigree;

paragraph.text: The name of the prescription drug;
The dosage form and strength of the prescription drug;
The size of the container;
The number of containers;
The lot number and National Drug Code of the prescription drug; and
The name of the manufacturer of the finished dosage form.

subsection.text: Each pedigree for a prescription drug shall be:

paragraph.text: Maintained by the purchaser and the wholesale distributor for 3 years from the date of sale or transfer; and
Available for inspection or use within 5 business days on request of the Board, the Board’s designee, or an authorized law enforcement officer.
If a person knowingly violates any provision of this subtitle or any regulation adopted under this subtitle, the Board may impose a fine not to exceed $500,000.
Before the Board imposes a fine, the Board shall consider the appropriateness of the fine in relation to:

subparagraph.text: The size of the wholesale distributor;
The gravity of the violation for which the fine is to be imposed;
The good faith of the wholesale distributor; and
Any previous violations by the wholesale distributor.

subsection.text: In addition to the penalty provided in subsection (a) of this section, the Board also may take disciplinary action against a permit holder who is convicted of or pleads guilty or nolo contendere to a violation of State, federal, or local drug laws.

section.text: On or before January 1, 2008, the Board shall adopt regulations to implement this subtitle.

On or before January 1, 2008, and on or before January 1 of each subsequent year, the Board shall report to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly on the implementation of this subtitle.
Except as otherwise provided in this title, a person may not practice, attempt to practice, or offer to practice pharmacy in this State unless licensed by the Board.

subsection.text: A person may not obtain a license by making any false representation.
On conviction of a person for obtaining a license by false representation, the license held by that person is void.

section.text: A person may not establish or operate a pharmacy in this State or a nonresident pharmacy unless the person holds a pharmacy permit issued by the Board.

paragraph.text: Unless authorized to practice pharmacy under this title, a person may not represent to the public by title, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the person is authorized to practice pharmacy in this State.
Unless authorized to practice pharmacy under this title, a person may not use the terms “pharmacist” or “druggist” with the intent to represent that the person practices pharmacy.

Unless an establishment has a pharmacy permit, a person may not represent to the public by title, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the establishment is a pharmacy.

The acts prohibited by this subsection include using, with the intent to misrepresent that an establishment is a pharmacy, the terms “pharmacy” or “drugstore”, the characteristic show bottles or globes filled with colored water, or any other term or symbol traditionally associated with practicing pharmacy.

subsection.text: A person who violates any provision of the following subtitles or sections of this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000:

paragraph.text: § 12-311 (“Display of licenses”);
Subtitle 4 (“Pharmacy permits”);
§ 12-502(b) (“Pharmaceutical information”);
§ 12-505 (“Labeling requirements for prescription medicines”); and
§ 12-604 (“General power to inspect drugs, devices, and other products”).

subsection.text: A person who violates any provision of the following sections of this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both:

paragraph.text: § 12-602 (“Distribution permits”);
§ 12-701 (“Practicing pharmacy without license”);
§ 12-702 (“License obtained by false representation”);
§ 12-703 (“Operating a pharmacy without permit”);
§ 12-704 (“Misrepresentations”); and
§ 12-6B-12 (“Working as an unregistered pharmacy technician”).

subsection.text: Each day that a violation of any section of Subtitle 4 of this title continues constitutes a separate offense.
Within 10 days after a court renders the conviction, the court shall report to the Board each conviction of a pharmacist or registered pharmacy technician for:

paragraph.text: Any crime regarding the pharmacy or drug laws that involves professional misconduct; or
Any crime that involves the State law regarding controlled dangerous substances or the federal narcotic laws.

Any person who violates § 12-701 (“Practicing pharmacy without a license”), § 12-703 (“Operating a pharmacy without a permit”), or § 12-6B-12 (“Working as an unregistered pharmacy technician”) of this title is subject to a civil fine of not more than $50,000 to be assessed by the Board.
The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this subsection into the State Board of Pharmacy Fund.

section.text: This title may be cited as the “Maryland Pharmacy Act”.

Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Program Evaluation Act, this title and all rules and regulations adopted under this title shall terminate and be of no effect after July 1, 2023.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the State Board of Physical Therapy Examiners.
“License” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a license issued by the Board to practice:

paragraph.text: Physical therapy; or
Limited physical therapy.

subsection.text: “Licensed physical therapist” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a physical therapist who is licensed by the Board to practice physical therapy.
“Licensed physical therapist assistant” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a physical therapist assistant who is licensed by the Board to practice limited physical therapy.

“Physical therapist” means an individual, licensed by the State Board of Physical Therapy Examiners, who practices physical therapy and who has passed the national physical therapy licensing examination administered or accepted by the Board.
“Physical therapist assistant” means an individual who practices limited physical therapy and who has passed the national physical therapy licensing examination administered or accepted by the Board.

paragraph.text: “Practice limited physical therapy” means to implement therapeutic interventions for the purpose of:

subparagraph.text: The prevention of disability in patients or clients; and
The physical rehabilitation of patients or clients with a congenital or acquired disability.

paragraph.text: “Practice limited physical therapy” includes, except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection:

subparagraph.text: Taking and documenting measurements; and

Administering therapeutic interventions that include therapeutic exercise, therapeutic massage, mechanical devices, or therapeutic agents that use the physical, chemical, or other properties of air, water, electricity, sound, or radiant energy.

paragraph.text: “Practice limited physical therapy” does not include:

subparagraph.text: Interpreting measurements;
Planning treatment programs;
Taking X rays;
Using radioactive substances; or
Using electricity for cauterization or surgery.

paragraph.text: “Practice physical therapy” means to design, implement, and modify therapeutic interventions for the purpose of:

subparagraph.text: The prevention of disability in patients or clients; and
The physical rehabilitation of patients or clients with a congenital or acquired disability.

paragraph.text: “Practice physical therapy” includes:

subparagraph.text: Performing an evaluation of the physical therapy needs of patients or clients;
Performing and interpreting tests and measurements of neuromuscular and musculoskeletal functions to aid treatment;
Planning treatment programs that are based on test findings; and

Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, administering therapeutic interventions that include therapeutic exercise, therapeutic massage, mechanical devices, or therapeutic agents that use the physical, chemical, or other properties of air, water, electricity, sound, or radiant energy.

paragraph.text: “Practice physical therapy” does not include:

subparagraph.text: Taking X rays;
Using radioactive substances; or
Using electricity for cauterization or surgery.

subsection.text: “Restricted license” means a license issued by the Board under and as limited by § 13–314 of this title to practice physical therapy.

section.text: Except as specifically provided in this title, this title does not limit the right of:

paragraph.text: An individual to practice a health occupation that the individual is authorized to practice under this article;
A chiropractor to practice physical therapy if the chiropractor is authorized to practice physical therapy under Title 3 of this article;
An individual to provide nonmedical services while:

subparagraph.text: Practicing cosmetology; or
Operating a health club; or

paragraph.text: A health club to advertise as a health club.

section.text: There is a State Board of Physical Therapy Examiners in the Department.

paragraph.text: The Board consists of 8 members.
Of the 8 Board members:

subparagraph.text: Five shall be licensed physical therapists, of which a minimum of four shall be engaged primarily in the clinical practice of physical therapy in this State;
One shall be a licensed physical therapist assistant practicing limited physical therapy in this State; and
Two shall be consumer members.

paragraph.text: The Governor shall appoint the licensed physical therapist members and the licensed physical therapist assistant member, with the advice of the Secretary, from a list of names of qualified individuals submitted to the Secretary and the Governor by the American Physical Therapy Association of Maryland. The number of names on the list shall be at least three times the number of vacancies.
The Governor shall appoint the consumer members with the advice of the Secretary and the advice and consent of the Senate.

subsection.text: Each licensed physical therapist member:

paragraph.text: Shall have at least 5 years’ experience in physical therapy administration, education, practice, or research immediately before appointment; and
Shall be engaged in the profession of physical therapy in this State.

subsection.text: The licensed physical therapist assistant member shall:

paragraph.text: Have 5 years’ experience in limited physical therapy; and
Be engaged in the profession of limited physical therapy in this State.

subsection.text: Each consumer member of the Board:

paragraph.text: Shall be a member of the general public;
May not be or ever have been a physical therapist or physical therapist assistant or in training to become a physical therapist or physical therapist assistant;
May not have a household member who is a physical therapist or physical therapist assistant or in training to become a physical therapist or physical therapist assistant;
May not participate or ever have participated in a commercial or professional field related to physical therapy;
May not have a household member who participates in a commercial or professional field related to physical therapy; and
May not have had within 2 years before appointment a substantial financial interest in a person regulated by the Board.

subsection.text: While a member of the Board, a consumer member may not have a substantial financial interest in a person regulated by the Board.
Before taking office, each appointee to the Board shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 4 years.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on July 1, 1981.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
To the extent practicable, the Governor shall fill any vacancy on the Board within 60 days of the date of the vacancy.
A member may not serve more than 2 consecutive full terms.
The Governor may remove a member for incompetence or misconduct.
Upon the recommendation of the Secretary, the Governor may remove a member whom the Secretary finds to have been absent from 2 successive Board meetings without adequate reason.

subsection.text: From among its members, the Board annually shall elect a chairman and vice chairman.
The Board shall determine:

paragraph.text: The manner of election of the chairman and vice chairman; and
The duties of the chairman and vice chairman.

subsection.text: The Board shall appoint a Board executive director, who serves at the pleasure of the Board.
The Board executive director:

paragraph.text: Is the executive officer of the Board; and
Has the powers and duties assigned by the Board.

subsection.text: A majority of the full authorized membership of the Board is a quorum to do business.
The Board shall determine the times and places of its meetings.
Each member of the Board is entitled to:

paragraph.text: Compensation determined by the Board and in accordance with the budget of the Board; and
Reimbursement for expenses at a rate determined by the Board.

subsection.text: In accordance with the budget of the Board, the Board may employ:

paragraph.text: A staff; and
Experts and consultants to obtain information and advice that relate to physical therapy.

subsection.text: In addition to the powers set forth elsewhere in this title, the Board may:

paragraph.text: Adopt rules and regulations to carry out the provisions of this title;
Adopt standards of practice and a code of ethics for the practice of physical therapy and limited physical therapy; and
Pay, in accordance with the State budget, any necessary expense that relates to the referral of an alleged violation of the criminal provisions of this title.

subsection.text: In addition to the duties set forth elsewhere in this title, the Board shall:

paragraph.text: Keep a list of the name and address of each licensed physical therapist and licensed physical therapist assistant;
Present evidence of any alleged violation of this title to the State’s Attorney of the county where the alleged violation occurred; and
Adopt rules and regulations that govern the use of a physical therapy aide by a licensed physical therapist.

subsection.text: There is a State Board of Physical Therapy Examiners Fund.

paragraph.text: The Board may set reasonable fees for the issuance and renewal of licenses and its other services.
The fees charged shall be set so as to approximate the cost of maintaining the Board.
Funds to cover the compensation and expenses of the Board members shall be generated by fees set under this section.
The Board shall pay all funds collected under this title to the Comptroller of the State.
The Comptroller shall distribute the fees to the State Board of Physical Therapy Examiners Fund.
The Fund shall be used to cover the actual documented direct and indirect costs of fulfilling the statutory and regulatory duties of the Board as provided by the provisions of this article.
The Fund is a continuing, nonlapsing fund, not subject to § 7-302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
Any unspent portions of the Fund may not be transferred or revert to the General Fund of the State, but shall remain in the Fund to be used for the purposes specified in this article.
No other State money may be used to support the Fund.
A designee of the Board shall administer the Fund.
Moneys in the Fund may be expended only for any lawful purpose authorized under the provisions of this article.

subsection.text: The Legislative Auditor shall audit the accounts and transactions of the Fund as provided in § 2-1220 of the State Government Article.

section.text: If it is determined that disclosure of information contained in a record of the Board will serve to protect the public, the Board, after an affirmative vote of a majority, may:

paragraph.text: Disclose any information contained in a record of the Board to any other health occupations licensure board of this State if the information relates to an individual licensed or certified by the other board; or
Disclose to a physical therapy licensure board of any other state:

subparagraph.text: Any information contained in a record of the Board if the information relates to an individual licensed by the Board and is based on a final decision of the Board; or
The information that a licensee has charges pending before the Board and there has been no final decision in the matter.

section.text: A person shall have the immunity from liability described under § 5-714 of the Courts and Judicial Proceedings Article for giving information to the Board or otherwise participating in its activities.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, an individual shall be licensed by the Board before the individual may practice physical therapy or limited physical therapy in this State.
This section does not apply to:

paragraph.text: A student who is supervised directly by a licensed physical therapist in a Board approved physical therapy educational program; or
A physical therapy aide, if the physical therapy aide:

subparagraph.text: Subject to the rules and regulations adopted by the Board, performs only procedures that do not require the professional skills of a licensed physical therapist or a licensed physical therapist assistant; and
Performs procedures only under the direct supervision of a licensed physical therapist who personally is present in the area where the procedures are performed.

paragraph.text: To qualify for a physical therapy license, an applicant shall be an individual who meets the requirements of:

subparagraph.text: This section; and
§ 13-303 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: To qualify for a physical therapist assistant license, an applicant shall be an individual who meets the requirements of:

subparagraph.text: This section; and
§ 13-304 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The applicant shall be of good moral character.
Except as otherwise provided in this title, the applicant shall pass the appropriate examination given by the Board under this subtitle.
The applicant shall meet any other qualifications or requirements that the Board establishes for license applicants.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Board shall require as part of its examination or licensing procedures that an applicant for a license to practice physical therapy or limited physical therapy demonstrate written and oral competency in the English language.
An applicant is exempt from English language competency testing under paragraph (1) of this subsection if the applicant graduated from a physical therapy program that was taught in English.

By regulation, the Board shall develop a procedure for testing individuals who because of their speech impairment are unable to complete satisfactorily a Board approved standardized test of oral competency.

If any disciplinary charges or action that involves a problem with the oral communication of the English language are brought against a licensee under this title, the Board shall require the licensee to take and pass a Board approved standardized test of oral competency.

subsection.text: If an applicant for a physical therapy license has been educated in physical therapy in any state, the applicant shall have:

paragraph.text: Graduated from a physical therapy program that, in the year of graduation, was approved by:

subparagraph.text: The American Medical Association;
The American Physical Therapy Association; or
The Commission on Accreditation of Physical Therapy Education; and

paragraph.text: Completed satisfactorily the clinical training required by the physical therapy curriculum.

subsection.text: If an applicant for a physical therapy license has been educated in physical therapy outside of any state, the applicant shall have graduated from a physical therapy program that in the year of graduation had educational requirements equivalent to a degree in physical therapy from a United States program accredited by the Commission on Accreditation of Physical Therapy Education.

section.text: To qualify for a physical therapist assistant license, an applicant shall have:

paragraph.text: Graduated from a curriculum for physical therapist assistants that is approved by the American Physical Therapy Association; and
Completed satisfactorily the clinical training required by the curriculum for physical therapist assistants.

subsection.text: To apply for a physical therapy license, an applicant shall:

paragraph.text: Submit to the Board:

subparagraph.text: An application on the form that the Board requires;
Evidence of completion of:

sub-subparagraph.text: A physical therapy curriculum; and
Any clinical training required under the physical therapy curriculum; and

subparagraph.text: Any other document that the Board requires; and

paragraph.text: Pay to the Board the application fee set by the Board.

subsection.text: To apply for a physical therapist assistant license, an applicant shall:

paragraph.text: Submit to the Board:

subparagraph.text: An application on the form that the Board requires;
Evidence of completion of:

sub-subparagraph.text: A physical therapist assistant curriculum; and
Any clinical training required under the physical therapist assistant curriculum; and

subparagraph.text: Any other document that the Board requires; and

paragraph.text: Pay to the Board the application fee set by the Board.

subsection.text: An applicant who otherwise qualifies for a license is entitled to be examined for that license as provided in this section.
The Board shall give examinations at least twice a year, at the times and places that the Board determines, to applicants for:

paragraph.text: A physical therapy license; and
A physical therapist assistant license.

subsection.text: The Board or its agent shall notify each qualified applicant of the time and place of the examination.
The Board shall determine the subjects, scope, form, and passing score for examinations given under this subtitle.

Subject to the provisions of this section, the Board may waive any examination requirement for an applicant who is licensed or otherwise is authorized to practice physical therapy or limited physical therapy in another state.
The Board may grant a waiver under this section only if the applicant:
