subsection.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 14–405 of this title, the Board, on the affirmative vote of a majority of the quorum may deny a license or temporary license to any applicant, reprimand any licensee or holder of a temporary license, place any licensee or holder of a temporary license on probation, or suspend or revoke a license if the applicant licensee or holder of a temporary license:

paragraph.text: Fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a license or temporary license for the applicant, licensed individual, holder of a temporary license, or for another;
Fraudulently or deceptively uses a license or temporary license;
Is guilty of unprofessional or immoral conduct in the practice of radiation therapy, radiography, nuclear medicine technology, or radiology assistance;
Is professionally, physically, or mentally incompetent;
Abandons a patient;
Is habitually intoxicated;
Is addicted to or habitually abuses any narcotic or controlled dangerous substance as defined in § 5–101 of the Criminal Law Article;
Provides professional services while:

subparagraph.text: Under the influence of alcohol; or
Using any narcotic or controlled dangerous substance as defined in § 5–101 of the Criminal Law Article or any other drug that is in excess of therapeutic amounts or without valid medical indication;

paragraph.text: Promotes the sale of services, drugs, devices, appliances, or goods to a patient so as to exploit the patient for financial gain;
Willfully makes or files a false report or record in the practice of radiation therapy, radiography, nuclear medicine technology, or radiology assistance;
Willfully fails to file or record any report as required under law, willfully impedes or obstructs the filing or recording of a report, or induces another to fail to file or record a report;
Breaches patient confidentiality;

Pays or agrees to pay any sum or provide any form of remuneration or material benefit to any person for bringing or referring a patient or accepts or agrees to accept any sum or any form of remuneration or material benefit from an individual for bringing or referring a patient;
Knowingly makes a misrepresentation while practicing radiation therapy, radiography, nuclear medicine technology, or radiology assistance;

Knowingly practices radiation therapy, radiography, nuclear medicine technology, or radiology assistance with an unauthorized individual or aids an unauthorized individual in the practice of radiation therapy, radiography, nuclear medicine technology, or radiology assistance;
Offers, undertakes, or agrees to cure or treat disease by a secret method, treatment, or medicine;

Is disciplined by a licensing or disciplinary authority or is convicted or disciplined by a court of any state or country or is disciplined by any branch of the United States uniformed services or the Veterans’ Administration for an act that would be grounds for disciplinary action under the Board’s disciplinary statutes;

Fails to meet appropriate standards for the delivery of quality radiation therapy, radiography, nuclear medicine technology, or radiology assistance care performed in any outpatient surgical facility, office, hospital or related institution, or any other location in this State;
Knowingly submits false statements to collect fees for which services are not provided;

subparagraph.text: Has been subject to investigation or disciplinary action by a licensing or disciplinary authority or by a court of any state or country for an act that would be grounds for disciplinary action under the Board’s disciplinary statutes; and
The licensed individual:

sub-subparagraph.text: Surrendered the license issued by the state or country; or
Allowed the license issued by the state or country to expire or lapse;

paragraph.text: Knowingly fails to report suspected child abuse in violation of § 5–704 of the Family Law Article;
Sells, prescribes, gives away, or administers drugs for illegal or illegitimate medical purposes;
Practices or attempts to practice beyond the authorized scope of practice;

Refuses, withholds from, denies, or discriminates against an individual with regard to the provision of professional services for which the licensee or holder of a temporary license is licensed and qualified to render because the individual is HIV positive;

Practices or attempts to practice a radiation therapy, radiography, nuclear medicine technology, or radiology assistance procedure or uses radiation therapy, radiography, nuclear medicine technology, or radiology assistance equipment if the applicant or licensee or holder of a temporary license has not received education, internship, training, or experience in the performance of the procedure or the use of the equipment;
Fails to cooperate with a lawful investigation conducted by the Board; or
Fails to practice under the supervision of a physician or violates a supervisory order of a supervising physician.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in the Administrative Procedure Act, before the Board takes any action under subsection (a) of this section, it shall give the individual against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Board in accordance with the hearing requirements of § 14–405 of this title.

paragraph.text: On the filing of certified docket entries with the Board by the Office of the Attorney General, the Board shall order the suspension of a licensee or holder of a temporary license if the licensee or holder of a temporary license is convicted of or pleads guilty or nolo contendere with respect to a crime involving moral turpitude, whether or not any appeal or other proceeding is pending to have the conviction or plea set aside.

After completion of the appellate process if the conviction has not been reversed or the plea has not been set aside with respect to a crime involving moral turpitude, the Board shall order the revocation of a license or temporary license on the certification by the Office of the Attorney General.
Any person aggrieved by a final decision of the Board under this subtitle may not appeal to the Secretary or Board of Review but may take a direct judicial appeal.
The appeal shall be made as provided for judicial review of final decisions in the Administrative Procedure Act.

subsection.text: An order of the Board may not be stayed pending review.
The Board may appeal from any decision that reverses or modifies its order.

Except as provided in subsections (b) and (d) of this section, hospitals, related institutions, alternative health systems as defined in § 1–401 of this article, and employers shall file with the Board a report that the hospital, related institution, alternative health system, or employer limited, reduced, otherwise changed, or terminated any licensee or holder of a temporary license for any reason that might be grounds for disciplinary action under § 14–5B–13 of this subtitle.

A hospital, related institution, alternative health system, or employer that has reason to know that a licensee or holder of a temporary license has committed an action or has a condition that might be grounds for reprimand or probation of the licensee or holder of a temporary license or suspension or revocation of the licensure because the licensee or holder of a temporary license is alcohol impaired or drug impaired is not required to report the licensee or holder of a temporary license to the Board if:

paragraph.text: The hospital, related institution, alternative health system, or employer knows that the licensee or holder of a temporary license is:

subparagraph.text: In an alcohol or drug treatment program that is accredited by the Joint Commission on Accreditation of Healthcare Organizations or is certified by the Department; or
Under the care of a health care practitioner who is competent and capable of dealing with alcoholism and drug abuse;
The hospital, related institution, alternative health system, or employer is able to verify that the licensee or holder of a temporary license remains in the treatment program until discharge; and
The action or condition of the licensee or holder of a temporary license has not caused injury to any person while the licensee or holder of a temporary license is practicing.

paragraph.text: If the licensee or holder of a temporary license enters, or is considering entering, an alcohol or drug treatment program that is accredited by the Joint Commission on Accreditation of Healthcare Organizations or that is certified by the Department, the licensee or holder of a temporary license shall notify the hospital, related institution, alternative health system, or employer of the licensee’s or holder’s decision to enter the treatment program.

If the licensee or holder of a temporary license fails to provide the notice required under paragraph (1) of this subsection, and the hospital, related institution, alternative health system, or employer learns that the licensee or holder of a temporary license has entered a treatment program, the hospital, related institution, alternative health system, or employer shall report to the Board that the licensee or holder of a temporary license has entered a treatment program and has failed to provide the required notice.

If the licensee or holder of a temporary license is found to be noncompliant with the treatment program’s policies and procedures while in the treatment program, the treatment program shall notify the hospital, related institution, alternative health system, or employer of the licensee’s or holder’s noncompliance.

On receipt of the notification required under paragraph (3) of this subsection, the hospital, related institution, alternative health system, or employer of the licensee or holder of a temporary license shall report the licensee’s or holder’s noncompliance to the Board.

subsection.text: A person is not required under this section to make any report that would be in violation of any federal or State law, rule, or regulation concerning the confidentiality of alcohol and drug abuse patient records.
The hospital, related institution, alternative health system, or employer shall submit the report within 10 days of any action described in this section.
A report made under this section is not subject to subpoena or discovery in any civil action other than a proceeding arising out of a hearing and decision of the Board under this title.

paragraph.text: The Board may impose a civil penalty of up to $1,000 for failure to report under this section.
The Board shall remit any penalty collected under this subsection into the General Fund of the State.

section.text: On the application of an individual whose license has been revoked, the Board may reinstate a revoked license.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, a person may not practice, attempt to practice, or offer to practice radiation therapy in this State unless licensed to practice radiation therapy by the Board.

Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, a person may not practice, attempt to practice, or offer to practice nuclear medicine technology in this State unless licensed to practice nuclear medicine technology by the Board.
Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, a person may not practice, attempt to practice, or offer to practice radiography in this State unless licensed to practice radiography by the Board.

Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, a person may not practice, attempt to practice, or offer to practice radiology assistance in this State unless licensed to practice radiology assistance by the Board.

Unless authorized to practice radiation therapy, radiography, nuclear medicine technology, or radiology assistance under this subtitle, a person may not represent to the public by title, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the person is authorized to practice radiation therapy, radiography, nuclear medicine technology, or radiology assistance in this State.

A person may not provide, attempt to provide, offer to provide, or represent that the person provides radiation therapy, radiography, nuclear medicine technology, or radiology assistance care unless the radiation therapy, radiography, nuclear medicine technology, or radiology assistance care is provided by an individual who is authorized to practice radiation therapy, radiography, nuclear medicine technology, or radiology assistance under this subtitle.

Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, a licensed physician may not employ or supervise an individual practicing radiation therapy, radiography, nuclear medicine technology, or radiology assistance without a license or temporary license.

Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, a hospital, related institution, alternative health system, or employer may not employ an individual practicing radiation therapy, radiography, nuclear medicine technology, or radiology assistance without a license or temporary license.
The Board may impose a civil penalty of up to $1,000 for employing an individual without a license or temporary license under this section.
The Board shall remit any penalty collected under this section into the General Fund of the State.
A person who violates any provision of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.
Any person who violates this subtitle is subject to a civil fine of not more than $5,000 to be levied by the Board.
The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this section into the Board of Physicians Fund.

section.text: This subtitle may be cited as the “Maryland Radiation Therapy, Radiography, Nuclear Medicine Technology, and Radiology Assistance Act”.

Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act, and subject to the termination of this title under § 14-702 of this title, this subtitle and all rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle shall terminate and be of no effect after July 1, 2013.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the State Board of Physicians.
“Committee” means the Polysomnography Professional Standards Committee established under § 14-5C-05 of this subtitle.
“License” means a license issued by the Board.

“Licensed polysomnographic technologist” means a polysomnographic technologist who is licensed by the Board under this subtitle to practice polysomnography under the supervision of a licensed physician.

paragraph.text: “Practice polysomnography” means:

subparagraph.text: Monitoring and recording physiologic data during sleep, including sleep-related respiratory disturbances under the supervision of a licensed physician; or
Using data collected under item (i) of this paragraph for the purposes of assisting a licensed physician in the diagnosis and treatment of sleep and wake disorders.

paragraph.text: “Practice polysomnography” includes:

subparagraph.text: Providing polysomnography services that are safe, aseptic, preventive, and restorative;
Diagnosing and treating individuals who suffer from sleep disorders as a result of developmental defects, the aging process, physical injury, disease, or actual or anticipated somatic dysfunction;

Observing and monitoring physical signs and symptoms, general behavior, and general physical response to polysomnographic evaluation and determining whether initiation, modification, or discontinuation of a treatment regimen is warranted;

Using evaluation techniques that include limited cardiopulmonary function assessments, the need and effectiveness of therapeutic modalities and procedures, and the assessment and evaluation of the need for extended care; and
Applying the use of techniques, equipment, and procedures involved in the evaluation of polysomnography, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: Continuous positive airway pressure or bi-level positive airway pressure titration on spontaneously breathing patients;
Supplemental low flow oxygen therapy during polysomnogram;
Capnography during polysomnogram;
Cardiopulmonary resuscitation;
Pulse oximetry;
PH probe placement and monitoring;
Esophageal pressure;
Sleep staging including surface electroencephalography, surface electrooculography, and surface submental electromyography;
Surface electromyography of arms and legs;
Electrocardiography;
Respiratory effort including thoracic and abdominal;
Plethysmography blood flow;
Snore monitoring;
Audio or video monitoring;
Implementation of a written or verbal order from a licensed physician that requires the practice of polysomnography;
Monitoring the effects a nasal device, used to treat sleep apnea, has on sleep patterns provided that the device does not extend into the trachea; and
Monitoring the effects an oral device, used to treat sleep apnea, has on sleep patterns, provided that:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: The device does not extend into the trachea;
A dentist has evaluated the structures of the patient’s oral and maxillofacial region for purposes of fitting;
A dentist made or directed the making of the oral device; and
A dentist directs the use of the oral device.

subsection.text: “Student” means an individual who, in accordance with section 14-5C-09(c) of this subtitle, is:

paragraph.text: Enrolled in an accredited educational program in order to qualify for a license under this title; and
Performing polysomnography services within the accredited program under the supervision of a licensed physician and without compensation.

subsection.text: “Registered polysomnographic technologist” means a polysomnographic technologist who is registered by the Board of Registered Polysomnographic Technicians.
“Supervision” means general or direct supervision of a licensed polysomnographic technologist by a licensed physician.

section.text: This subtitle does not limit:

paragraph.text: The right of an individual to practice a health occupation that the individual is authorized to practice under this article;
The right of a licensed home medical equipment provider to provide home medical equipment services as defined under Title 19, Subtitle 4A of the Health – General Article; or

The right of a licensed respiratory care practitioner to practice respiratory care within the scope of practice of the respiratory care practitioner’s license, including practicing respiratory care in a sleep laboratory.

section.text: The Board shall adopt regulations for the licensure and practice of polysomnography.

paragraph.text: The Board shall set reasonable fees for the issuance of and renewal of licenses and other services it provides to polysomnographic technologists.
The fees charged shall be set so as to produce funds to approximate the cost of maintaining the licensure program and the other services provided to polysomnographic technologists.
The Board shall pay all fees collected under the provisions of this subtitle to the Comptroller.
The Comptroller shall distribute all fees to the Board.

subsection.text: The fees shall be used to cover the actual documented direct and indirect costs of fulfilling the statutory and regulatory duties of the Board as provided by the provisions of this subtitle.

section.text: There is a Polysomnography Professional Standards Committee within the Board.

subsection.text: The Committee consists of seven members appointed by the Board as follows:

subparagraph.text: On or before September 30, 2009, three registered polysomnographic technologists; or
On or after October 1, 2009, three licensed polysomnographic technologists;

paragraph.text: Three physicians who are Board certified in sleep medicine:

subparagraph.text: One of whom is a specialist in psychiatry or internal medicine;
One of whom is a specialist in pulmonary medicine; and
One of whom is a specialist in neurology; and

paragraph.text: One consumer member.

subsection.text: The consumer member of the Committee:

paragraph.text: Shall be a member of the general public;
May not be or ever have been:

subparagraph.text: A polysomnographic technologist;
Any health care professional; or
In training to be a polysomnographic technologist or other health care professional;

paragraph.text: May not have a household member who is a health care professional or is in training to be a health care professional; and
May not:

subparagraph.text: Participate or ever have participated in a commercial or professional field related to polysomnography;
Have a household member who participates in a commercial or professional field related to polysomnography;
Have had within 2 years before appointment a financial interest in a person regulated by the Board; or
Have had within 2 years before appointment a financial interest in the provision of goods or services to polysomnographic technologists or to the field of polysomnography.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 3 years.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Committee on October 1, 2006.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

section.text: In addition to the powers set forth elsewhere in this subtitle, the Committee shall:

paragraph.text: Develop and recommend to the Board regulations to carry out the provisions of this subtitle;
Develop and recommend to the Board a code of ethics for the practice of polysomnography for adoption by the Board;
Develop and recommend to the Board standards of care for the practice of polysomnography;
Develop and recommend to the Board the requirements for licensure as a polysomnographic technologist, including:

subparagraph.text: Criteria for the educational and clinical training of licensed polysomnographic technologists; and
Criteria for a professional competency examination and testing of applicants for a license to practice polysomnography;

paragraph.text: Develop and recommend to the Board criteria for licensed polysomnographic technologists who are licensed in other states to practice in this State;
Evaluate the accreditation status of education programs in polysomnography for approval by the Board;
Evaluate the credentials of applicants and recommend licensure of applicants who fulfill the requirements for a license to practice polysomnography;
Develop and recommend to the Board continuing education requirements for license renewal;
Provide the Board with recommendations concerning the practice of polysomnography;
Develop and recommend to the Board criteria for the direction of students in clinical education programs by licensed polysomnographic technologists and licensed physicians;
Keep a record of its proceedings; and
Submit an annual report to the Board.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, on or after October 1, 2013, an individual shall be licensed by the Board before the individual may practice polysomnography in this State.
This section does not apply to a student enrolled in an education program under § 14–5C–09(c)(3) of this subtitle while practicing polysomnography in that program.

This section does not apply to a respiratory care practitioner who was licensed by the Board to practice respiratory care on or before December 31, 2012, and whose duties include practicing polysomnography.
To qualify for a license, an applicant shall be an individual who meets the requirements of this section.
The applicant shall:

paragraph.text: Be of good moral character; and
Be at least 18 years old.

subsection.text: An applicant for a polysomnographic technologist license shall:

paragraph.text: Have passed the national certifying examination given by the Board of Registered Polysomnographic Technologists or another examination approved by the Board;
Submit to the Board proof of certification as a registered polysomnographic technologist or other national certification approved by the Board;

sub-subparagraph.text: Have graduated from a polysomnographic educational program that is accredited by the Commission on Accreditation of Allied Health Education Programs; or

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: Have graduated from a sleep technologist educational program that is accredited by the American Academy of Sleep Medicine; and
Have completed a clinical component of an educational program as established by the Committee and approved by the Board;

sub-subparagraph.text: Have graduated from a respiratory care educational program that is accredited by the Commission on Accreditation of Allied Health Education Programs; and

Have completed the Committee on Accreditation for Respiratory Care’s curriculum for a polysomnography certificate that is accredited by the Commission on Accreditation of Allied Health Education Programs; or
Have graduated from an electroneuro–diagnostic educational program that is accredited by the Commission on Accreditation of Allied Health Education Programs; and

Have completed additional units, modules, and courses of instruction focused on polysomnographic technology that are accredited by the Commission on Accreditation of Allied Health Education Programs; and

paragraph.text: Meet any other educational or clinical requirements established by the Committee and approved by the Board.

subsection.text: The Board shall waive the education requirement under § 14–5C–09(c)(3) of this subtitle if on or before September 30, 2013, an individual:

paragraph.text: Has passed the national certifying examination by the Board of Registered Polysomnographic Technologists or another examination approved by the Board;
Is certified by the Board of Registered Polysomnographic Technologists as a registered polysomnographic technologist;
Has submitted an application for licensure to the Board; and
Meets all of the requirements under § 14–5C–09(b) and (c)(1) and (2) of this subtitle.
If an individual has not satisfied the requirements under subsection (a) of this section on or before September 30, 2013, the individual may petition the Board for an extension.
The Board shall determine whether to grant an extension under this subsection on a case–by–case basis.

section.text: To apply for a license, an applicant shall:

paragraph.text: Submit an application to the Board on the form that the Board requires; and
Pay to the Board the application fee set by the Board.

section.text: The Board shall issue a license to an applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle.

subsection.text: A license authorizes a polysomnographic technologist to practice polysomnography in this State while the license is effective.
A licensed polysomnographic technologist may practice polysomnography in:

paragraph.text: A hospital sleep laboratory; or
A stand-alone sleep center.

subsection.text: A license expires on a date set by the Board, unless the license is renewed for an additional term as provided in this section.

At least 1 month before a license expires, the Board shall send to the licensed polysomnographic technologist, by first-class mail to the last known address of the licensed polysomnographic technologist, a renewal notice that states:

paragraph.text: The date on which the current license expires;
The date by which the renewal application must be received by the Board for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the license expires; and
The amount of the renewal fee.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, before a license expires, the licensed polysomnographic technologist periodically may renew it for an additional term, if the licensee:

paragraph.text: Otherwise is entitled to be licensed;
Pays to the Board a renewal fee set by the Board; and
Submits to the Board:

subparagraph.text: A renewal application on the form that the Board requires; and
Satisfactory evidence of compliance with any continuing education or competency requirements and other requirements set under this section for license renewal.

subsection.text: In addition to any other qualifications and requirements established by the Board, the Board may establish continuing education or competency requirements as a condition of the renewal of a license under this section.
The Board shall renew the license of each licensee who meets the requirements of this section.

The Board shall reinstate the license of a polysomnographic technologist who has not placed the license on an inactive status and who has failed to renew the license for any reason if the polysomnographic technologist:

paragraph.text: Applies for reinstatement within 30 days after the date the license expires;
Meets the renewal requirements of this section; and
Pays to the Board the reinstatement fee set by the Board.
The Board shall place a licensed polysomnographic technologist on inactive status, if the licensee submits to the Board:

subparagraph.text: An application for inactive status on the form required by the Board; and
The inactive status fee set by the Board.

paragraph.text: The Board shall issue a license to an individual who is on inactive status if the individual complies with the renewal requirements that exist at the time the individual changes from inactive to active status.

subsection.text: The Board may reinstate the license of a polysomnographic technologist who has not been put on inactive status, who has failed to renew the license for any reason, and who applies for reinstatement more than 30 days after the license has expired, if the polysomnographic technologist:

paragraph.text: Meets the renewal requirements of § 14-5C-14 of this subtitle;
Pays to the Board the reinstatement fee set by the Board; and
Meets any other requirements established by regulation.

section.text: Unless the Board agrees to accept the surrender of a license, a licensed polysomnographic technologist may not surrender the license nor may the license lapse by operation of law while the licensee is under investigation or while charges are pending against the licensee.

subsection.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 14-405 of this title, the Board may deny a license to any applicant, reprimand any licensee, place any licensee on probation, or suspend or revoke a license if the applicant or licensee:

paragraph.text: Fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a license for the applicant, licensee, or for another;
Fraudulently or deceptively uses a license;
Is guilty of unprofessional or immoral conduct in the practice of polysomnography;
Is professionally, physically, or mentally incompetent;
Abandons a patient;
Is habitually intoxicated;
Is addicted to or habitually abuses any narcotic or controlled dangerous substance as defined in § 5-101 of the Criminal Law Article;
Provides professional services while:

subparagraph.text: Under the influence of alcohol; or
Using any narcotic or controlled dangerous substance as defined in § 5-101 of the Criminal Law Article or any other drug that is in excess of therapeutic amounts or without valid medical indication;

paragraph.text: Promotes the sale of services, drugs, devices, appliances, or goods to a patient so as to exploit the patient for financial gain;
Willfully makes or files a false report or record in the practice of polysomnography;
Willfully fails to file or record any report as required under law, willfully impedes or obstructs the filing or recording of a report, or induces another to fail to file or record a report;
Breaches patient confidentiality;

Pays or agrees to pay any sum or provide any form of remuneration or material benefit to any person for bringing or referring a patient or accepts or agrees to accept any sum or any form of remuneration or material benefit from an individual for bringing or referring a patient;
Knowingly makes a misrepresentation while practicing polysomnography;
Knowingly practices polysomnography with an unauthorized individual or aids an unauthorized individual in the practice of polysomnography;
Knowingly delegates a polysomnographic duty to an unlicensed individual;
Offers, undertakes, or agrees to cure or treat disease by a secret method, treatment, or medicine;

Is disciplined by a licensing or disciplinary authority or is convicted or disciplined by a court of any state or country or is disciplined by any branch of the United States uniformed services or the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs for an act that would be grounds for disciplinary action under the Board’s disciplinary statutes;
Fails to meet appropriate standards for the delivery of polysomnographic services performed in a hospital sleep laboratory or a stand-alone sleep center;
Knowingly submits false statements to collect fees for which services are not provided;

subparagraph.text: Has been subject to investigation or disciplinary action by a licensing or disciplinary authority or by a court of any state or country for an act that would be grounds for disciplinary action under the Board’s disciplinary statutes; and
Has:

sub-subparagraph.text: Surrendered the license, if any, issued by the state or country; or
Allowed the license, if any, issued by the state or country to expire or lapse;

paragraph.text: Knowingly fails to report suspected child abuse in violation of § 5-704 of the Family Law Article;
Sells, prescribes, gives away, or administers drugs for illegal or illegitimate medical purposes;
Practices or attempts to practice beyond the authorized scope of practice;

Is convicted of or pleads guilty or nolo contendere to a felony or to a crime involving moral turpitude, whether or not any appeal or other proceeding is pending to have the conviction or plea set aside;

Refuses, withholds from, denies, or discriminates against an individual with regard to the provision of professional services for which the licensee is licensed and qualified to render because the individual is HIV positive; or

Practices or attempts to practice a polysomnography procedure or uses or attempts to use polysomnography equipment if the applicant or licensee has not received education and training in the performance of the procedure or the use of the equipment.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article, before the Board takes any action under subsection (a) of this section, it shall give the individual against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Board in accordance with the hearing requirements of § 14-405 of this title.

paragraph.text: On the filing of certified docket entries with the Board by the Office of the Attorney General, the Board shall order the suspension of a license if the licensee is convicted of or pleads guilty or nolo contendere with respect to a crime involving moral turpitude, whether or not any appeal or other proceeding is pending to have the conviction or plea set aside.

After completion of the appellate process if the conviction has not been reversed or the plea has not been set aside with respect to a crime involving moral turpitude, the Board shall order the revocation of a license on the certification by the Office of the Attorney General.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsections (b) and (d) of this section, hospitals, related institutions, alternative health systems as defined in § 1–401 of this article, and employers shall file with the Board a report that the hospital, related institution, alternative health system, or employer limited, reduced, otherwise changed, or terminated any licensed polysomnographic technologist for any reason that might be grounds for disciplinary action under § 14–5C–17 of this subtitle.

A hospital, related institution, alternative health system, or employer that has reason to know that a licensed polysomnographic technologist has committed an action or has a condition that might be grounds for reprimand or probation of the licensed polysomnographic technologist or suspension or revocation of the license because the licensed polysomnographic technologist is alcohol impaired or drug impaired is not required to report the technologist to the Board if:

paragraph.text: The hospital, related institution, alternative health system, or employer knows that the licensed polysomnographic technologist is:

subparagraph.text: In an alcohol or drug treatment program that is accredited by the Joint Commission on Accreditation of Healthcare Organizations or is certified by the Department; or
Under the care of a health care practitioner who is competent and capable of dealing with alcoholism and drug abuse; and
The hospital, related institution, alternative health system, or employer is able to verify that the licensed polysomnographic technologist remains in the treatment program until discharge; and
The action or condition of the licensed polysomnographic technologist has not caused injury to any person while the technologist is practicing as a licensed polysomnographic technologist.

paragraph.text: If the licensed polysomnographic technologist enters, or is considering entering, an alcohol or drug treatment program that is accredited by the Joint Commission on Accreditation of Healthcare Organizations or that is certified by the Department, the licensed polysomnographic technologist shall notify the hospital, related institution, alternative health system, or employer of the licensed polysomnographic technologist’s decision to enter the treatment program.

If the licensed polysomnographic technologist fails to provide the notice required under paragraph (1) of this subsection, and the hospital, related institution, alternative health system, or employer learns that the licensed polysomnographic technologist has entered a treatment program, the hospital, related institution, alternative health system, or employer shall report to the Board that the licensed polysomnographic technologist has entered a treatment program and has failed to provide the required notice.

If the licensed polysomnographic technologist is found to be noncompliant with the treatment program’s policies and procedures while in the treatment program, the treatment program shall notify the hospital, related institution, alternative health system, or employer of the licensed polysomnographic technologist’s noncompliance.

On receipt of the notification required under paragraph (3) of this subsection, the hospital, related institution, alternative health system, or employer of the licensed polysomnographic technologist shall report the licensed polysomnographic technologist’s noncompliance to the Board.

subsection.text: A person is not required under this section to make any report that would be in violation of any federal or state law, rule, or regulation concerning the confidentiality of alcohol and drug abuse patient records.
The hospital, related institution, alternative health system, or employer shall submit the report within 10 days of any action described in this section.
A report made under this section is not subject to subpoena or discovery in any civil action other than a proceeding arising out of a hearing and decision of the Board under this title.

paragraph.text: The Board may impose a civil penalty of up to $1,000 for failure to report under this section.
The Board shall remit any penalty collected under this subsection into the General Fund of the State.

section.text: On the application of an individual whose license has been revoked, the Board, on the affirmative vote of a majority of its full authorized membership, may reinstate a revoked license.

Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, a person may not practice, attempt to practice, or offer to practice polysomnography in this State unless licensed to practice polysomnography by the Board.

subsection.text: Unless authorized to practice polysomnography under this subtitle, a person may not represent to the public by title, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the person is authorized to practice polysomnography in this State.

Unless authorized to practice polysomnography under this subtitle, a person may not use the abbreviation “P.S.G.” or any other words, letters, or symbols with the intent to represent that the person practices polysomnography.

section.text: A person may not provide, attempt to provide, offer to provide, or represent that the person provides polysomnography unless the polysomnography is provided by an individual who is authorized to practice polysomnography under this subtitle.

subsection.text: A person who violates any provision of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.
Any person who violates § 14-5C-21 of this subtitle is subject to a civil fine of not more than $5,000 to be levied by the Board.
The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this section into the Board of Physicians Fund.

section.text: This subtitle may be cited as the “Maryland Polysomnography Act”.

Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act and subject to the termination of this title under § 14–702 of this title, this subtitle and all regulations adopted under this subtitle shall terminate and be of no effect after July 1, 2013.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Alternate supervising physician” means one or more physicians designated by the supervising physician to provide supervision of an athletic trainer:

paragraph.text: During the absence of the supervising physician; and
In accordance with the evaluation and treatment protocol on file with the Board.

subsection.text: “Athlete” means an individual who participates in an athletic activity.
“Athletic activity” means exercise, recreation, sport, competition, or game that:

paragraph.text: Requires physical strength, range of motion, flexibility, control, speed, stamina, or agility; and
Is associated with a setting as defined under this section, an educational institution, or a professional, amateur, or recreational sports club or athletic organization.

subsection.text: “Athletic injury” means an injury that affects an athlete’s participation or performance in an athletic activity.
“Board” means the State Board of Physicians.
“Committee” means the Athletic Trainer Advisory Committee established under § 14–5D–04 of this subtitle.
“Educational institution” includes:

paragraph.text: The schools in the public elementary and secondary education system of the State;
A noncollegiate educational institution governed under § 2–206 of the Education Article; and
An institution of higher education as defined in § 10–101 of the Education Article.

subsection.text: “Evaluation and treatment protocol” means a document that is executed by a physician and an athletic trainer that meets the requirements of § 14–5D–11 of this subtitle.
“License” means a license issued by the Board to practice athletic training.
“Licensed athletic trainer” means an individual who is licensed by the Board to practice athletic training.
“Licensed health care practitioner” means an individual licensed, certified, or otherwise authorized to practice a health occupation under this article.
“National certifying board” means the National Athletic Trainers’ Association Board of Certification, Inc., or its successor organization.
“Nonsupervising physician” means a physician licensed by the Board who is not the supervising physician of the licensed athletic trainer.
“Outside referral” means a request for treatment from a nonsupervising physician or licensed health care practitioner.

paragraph.text: “Practice athletic training” means application of the following principles and methods for managing athletic injuries for athletes in good overall health under the supervision of a licensed physician:

subparagraph.text: Prevention;
Clinical evaluation and assessment;
Immediate care; and
Treatment, rehabilitation, and reconditioning.

paragraph.text: “Practice athletic training” includes:

subparagraph.text: Organization and administration of an athletic training program; and
Instruction to coaches, athletes, parents, medical personnel, and community members regarding the care and prevention of athletic injuries.

paragraph.text: “Practice athletic training” does not include:

subparagraph.text: The practice of:

sub-subparagraph.text: Chiropractic, including adjustments, manipulation, or high velocity mobilizations of the spine or extremities;
Massage therapy;
Medicine;
Occupational therapy;
Physical therapy; or
Podiatry;

subparagraph.text: The reconditioning of systemic neurologic injuries, conditions, or disease; or
Except for the conditioning of an athlete under the supervision of a treating physician, the treatment, rehabilitation, or reconditioning of nonathletic injuries or disease.

subsection.text: “Setting” means a:

paragraph.text: Location where an athletic activity, as defined in subsection (d) of this section, is being held;
Health or fitness club;
Clinic or hospital;
Corporation; or
Government agency.

subsection.text: “Supervising physician” means a physician who has been approved by the Board to supervise one or more athletic trainers.

“Supervision” means the responsibility of a physician to provide ongoing and immediately available instruction, in person, by telephone, or by other electronic means, that is adequate to ensure the safety and welfare of a patient and is appropriate to the setting.

section.text: This subtitle does not limit the right of an individual to practice a health occupation that the individual is authorized to practice under this article.

paragraph.text: The Board shall set reasonable fees for the issuance and renewal of licenses and the other services it provides to athletic trainers.
The fees charged shall be set so as to produce funds to approximate the cost of maintaining the licensure program and the other services provided to athletic trainers.
The Board shall pay all fees collected under the provisions of this subtitle to the Comptroller.
The Comptroller shall distribute all fees to the Board.

subsection.text: The fees shall be used to cover the actual documented direct and indirect costs of fulfilling the statutory and regulatory duties of the Board as provided by the provisions of this subtitle.

section.text: There is an Athletic Trainer Advisory Committee within the Board.

subsection.text: The Committee consists of 11 members appointed by the Board as follows:

subparagraph.text: On or before September 30, 2011, three athletic trainers who:

sub-subparagraph.text: Are certified by a national certifying board; and
Have a minimum of 5 years of clinical experience; and

subparagraph.text: On or after October 1, 2011, three licensed athletic trainers who:

sub-subparagraph.text: Are certified by a national certifying board; and
Have a minimum of 5 years of clinical experience;

paragraph.text: Three licensed physicians:

subparagraph.text: At least one of whom is a specialist in orthopedic or sports medicine; and
Two of whom previously or currently have partnered with or directed an athletic trainer;

paragraph.text: One licensed chiropractor who has sports medicine experience;
One licensed physical therapist;
One licensed occupational therapist; and
Two consumer members.
The athletic trainer members may be appointed by the Board from a list of qualified individuals submitted to the Board by the Maryland Athletic Trainers Association, Inc.
The Board may request an additional list of nominees for each vacancy.

subsection.text: The consumer member of the Committee:

paragraph.text: Shall be a member of the general public;
May not be or ever have been:

subparagraph.text: An athletic trainer;
A health care professional; or
In training to be an athletic trainer or other health professional; and

paragraph.text: May not:

subparagraph.text: Participate or ever have participated in a commercial or professional field related to athletic training;
Have had within 2 years before appointment a financial interest in a person regulated by the Board; or
Have had within 2 years before appointment a financial interest in the provision of goods or services to athletic trainers or to the field of athletic training.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 3 years.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Committee on October 1, 2009.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed.

subsection.text: From among its members, the Committee shall elect a chair every 2 years.

section.text: In addition to the powers set forth elsewhere in this subtitle, the Committee shall:

paragraph.text: Develop and recommend to the Board regulations to carry out this subtitle;
Develop and recommend to the Board continuing education requirements for license renewal;
Provide the Board with recommendations concerning the practice of athletic training;
Develop and recommend to the Board an evaluation and treatment protocol for use by an athletic trainer and the physician with whom the athletic trainer practices;
Provide advice and recommendations to the Board on individual evaluation and treatment protocols when requested; and
Keep a record of its proceedings.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, on or after October 1, 2011, an individual shall be licensed by the Board before the individual may practice athletic training in the State.
This section does not apply to:

paragraph.text: An individual employed by the federal government as an athletic trainer while the individual is practicing within the scope of that employment;
An individual employed by or under contract with an entity located in another state who represents that entity:

subparagraph.text: At an athletic event in the State;
For a period of time not to exceed 45 days within a calendar year; and
By providing athletic training services to individuals representing the entity at the event; or

paragraph.text: A student enrolled in an education program that meets the criteria of § 14–5D–08(c)(2) of this subtitle while engaged in an unpaid, clinical educational experience of athletic training.

subsection.text: To qualify for a license, an applicant shall be an individual who meets the requirements of this section.
The applicant shall:

paragraph.text: Be of good moral character; and
Be at least 18 years old.

subsection.text: The applicant shall:

paragraph.text: Have a current certification by a national certifying board approved by the Board;
Have received a bachelor’s or master’s degree from an athletic training educational program that is accredited by the Commission on Accreditation of Athletic Training Education or its successor;
Demonstrate oral and written competency in English as required by the Board; and
Meet any other requirements established by the Board.

subsection.text: The Board shall waive the education requirements under this section if an individual was certified by the National Athletic Trainers’ Association Board of Certification, Inc., on or before October 1, 2012, and is currently in good standing.
To apply for a license, an applicant shall:

paragraph.text: Submit an application to the Board on the form that the Board requires; and
Pay to the Board the application fee set by the Board.

subsection.text: The Board shall issue the appropriate license to an applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle for that license.
An athletic trainer license authorizes the licensee to practice athletic training services in an approved setting while the license is effective.
A licensed athletic trainer shall practice athletic training in accordance with the evaluation and treatment protocol between the athletic trainer and a licensed physician.
Nothing in this title may be construed to authorize an athletic trainer to practice except under the supervision of a licensed physician and in an approved setting.
Before an athletic trainer may practice athletic training, the athletic trainer shall:

paragraph.text: Obtain a license under this subtitle;
Enter into a written evaluation and treatment protocol with a licensed physician; and
Obtain Board approval of the evaluation and treatment protocol.

subsection.text: An evaluation and treatment protocol shall:

paragraph.text: Describe the qualifications of the licensed physician and licensed athletic trainer;
Describe the settings where the athletic trainer may practice;
Describe the physician supervision mechanisms that the physician will use to give direction to the athletic trainer;
Specify the treatment procedures the athletic trainer may perform;
Describe tasks the athletic trainer may not perform;

Describe specialized tasks the supervising physician is delegating to the athletic trainer to perform with documentation of competencies, certification, credentials, or any other requirements established by the Board to support the delegation of the specialized tasks;
Indicate whether the athletic trainer may accept outside referrals from nonsupervising physicians and other licensed health care practitioners;
Designate an alternate supervising physician, if appropriate or necessary; and

Contain an attestation that states the supervising physician will be responsible for providing ongoing and immediately available instruction that is adequate to ensure the safety and welfare of a patient and is appropriate to the setting.

subsection.text: An athletic trainer may accept an outside referral from a nonsupervising physician or licensed health care practitioner if:

paragraph.text: The supervising physician specifies in the evaluation and treatment protocol that the athletic trainer may accept referrals from a nonsupervising physician or licensed health care practitioner;
The nonsupervising physician or licensed health care practitioner has seen the athlete and has written an order for the care of the athlete; and
The treatment procedures to be used by the athletic trainer are:

subparagraph.text: Within the scope of practice of an athletic trainer; and
Included in the evaluation and treatment protocol that the athletic trainer has entered into with the supervising physician.

subsection.text: In the event of a sudden departure, incapacity, or death of a supervising physician, a designated alternate supervising physician may assume the role of the supervising physician by submitting an evaluation and treatment protocol to the Board within 15 days of the event.

Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, a licensed physician may not employ or supervise an individual practicing athletic training without a license or without an approved evaluation and treatment protocol.

Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, a hospital, an institution, an alternative health system, or any other employer may not employ an individual practicing athletic training without a license or without an approved evaluation and treatment protocol.
The Board may impose a civil penalty of up to $1,000 on a person who employs or supervises an individual without a license or without an approved evaluation and treatment protocol.
A physician or an employer shall notify the Board within 10 days of the termination of an athletic trainer for reasons that would be grounds for discipline under this subtitle.
A supervising physician and an athletic trainer shall notify the Board of the termination of the relationship under an evaluation and treatment protocol.
A license expires on a date set by the Board, unless the license is renewed for an additional term as provided in this section.
At least 1 month before a license expires, the Board shall send to the licensee a renewal notice that states:

paragraph.text: The date on which the current license expires;
The date by which the renewal application must be received by the Board for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the license expires; and
The amount of the renewal fee.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, before a license expires, the licensee periodically may renew it for an additional term, if the licensee:

paragraph.text: Otherwise is entitled to be licensed;
Pays to the Board a renewal fee set by the Board; and
Submits to the Board:

subparagraph.text: A renewal application on the form that the Board requires;
Satisfactory evidence of compliance with any continuing education or competency requirements; and
Any other requirements set under this section for license renewal.

subsection.text: In addition to any other qualifications and requirements established by the Board, the Board may establish continuing education or competency requirements as a condition of the renewal of licenses under this section.
The Board shall renew the license of each licensee who meets the requirements of this section.
The Board shall reinstate the license of an athletic trainer who has failed to renew the license for any reason if the athletic trainer:

paragraph.text: Applies for reinstatement;
Meets renewal and reinstatement requirements; and
Pays to the Board the reinstatement fee set by the Board.

subsection.text: The Board may impose a civil penalty of up to $100 per continuing education credit in lieu of a sanction under § 14–5D–14 of this subtitle, for a first offense for failure of a licensee to obtain the continuing education credits required by the Board.
A licensee shall notify the Board in writing of a change in name or address within 60 days after the change.
A licensee who fails to comply with subsection (a) of this section is subject to an administrative penalty of $100.

section.text: Unless the Board agrees to accept the surrender of a license, a licensed athletic trainer may not surrender the license nor may the license lapse by operation of law while the licensee is under investigation or while charges are pending against the licensee.

subsection.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 14–405 of this title, the Board may deny a license to any applicant, reprimand any licensee, place any licensee on probation, or suspend or revoke a license if the applicant or licensee:

paragraph.text: Fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a license for the applicant, licensee, or for another;
Fraudulently or deceptively uses a license;
Is guilty of unprofessional or immoral conduct in the practice of athletic training;
Is professionally, physically, or mentally incompetent;
Abandons a patient;
Habitually is intoxicated;
Is addicted to, or habitually abuses, any narcotic or controlled dangerous substance as defined in § 5–101 of the Criminal Law Article;
Provides professional services while:

subparagraph.text: Under the influence of alcohol; or
Using any narcotic or controlled dangerous substance as defined in § 5–101 of the Criminal Law Article, or any other drug that is in excess of therapeutic amounts or without valid medical indication;

paragraph.text: Promotes the sale of services, drugs, devices, appliances, or goods to a patient so as to exploit the patient for financial gain;
Willfully makes or files a false report or record in the practice of athletic training;
Willfully fails to file or record any report as required under law, willfully impedes or obstructs the filing or recording of the report, or induces another to fail to file or record the report;
Breaches patient confidentiality;

Pays or agrees to pay any sum or provide any form of remuneration or material benefit to any individual for bringing or referring a patient or accepts or agrees to accept any sum or any form of remuneration or material benefit from an individual for bringing or referring a patient;
Knowingly makes a misrepresentation while practicing athletic training;
Knowingly practices athletic training with an unauthorized individual or aids an unauthorized individual in the practice of athletic trainer services;
Offers, undertakes, or agrees to cure or treat disease by a secret method, treatment, or medicine;

Is disciplined by a licensing, certifying, or disciplinary authority or is convicted or disciplined by a court of any state or country or is disciplined by any branch of the United States uniformed services or the Veterans Administration for an act that would be grounds for disciplinary action under this section;
Fails to meet appropriate standards for the delivery of athletic training services;
Knowingly submits false statements to collect fees for which services have not been provided;

subparagraph.text: Has been subject to investigation or disciplinary action by a licensing or disciplinary authority or by a court of any state or country for an act that would be grounds for disciplinary action under the Board’s disciplinary statutes; and
The licensed individual:

sub-subparagraph.text: Surrendered the license issued by the state or country; or
Allowed the license issued by the state or country to expire or lapse;

paragraph.text: Knowingly fails to report suspected child abuse in violation of § 5–704 of the Family Law Article;
Sells, prescribes, gives away, or administers drugs for illegal or illegitimate medical purposes;
Practices or attempts to practice beyond the authorized scope of practice;

Refuses, withholds from, denies, or discriminates against an individual with regard to the provision of professional services for which the licensee is licensed and qualified to render because the individual is HIV positive;

Practices or attempts to practice an athletic training procedure or uses or attempts to use athletic training equipment if the applicant or licensee has not received education and training in the performance of the procedure or the use of the equipment;
Fails to cooperate with a lawful investigation conducted by the Board;
Fails to practice under the supervision of a physician or violates the approved evaluation and treatment protocol; or
Violates an order of the Board, including any condition of probation.

On the filing of certified docket entries with the Board by the Office of the Attorney General, the Board shall order the suspension of a license if the licensee is convicted of or pleads guilty or nolo contendere with respect to a crime involving moral turpitude, whether or not any appeal or other proceeding is pending to have the conviction or plea set aside.

After completion of the appellate process, if the conviction has not been reversed or the plea has not been set aside with respect to a crime involving moral turpitude, the Board shall order the revocation of a license on the certification by the Office of the Attorney General.

Except as otherwise provided in § 10–226 of the State Government Article, before the Board takes any action under § 14–5D–14 of this subtitle, it shall give the individual against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before a hearing officer.
The hearing officer shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2, of the State Government Article.
The Board may administer oaths in connection with any proceedings under this section.
At least 14 days before the hearing, a hearing notice shall be sent by certified mail to the last known address of the individual.
Any person aggrieved by a final decision of the Board under this subtitle may not appeal to the Secretary or Board of Review but may take a direct judicial appeal.
The appeal shall be made as provided for judicial review of final decisions in the Administrative Procedure Act.

subsection.text: An order of the Board may not be stayed pending review.
The Board may appeal from any decision that reverses or modifies its order.

section.text: On the application of an individual whose license has been revoked, the Board may reinstate a revoked license.
Unless authorized to practice athletic training under this subtitle, a person may not:

paragraph.text: Practice athletic training in this State;
Attempt to practice or offer to practice athletic training in this State;
Represent to the public by title, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the person is authorized to practice athletic training in this State; or
Use the abbreviation “A.T.”, “A.T.L.”, “L.A.T.”, or any other words, letters, or symbols with the intent to represent that the person practices athletic training.

subsection.text: A person who violates any provision of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.
Any person who violates any provision of this subtitle is subject to a civil fine of not more than $5,000 to be levied by the Board.
The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this section into the Board of Physicians Fund.

section.text: This subtitle may be cited as the “Maryland Athletic Trainers Act”.

Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act and subject to the termination of this title under § 14–702 of this title, this subtitle and all rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle shall terminate and be of no effect after July 1, 2013.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the State Board of Physicians.
“Committee” means the Perfusion Advisory Committee established under § 14–5E–05 of this subtitle.
“License” means a license issued by the Board to practice perfusion.
“Licensed perfusionist” means a perfusionist who is licensed by the Board under this subtitle to practice perfusion.

paragraph.text: “Practice perfusion” means to perform the functions necessary for the support, treatment, measurement, or supplementation of the cardiovascular, circulatory, or respiratory systems, or other organs to ensure the safe management of physiologic functions by monitoring and analyzing the parameters of the systems under an order and the supervision of a licensed physician.
“Practice perfusion” includes:

subparagraph.text: Cardiopulmonary bypass for adult, pediatric, and neonatal patients;
Extracorporeal circulatory support for renal, neurological, hepatic, and vascular surgery;
Extracorporeal resuscitation;
Extracorporeal circulation for long–term support of failing respiratory or cardiac function;
Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation;
Extracorporeal carbon dioxide removal;
Myocardial protection;
Perfusion–assisted direct coronary artery bypass;
Hemofiltration and hemodialysis;
Anticoagulation and hemostasis monitoring, analysis, and intervention;
Thermal regulation;
Blood gas and blood chemistry monitoring, analysis, and intervention;
Physiological monitoring, analysis, and intervention;
Administration of blood components and pharmaceuticals;
Administration of anesthetic agents through a heart lung machine at the direction of an anesthesiologist;
Ventricular assist device and mechanical circulatory support management;
Intra–aortic balloon counterpulsation;
Temporary pacemaker management;
Periodic flow augmentation therapy;
Autotransfusion;
Platelet gel production, autologous hemocyte tissue matrix production;
Nondifferentiated progenitor cell harvest bone marrow aspirate concentrate;
Acute normovolemic hemodilution;
Isolated limb or organ delivery of chemotherapeutics, progenitor cells, gene therapy vectors, and other items;
Organ procurement and preservation;
Thermogenic lavage;
Electrophysiological analysis;
Therapeutic hyperthermia;
Intravascular membrane oxygenation; and
Renal perfusion.

subsection.text: “Student” means an individual who, in accordance with § 14–5E–09(c) of this subtitle, is:

paragraph.text: Enrolled in an accredited educational program to qualify for a license under this subtitle; and
Performing perfusion services within the accredited program under the supervision of a licensed perfusionist and without compensation.

subsection.text: “Supervision” means the responsibility of a licensed physician to exercise on site or immediately available direction for a licensed perfusionist to ensure the safety and welfare of patients during the course of perfusion.

section.text: This subtitle does not limit the right of an individual to practice a health occupation that the individual is authorized to practice under this article.
The Board shall adopt regulations for the licensure and practice of perfusion.

paragraph.text: The Board shall set reasonable fees for the issuance and renewal of licenses and other services it provides to perfusionists.
The fees charged shall be set so as to produce funds to approximate the cost of maintaining the licensure program and the other services provided to perfusionists.
The Board shall pay all fees collected under the provisions of this subtitle to the Comptroller.
The Comptroller shall distribute all fees to the Board.

subsection.text: The fees shall be used to cover the actual documented direct and indirect costs of fulfilling the statutory and regulatory duties of the Board as provided by the provisions of this subtitle.

section.text: There is a Perfusion Advisory Committee within the Board.

subsection.text: The Committee consists of seven members, appointed by the Board as follows:

subparagraph.text: On or before September 30, 2013, three individuals who practice perfusion and who:

sub-subparagraph.text: Are certified by a national certifying board; and
Have a minimum of 2 years experience; and

subparagraph.text: On or after October 1, 2013, three licensed perfusionists;

paragraph.text: Three physicians, at least one of whom performs cardiac or cardio–thoracic surgery; and
One consumer member.

subsection.text: The consumer member of the Committee:

paragraph.text: Shall be a member of the general public;
May not practice or ever have practiced perfusion or any health care profession;
May not be or ever have been in training to practice perfusion or any other health care profession;
May not have a household member who is a health care professional or is in training to be a health care professional; and
May not:

subparagraph.text: Participate or ever have participated in a commercial or professional field related to perfusion;
Have a household member who participates in a commercial or professional field related to perfusion;
Have had within 2 years before appointment a financial interest in a person regulated by the Board; or
Have had within 2 years before appointment a financial interest in the provision of goods or services to perfusionists or to the field of perfusion.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 3 years.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Committee on October 1, 2012.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: From among its members, the Committee shall elect a chair every 2 years.

section.text: In addition to the powers set forth elsewhere in this subtitle, the Committee shall:

paragraph.text: Develop and recommend to the Board:

subparagraph.text: Regulations to carry out the provisions of this subtitle;
A code of ethics for the practice of perfusion for adoption by the Board;
Recommendations concerning the practice of perfusion, including standards of care for the practice of perfusion; and
Continuing education requirements for license renewal; and

paragraph.text: Keep a record of its proceedings.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, on or after October 1, 2013, an individual shall be licensed by the Board before the individual may practice perfusion in this State.
This section does not apply to a student enrolled in an education program under § 14–5E–09(c)(2) of this subtitle while practicing perfusion in that program.
To qualify for a license, an applicant shall be an individual who meets the requirements of this section.
The applicant shall:

paragraph.text: Be of good moral character; and
Be at least 18 years old.

subsection.text: An applicant for a license to practice perfusion shall:

subparagraph.text: Submit to the Board satisfactory evidence of certification as a certified perfusionist or other national certification approved by the Board; and
Meet any other educational or clinical requirements established by the Committee and approved by the Board; or

Submit to the Board satisfactory evidence of graduation from a perfusion educational program that is accredited by the Committee on Accreditation of Allied Health Education Programs, or the Committee’s predecessor or successor; and
Meet any other educational or clinical requirements established by the Committee and approved by the Board.

section.text: An applicant who otherwise qualifies for a license under § 14–5E–09(c)(2) of this subtitle is entitled to be licensed for a single 2–year term before taking the national certifying examination given by the American Board of Cardiovascular Perfusion or its successor organization or another examination given or approved by the Board.

subsection.text: To apply for a license, an applicant shall:

paragraph.text: Submit an application to the Board on the form that the Board requires; and
Pay to the Board the application fee set by the Board.

subsection.text: The Board shall issue a license to an applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle.

section.text: A license authorizes an individual to practice perfusion in this State while the license is effective.

paragraph.text: A license expires on a date set by the Board, unless the license is renewed for an additional term as provided in this section.
A license may not be renewed for a term longer than 2 years.

subsection.text: At least 1 month before a license expires, the Board shall send to the licensed perfusionist a renewal notice that states:

paragraph.text: The date on which the current license expires;
The date by which the renewal application must be received by the Board for the renewal to be issued and sent before the license expires;
The amount of the renewal fee; and

For licensees who qualified for an initial license under § 14–5E–09(c)(2) of this subtitle, that the licensee must submit satisfactory evidence of a passing score on the examination as required under subsection (c)(2) of this section.
Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, before a license expires, the licensed perfusionist periodically may renew it for an additional term, if the licensee:

subparagraph.text: Otherwise is entitled to be licensed;
Pays to the Board a renewal fee set by the Board; and
Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, submits to the Board:

sub-subparagraph.text: A renewal application on the form that the Board requires; and
Satisfactory evidence of compliance with any continuing education or competency requirements and other requirements set under this section for license renewal.

paragraph.text: A licensee who qualified for an initial license under § 14–5E–09(c)(2) of this subtitle shall submit to the Board satisfactory evidence of a passing score on the national certifying examination given by the American Board of Cardiovascular Perfusion or its successor organization or another examination given or approved by the Board.

subsection.text: In addition to any other qualifications and requirements established by the Board, the Board shall establish continuing education or competency requirements as a condition of the renewal of a license under this section.

paragraph.text: The Board shall renew the license of each licensee who meets the requirements of this section.
The Board may not renew the license of a licensee who fails to submit satisfactory evidence of a passing score on the examination as required under subsection (c)(2) of this section.

subsection.text: The Board shall reinstate the license of an individual who has not been placed on inactive status but has failed to renew the license for any reason if the individual:

paragraph.text: Applies for reinstatement within 30 days after the date the license expires;
Meets the renewal requirements of this section; and
Pays to the Board the reinstatement fee set by the Board.
A licensed perfusionist shall notify the Board in writing of a change in name or address within 60 days after the change.
A licensed perfusionist who fails to comply with the requirements of paragraph (1) of this subsection is subject to an administrative penalty of $100.

subsection.text: Each licensed perfusionist shall display the license conspicuously in the office or place of employment of the licensee.

section.text: Unless the Board agrees to accept the surrender of a license, a licensed perfusionist may not surrender the license nor may the license lapse by operation of law while the licensee is under investigation or while charges are pending against the licensee.

subsection.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 14–405 of this title, the Board may deny a license to any applicant, reprimand any licensee, place any licensee on probation, or suspend or revoke a license if the applicant or licensee:

paragraph.text: Fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a license for the applicant or licensee or for another;
Fraudulently or deceptively uses a license;
Is guilty of unprofessional or immoral conduct in the practice of perfusion;
Is professionally, physically, or mentally incompetent;
Abandons a patient;
Is habitually intoxicated;
Is addicted to or habitually abuses any narcotic or controlled dangerous substance as defined in § 5–101 of the Criminal Law Article;
Provides professional services while:

subparagraph.text: Under the influence of alcohol; or
Using any narcotic or controlled dangerous substance as defined in § 5–101 of the Criminal Law Article or any other drug that is in excess of therapeutic amounts or without valid medical indication;

paragraph.text: Promotes the sale of services, drugs, devices, appliances, or goods to a patient so as to exploit the patient for financial gain;
Willfully makes or files a false report or record in the practice of perfusion;
Willfully fails to file or record any report as required under law, willfully impedes or obstructs the filing or recording of a report, or induces another to fail to file or record a report;
Breaches patient confidentiality;

Pays or agrees to pay any sum or provide any form of remuneration or material benefit to any person for bringing or referring a patient or accepts or agrees to accept any sum or any form of remuneration or material benefit from an individual for bringing or referring a patient;
Knowingly makes a misrepresentation while practicing perfusion;
Knowingly practices perfusion with an unauthorized individual or aids an unauthorized individual in the practice of perfusion;
Knowingly delegates a perfusion duty to an unlicensed individual;
Offers, undertakes, or agrees to cure or treat disease by a secret method, treatment, or medicine;

Is disciplined by a licensing or disciplinary authority or is convicted or disciplined by a court of any state or country or is disciplined by any branch of the United States uniformed services or the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs for an act that would be grounds for disciplinary action under the Board’s disciplinary statutes;
Fails to meet appropriate standards for the delivery of perfusion services;
