Fails to comply with the requirements of any order entered by the Board as a result of any disciplinary matter with the Board, including payment of costs as required by § 19-312 of this subtitle; or
Fails to maintain adequate patient records.

subsection.text: If after a hearing under § 19-312 of this subtitle the Board finds that there are grounds under § 19-311 of this subtitle to reprimand a licensee, place a licensee on probation, or suspend or revoke a license, the Board may impose a fine on the licensee in an amount not exceeding $5,000:

paragraph.text: Instead of reprimanding the licensee, placing the licensee on probation, or suspending or revoking the social worker’s license; or
In addition to reprimanding the licensee, placing the licensee on probation, or suspending or revoking the social worker’s license.

subsection.text: The Board shall adopt regulations to set standards for the imposition of fines under this section.
The Board shall pay any fine collected under this section into the General Fund.

Except as otherwise provided in the Administrative Procedure Act, before the Board takes any action under § 19-311 of this subtitle, it shall give the individual against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Board.
The Board shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with the Administrative Procedure Act.

Over the signature of an officer or the administrator of the Board, the Board may issue subpoenas and administer oaths in connection with any investigation under this title and any hearings or proceedings before it.

If, without lawful excuse, a person disobeys a subpoena from the Board or an order by the Board to take an oath or to testify or answer a question, then, on petition of the Board, a court of competent jurisdiction may punish the person as for contempt of court.
If after due notice the individual against whom the action is contemplated fails or refuses to appear, nevertheless the Board may hear and determine the matter.
If, after a hearing, an individual is found in violation of § 19-311 of this subtitle, the individual shall pay the costs of the hearing as specified in a regulation adopted by the Board.

Except as provided in this section for an action under § 19-311 of this subtitle, any person aggrieved by a final decision of the Board in a contested case, as defined in the Administrative Procedure Act, may:

paragraph.text: Appeal that decision to the Board of Review; and
Then take any further appeal allowed by the Administrative Procedure Act.
Any person aggrieved by a final decision of the Board under § 19-311 of this subtitle may not appeal to the Secretary or Board of Review but may take a direct judicial appeal.
The appeal shall be made as provided for judicial review of final decisions in the Administrative Procedure Act.

subsection.text: If a license has been suspended or revoked under § 19-311 of this subtitle, the Board may reinstate that license only in accordance with:

paragraph.text: The terms and conditions of the order of suspension or revocation; or
An order of reinstatement issued by the Board.

subsection.text: If a licensee has failed for any reason to renew the license for a period of less than 5 years, the Board shall reinstate the license if the social worker:

paragraph.text: Applies to the Board for reinstatement of the license;
Meets the continuing education requirements of § 19-308 of this subtitle for each 2-year period that the license was not renewed; and
Pays to the Board the reinstatement fee set by the Board.

subsection.text: If a licensee has failed for any reason to renew the license for a period of 5 years or more, the social worker shall meet the current requirements for licensure.
In this section, “social worker rehabilitation committee” means a committee that:

paragraph.text: Is defined in subsection (b) of this section; and
Performs any of the functions listed in subsection (d) of this section.

subsection.text: For purposes of this section, a social worker rehabilitation committee is a committee of the Board or a committee with representatives from one or more professional social work organizations that:

paragraph.text: Is recognized by the Board; and
Includes but is not limited to social workers.

subsection.text: A rehabilitation committee of the Board or recognized by the Board may function to assist persons referred:

paragraph.text: Solely by the Board;
Jointly with a rehabilitation committee representing another board or boards; or
By the licensee.

subsection.text: For purposes of this section, the social worker rehabilitation committee:

paragraph.text: Evaluates and provides assistance to any social worker, and any other individual regulated by the Board, in need of treatment and rehabilitation for alcoholism, substance abuse or dependency, or other physical, emotional, or mental condition; and
Provides information and resources to address impairment.

Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, the proceedings, records, and files of the social worker rehabilitation committee are not discoverable and are not admissible in evidence in any civil action arising out of matters that are being or have been reviewed and evaluated by the social worker rehabilitation committee.

Paragraph (1) of this subsection does not apply to any record or document that is considered by the social worker rehabilitation committee and that otherwise would be subject to discovery or introduction into evidence in a civil action.
For purposes of this subsection, civil action does not include a proceeding before the Board or judicial review of a proceeding before the Board.

subsection.text: A person who acts in good faith and within the scope of jurisdiction of the social worker rehabilitation committee is not civilly liable for any action as a member of the social worker rehabilitation committee or for giving information to, participating in, or contributing to the function of the social worker rehabilitation committee.
An action may be maintained in the name of the State or the Board to enjoin:

paragraph.text: The unauthorized practice of social work; or
Conduct that is a ground for disciplinary action under § 19-311 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: An action under this section may be brought by:

paragraph.text: The Board, in its own name;
The Attorney General, in the name of the State; or
A State’s Attorney, in the name of the State.

subsection.text: An action under this section shall be brought in the county where the defendant:

paragraph.text: Resides; or
Engages in the act sought to be enjoined.

subsection.text: Proof of actual damage or that any person will sustain any damage if an injunction is not granted is not required for an action under this section.

An action under this section is in addition to and not instead of criminal prosecution for unauthorized practice of social work under § 19-401 of this title or disciplinary action under § 19-311 of this subtitle.

While investigating an allegation against a licensee under this title, the Board may require the licensee to submit to an appropriate examination by a health care provider designated by the Board if the Board has reason to believe that the licensee may cause harm to a person.
In return for the privilege given to a licensee to practice social work in the State, the licensee is deemed to have:

paragraph.text: Consented to submit to an examination under this section, if requested by the Board in writing; and
Waived any claim of privilege as to the testimony or report of a health care provider who examines the licensee.

subsection.text: The failure or refusal of the licensee to submit to an examination required under this section is prima facie evidence of the licensee’s inability to practice social work competently, unless the Board finds that the failure or refusal was beyond the control of the licensee.
The Board shall pay the cost of any examination made under this section.
Before a licensee in a private individual, partnership, or group practice provides social work services to a client, the licensee shall provide to the client the following disclosures:

paragraph.text: The licensee’s professional identity;
The services which are or may be provided by the licensee and the fees for each service or the hourly rate; and
Sufficient information for a patient to give informed consent regarding the nature of the services to be provided.

subsection.text: The manner of providing these disclosures shall be as follows:

paragraph.text: The licensee’s professional identity may be provided by business card or display of license in a conspicuous location;
The licensee’s services and fees may be provided by documented discussion or printed fee schedule; and
Informed consent may be provided by documented discussion or a written form signed by the client which is kept in the client’s file.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, a person may not practice, attempt to practice, or offer to practice social work in this State while representing oneself to be a social worker unless licensed by the Board.

Except as otherwise provided in this title, a person may not practice, attempt to practice, or offer to practice clinical social work in this State unless licensed by the Board as a certified social worker-clinical.

section.text: Unless authorized to practice social work under this title, a person may not:

paragraph.text: Represent to the public that the person is a licensed social worker; or

Use any title, abbreviation, sign, card, or other representation that the person is a licensed social worker, including the use of the words “social worker” or “social work” and the use of the abbreviations “LSWA”, “LGSW”, “LCSW”, or “LCSW-C”.

section.text: A person may not intentionally:

paragraph.text: Use or attempt to use the license of another person who is a licensed social worker; or
Impersonate another person who is a licensed social worker.

section.text: In an attempt to obtain a license, a person may not intentionally give false information to the Board.
A person who violates any provision of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $500 or imprisonment not exceeding 90 days.
This title may be cited as the “Maryland Social Workers Act”.

Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Program Evaluation Act, this title and all rules and regulations adopted under this title shall terminate and be of no effect after July 1, 2024.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Agency” means:

subparagraph.text: The Developmental Disabilities Administration in the Department;
The Department;
The Department of Human Resources;
The Department of Juvenile Services; and
The Mental Hygiene Administration in the Department.

paragraph.text: “Agency” includes the State Superintendent of Schools.

subsection.text: “Board” means the State Board for Certification of Residential Child Care Program Professionals.
“Certificate” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a certificate issued by the Board to practice as a program administrator or as a residential child and youth care practitioner.
“Certified program administrator” means, unless the context requires otherwise, an individual who is certified by the Board to practice as a program administrator.

“Certified residential child and youth care practitioner” means, unless the context requires otherwise, an individual who is certified by the Board to practice as a residential child and youth care practitioner.

“Program administrator” means the individual responsible for the day–to–day management and operation of a residential child care program and for assuring the care, treatment, safety, and protection of the children in the residential child care program.

paragraph.text: “Residential child and youth care practitioner” means an individual assigned to perform direct responsibilities related to activities of daily living, self–help, and socialization skills in a residential child care program under the direction of a certified program administrator.

“Residential child and youth care practitioner” does not include an individual assigned to perform direct responsibilities related to activities of daily living, self–help, and socialization skills in a residential child care program licensed by the Developmental Disabilities Administration.

“Residential child care program” means an entity that provides for children 24–hour per day care within a structured set of services and activities that are designed to achieve specific objectives relative to the needs of the children served and that include the provision of food, clothing, shelter, education, social services, health, mental health, recreation, or any combination of these services and activities.
“Residential child care program” includes a program:

subparagraph.text: Licensed by:

sub-subparagraph.text: The Department of Health and Mental Hygiene;
The Department of Human Resources; or
The Department of Juvenile Services; and

subparagraph.text: That is subject to the licensing regulations of the Governor’s Office for Children governing the operations of residential child care programs.

section.text: There is a State Board for Certification of Residential Child Care Program Professionals in the Department.

paragraph.text: The Board consists of 12 members.
Of the 12 Board members:

subparagraph.text: Six members shall be appointed as follows:

sub-subparagraph.text: Two by the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene, one each for the Developmental Disabilities Administration and the Mental Hygiene Administration;
One by the Secretary of Juvenile Services for the agency;
One by the Secretary of Human Resources for the agency;
One by the State Superintendent of Schools; and
One by the Subcabinet; and

subparagraph.text: Six shall be appointed by the Governor.

paragraph.text: Of the six appointed by the Governor:

subparagraph.text: Three shall be program administrators;
One shall be a residential child and youth care practitioner; and
Two shall be consumer members.

subsection.text: The Governor shall appoint members with the advice and consent of the Senate.
Each Board member shall:

paragraph.text: Be a United States citizen; and
Have resided in this State for at least 1 year before appointment to the Board.

subsection.text: A consumer member of the Board:

paragraph.text: May not be a program administrator or a residential child and youth care practitioner;
May not have a household member who is a program administrator or a residential child and youth care practitioner;
May not have a household member who participates in a commercial or professional field related to administering a program; and
May not have had within 2 years before appointment a substantial financial interest in a program regulated by an agency.

subsection.text: While a member of the Board, a consumer member may not have a substantial financial interest in a program regulated by an agency.
Before taking office, each appointee to the Board shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 4 years.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on October 1, 2004.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member may not serve more than two consecutive full terms.
To the extent practicable, the Governor shall fill any vacancy on the Board within 60 days of the date of the vacancy.
The Governor may remove a member for incompetence, misconduct, incapacity, or neglect of duty.
On the recommendation of the Children’s Cabinet, the Governor may remove a member whom the Children’s Cabinet finds to have been absent from two successive Board meetings without adequate reason.

subsection.text: From among its members, the Board annually shall elect a chairman, vice chairman, and executive secretary.
The Board shall determine:

paragraph.text: The manner of election of officers;
The term of office of each officer; and
The duties of each officer.

subsection.text: A majority of the full authorized membership of the Board is a quorum.
The Board shall meet at least twice a year, at the times and places that it determines.
Each member of the Board is entitled to reimbursement for expenses at a rate determined by the Board.
The Board may employ staff in accordance with the budget of the Board.
The Board may appoint an executive director.
The executive director:

paragraph.text: Serves at the pleasure of the Board;
Serves as the executive officer of the Board; and
Has the powers and duties assigned by the Board.

subsection.text: In addition to the powers and duties set forth elsewhere in this title, the Board in consultation with the Children’s Cabinet shall:

paragraph.text: Adopt regulations to carry out the provisions of this subtitle;
Establish standards for the certification of applicants;
Conduct a continuing study and investigation of program administrators and residential child and youth care practitioners to improve:

subparagraph.text: Certification standards; and
Procedures for enforcing these standards;

paragraph.text: Establish a tiered certification structure for residential child and youth care practitioners; and
Devise examinations and adopt investigative procedures to:

subparagraph.text: Determine whether program administrators and residential child and youth care practitioners meet the standards adopted by the Board; and
Assure that program administrators and residential child and youth care practitioners continue to meet these standards.

subsection.text: In addition to the duties set forth elsewhere in this title, the Board shall:

paragraph.text: Maintain a registry of all program administrators and residential child and youth care practitioners certified by the Board;
Submit an annual report to the Governor and Children’s Cabinet;
Adopt a code of ethics that the Board considers appropriate and applicable to the program administrators and residential child and youth care practitioners certified by the Board;
Establish continuing education requirements for the program administrators certified by the Board;
Establish training and continuing education requirements for the residential child and youth care practitioners certified by the Board;
Adopt an official seal; and
Create committees as it deems appropriate to advise the Board on special issues.

subsection.text: The Board:

paragraph.text: Shall set reasonable fees for:

subparagraph.text: The issuance and renewal of certificates;
Approving training programs for residential child and youth care practitioners; and
Its other services;

paragraph.text: May waive the fees, based on demonstrated need, as determined by the Board; and
May not require fees for the examination of qualified certified residential child and youth care practitioner applicants under this title.

subsection.text: The Board shall pay all money collected under this title into the General Fund of the State.

section.text: A person shall have the immunity from liability described under § 5-710 of the Courts Article for giving information to the Board or otherwise participating in its activities.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, on or after October 1, 2007, an individual shall receive a certificate from the Board before the individual may be a program administrator in this State.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, if a program administrator leaves or is removed from a position as program administrator by death or for any other unexpected cause, the owner of a residential child care program or other appropriate program authority shall immediately designate a certified program administrator to serve in that capacity.

sub-subparagraph.text: In the event a certified program administrator is not available, the owner or other appropriate program authority may appoint a noncertified person to serve in the capacity of acting program administrator for a period not to exceed 180 days.

The owner or other appropriate program authority shall immediately notify the Board of the appointment and forward the credentials of the person appointed to the Board for evaluation to assure that the person appointed is experienced, trained, and competent.
The 180–day period begins on the date that the program administrator leaves or is removed from the position as a program administrator.
The Board may extend the 180–day period for a further period of not more than 30 days.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, on or before October 1, 2015, an individual shall receive a certificate from the Board before the individual may be a residential child and youth care practitioner in this State.
This subsection does not apply to:

subparagraph.text: An employee of the Maryland School for the Blind who is a residential child and youth care practitioner and holds a current paraprofessional certificate; or
For up to 180 days, an individual participating in a Board–approved training program.

subsection.text: To qualify for a certificate as a program administrator, an applicant shall be an individual who meets the requirements of this section.
The applicant shall be of good moral character.
The applicant shall have completed a State and national criminal history records check.
The applicant shall be at least 21 years old.
The applicant shall have:

subparagraph.text: A bachelor’s degree from an accredited college or university; and
At least 4 years experience in the human service field with at least 3 years in a supervisory or administrative capacity; or
A master’s degree from an accredited college or university; and
At least 2 years experience in the human service field with at least 1 year in a supervisory or administrative capacity.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, the applicant shall pass an examination given by the Board under this subtitle.
To qualify for a certificate as a residential child and youth care practitioner, an applicant shall be an individual who meets the requirements of this section.
The applicant shall be of good moral character.
The applicant shall have completed a State and national criminal history records check.
The applicant shall be:

paragraph.text: At least 21 years old; or
At least 18 years old and have earned at least an associate’s or bachelor’s degree from an accredited college or university.

subsection.text: The applicant shall have:

paragraph.text: A high school diploma or equivalent and have successfully completed an approved training program;
At least 2 years experience in the human service field and sponsorship from a certified program administrator; or
An associate’s or bachelor’s degree from an accredited college or university.
Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the applicant shall have successfully completed a training program approved under § 20–302.2 of this subtitle.

subparagraph.text: An applicant who has an associate’s or bachelor’s degree from an accredited college or university may be waived from the training program requirement, if the applicant passes an examination and meets other requirements established by the Board under this subtitle.
The Board shall establish requirements and procedures for waiving the training program requirement for an applicant under subparagraph (i) of this paragraph.

subsection.text: The applicant shall pass an examination given by the Board under this subtitle.
The Board shall waive the education, experience, training, and examination requirements of this section for an applicant who:

paragraph.text: Applies for certification on or before October 1, 2015; and
Presents to the Board satisfactory evidence that the applicant worked as a residential child and youth care practitioner in the State for at least 2 years before October 1, 2015.

subsection.text: The Board shall adopt regulations for approved training programs for residential child and youth care practitioners.
Successful completion of an approved training program shall prepare an individual for certification as a residential child and youth care practitioner.
The regulations shall:

paragraph.text: Require an approved training program to provide a fundamental working knowledge of the varied aspects of performing the direct responsibilities related to activities of daily living, self–help, and socialization to children and youth in residential child care programs;
Establish a process for approving residential child and youth care practitioner training programs; and
Establish the contact hours, curriculum, format, and fees for approved training programs.

subsection.text: The Board shall post a list of approved training programs on its Web site.
To apply for a certificate, an applicant shall:

paragraph.text: Submit an application to the Board on the form that the Board requires;
Pay to the Board the application fee set by the Board; and

Provide fingerprints for use by the Criminal Justice Information System Central Repository of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services to conduct a State and national criminal history records check.

An applicant required to provide fingerprints under subsection (a)(3) of this section shall pay any processing or other fees required by the Criminal Justice Information System Central Repository of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services.
The results of the criminal history records check shall be provided to the Board and the applicant.

subsection.text: The Board shall keep a file of each certificate application made under this subtitle.
The file shall contain:

paragraph.text: The name, address, and age of the applicant;
The date of the application;
Complete and current information on the educational, training, and experience qualifications of the applicant;
The date the Board reviewed and acted on the application;
The action taken by the Board on the application;
The identifying numbers of any certificate or renewal certificate issued to the applicant; and
Any other information that the Board considers necessary.

subsection.text: The application files shall be open to public inspection.
An applicant who otherwise qualifies for a certificate is entitled to be examined as provided in this section.
The Board shall give examinations to applicants at least four times a year, at the times and places that the Board determines.
The Board shall notify each qualified applicant of the time and place of examination.

paragraph.text: Subject to the provisions of this subsection, for qualified certified program administrator applicants, the Board shall determine the subjects, scope, form, and passing score for examinations given under this subtitle.
The subjects of examination shall be related to:

subparagraph.text: Health and safety issues, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: Nutritional standards;
Water safety;
Preventative and acute health care standards;
Suicide assessment;
Prevention of abuse and neglect; and
Crisis intervention and problem solving;

subparagraph.text: The importance of staff training in appropriate observation techniques, including educational and psychological tests and social histories;
Rights of the child, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: Educational and recreational needs; and
Establishment of and compliance with appropriate grievance procedures;

subparagraph.text: Physical plant requirements;
Criminal history records checks of personnel;
Fiscal accountability;
Record keeping that complies with federal requirements and State regulations;
Emergency planning; and
Other standards established in the regulations.

paragraph.text: Each applicant shall be required to show knowledge of the laws, rules, and regulations that apply to programs.
The scope, content, and form of an examination shall be the same for all certificate applicants who take the examination at the same time.

subsection.text: For qualified certified residential child and youth care practitioner applicants, the Board shall determine the subjects, scope, form, and passing score for examinations given under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The Board may limit the number of times an applicant may take an examination required under this subtitle.
To qualify for a certificate, an applicant shall pass the examination within 3 years of the first time the applicant takes the examination.

subsection.text: Subject to the provisions of this section, the Board may waive any examination requirement of this title for an individual who is certified as a program administrator in any other state that the Board determines has a comparable certification process to the one established in this title.
The Board may grant a waiver under this section only if the applicant:

paragraph.text: Is of good moral character;
Pays the application fee required by the Board under § 20-303 of this subtitle; and
Provides adequate evidence that:

subparagraph.text: At the time the applicant was certified in the other state, the applicant was qualified to take the examination that then was required by the laws of this State;
The applicant qualified for a certificate in the other state by passing an examination given in that or any other state; and
The applicant has completed a State criminal history records check.

subsection.text: The Board shall waive the requirements for certification as a certified program administrator under § 20-302 of this subtitle for any person who:

paragraph.text: Has filed a letter of intent with the Board by October 1, 2007;
Has completed not less than 8 years’ experience in the human service field with at least 4 years in a supervisory or administrative capacity; and
Has by October 1, 2007, successfully passed an examination approved by the Board.

subsection.text: The Board shall issue a certificate to any applicant who meets the requirements of this title.
The Board shall include on each certificate that the Board issues:

paragraph.text: The full name of the certificate holder;
A serial number; and
The seal of the Board.

subsection.text: The Board may issue a certificate to replace a lost, destroyed, or mutilated certificate if the certificate holder pays the certificate replacement fee set by the Board.

section.text: The applicant may appeal a decision of the Board that relates to issuing or renewing a certificate to the Board of Review as provided in § 20-315(a) of this subtitle.
A certificate authorizes:

paragraph.text: An individual who is a program administrator to administer a residential child care program while the certificate is effective; or

An individual who is a residential child and youth care practitioner to perform direct responsibilities related to activities of daily living, self–help, and socialization skills in a residential child care program while the certificate is effective.
A certificate expires on a date set by the Board, unless the certificate is renewed for an additional term as provided in this section.
A certificate may not be renewed for a term longer than 2 years.

subsection.text: At least 1 month before the certificate expires, the Board shall send to the certified program administrator or certified residential child and youth care practitioner, by first–class mail to the last known address of the certified program administrator or certified residential child and youth care practitioner, a renewal notice that states:

paragraph.text: The date on which the current certificate expires;
The date by which the renewal application must be received by the Board for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the certificate expires; and
The amount of the renewal fee.

subsection.text: Before the certificate expires, the certified program administrator or certified residential child and youth care practitioner periodically may renew it for an additional 2–year term, if the certified program administrator or certified residential child and youth care practitioner:

paragraph.text: Otherwise is entitled to obtain a certificate;
Pays to the Board a renewal fee set by the Board; and
Submits to the Board:

subparagraph.text: A renewal application on the form that the Board requires; and
Satisfactory evidence of compliance with any continuing education and other qualifications and requirements set under this section for certificate renewal.

subsection.text: In addition to any other qualifications and requirements established in consultation with the Children’s Cabinet, the Board may set continuing education requirements as a condition for the renewal of certificates under this section.
The Board shall renew the certificate of each certified program administrator or certified residential child and youth care practitioner who meets the requirements of this section.
The Board shall reinstate the certificate of a program administrator or residential child and youth care practitioner who has failed to renew the certificate for any reason, if the individual:

paragraph.text: Has not had the certificate suspended or revoked;
Meets the renewal requirements of § 20–310 of this subtitle;
Pays to the Board the reinstatement fee set by the Board;
Submits to the Board satisfactory evidence of compliance with the qualifications and requirements established under this title for certificate reinstatements; and
Applies to the Board for reinstatement of the certificate within 5 years after the certificate expires.

The Board may not reinstate the certificate of a program administrator or residential child and youth care practitioner who fails to apply for reinstatement of the certificate within 5 years after the certificate expires.
However, the program administrator or residential child and youth care practitioner may be certified by meeting the current requirements for obtaining a new certificate under this title.

subsection.text: Unless the Board agrees to accept the surrender of a certificate, a certified program administrator or certified residential child and youth care practitioner may not surrender the certificate nor may the certificate lapse by operation of law while the certified program administrator or certified residential child and youth care practitioner is under investigation or while charges are pending against the certified program administrator or certified residential child and youth care practitioner.

The Board may set conditions on its agreement with the certified program administrator or certified residential child and youth care practitioner under investigation or against whom charges are pending to accept surrender of the certified program administrator’s certificate or the certified residential child and youth care practitioner’s certificate.

The Board shall investigate and take appropriate action as to any complaint filed with the Board that alleges that a certified program administrator or certified residential child and youth care practitioner has failed to meet any standard of the Board.

Subject to the hearing provisions of § 20–314 of this subtitle, the Board may deny a certificate to any applicant, reprimand any certified program administrator or certified residential child and youth care practitioner, place any certified program administrator or certified residential child and youth care practitioner on probation, or suspend or revoke a certificate if the applicant, certified program administrator, or certified residential child and youth care practitioner:

paragraph.text: Fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a certificate for a program administrator or residential child and youth care practitioner, or for another;
Fraudulently or deceptively uses a certificate;
Otherwise fails to meet substantially the standards for certification adopted by the Board under § 20–205 of this title;

Is convicted of or pleads guilty or nolo contendere to a felony or to a crime involving moral turpitude, whether or not any appeal or other proceeding is pending to have the conviction or plea set aside;
Performs the duties of a program administrator or residential child and youth care practitioner while:

subparagraph.text: Under the influence of alcohol; or
Using any narcotic or controlled dangerous substance, as defined in § 5–101 of the Criminal Law Article, or other drug that is in excess of therapeutic amounts or without valid medical indication;

paragraph.text: Is disciplined by a licensing or disciplinary authority of any other state or country or convicted or disciplined by a court of any state or country for an act that would be grounds for disciplinary action under the Board’s disciplinary statutes;

Performs the duties of a program administrator or residential child and youth care practitioner with an unauthorized person or supervises or aids an unauthorized person in performing the duties of a program administrator or residential child and youth care practitioner;
Willfully makes or files a false report or record while performing the duties of a program administrator or residential child and youth care practitioner;
Willfully fails to file or record any report as required under law, willfully impedes or obstructs the filing or recording of the report, or induces another to fail to file or record the report;
Commits an act of unprofessional conduct in performing the duties of a program administrator or residential child and youth care practitioner; or

Refuses, withholds from, denies, or discriminates against an individual with regard to the provision of professional services for which the individual is certified and qualified to render because the individual is HIV positive.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in the Administrative Procedure Act, before the Board takes any action under § 20-313 of this subtitle, it shall give the individual against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Board.
The Board shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with the Administrative Procedure Act.

Over the signature of an officer or the executive secretary of the Board, the Board may issue subpoenas and administer oaths in connection with any investigation under this title and any hearings or proceedings before it.

If, without lawful excuse, a person disobeys a subpoena from the Board or an order by the Board to take an oath or to testify or answer a question, then, on petition of the Board, a court of competent jurisdiction may punish the person as for contempt of court.
If after due notice the individual against whom the action is contemplated fails or refuses to appear, the Board may hear and determine the matter.

Except as provided in this section for an action under § 20-313 of this subtitle, any person aggrieved by a final decision of the Board in a contested case, as defined in the Administrative Procedure Act, may:

paragraph.text: Appeal that decision to the Board of Review; and
Then take any further appeal allowed by the Administrative Procedure Act.
Any person aggrieved by a final decision of the Board under § 20-314 of this subtitle may not appeal to the Secretary or Board of Review but may take a direct judicial appeal.
The appeal shall be made as provided for judicial review of final decisions in the Administrative Procedure Act.

section.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, an individual may not:

paragraph.text: Perform the duties of, attempt to perform the duties of, or offer to perform the duties of a program administrator or residential child and youth care practitioner in this State unless certified by the Board; or
Supervise, direct, induce, or aid an uncertified individual to perform the duties of a program administrator or residential child and youth care practitioner.

subsection.text: Unless authorized to perform the duties of a program administrator or residential child and youth care practitioner under this title, a person may not represent to the public by title, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the person is a program administrator or residential child and youth care practitioner in this State.

Unless authorized to practice under this title, a person may not use the title “residential child care program administrator”, “residential child and youth care practitioner”, or any other designation, title, or abbreviation with the intent to represent that the person is authorized to perform the duties of a program administrator or residential child and youth care practitioner.

section.text: A person may not:

paragraph.text: Sell or fraudulently obtain or furnish or aid in selling or fraudulently obtaining or furnishing a certificate issued under this title; or
Perform the duties of a program administrator or residential child and youth care practitioner under any certificate unlawfully or fraudulently obtained or issued.

section.text: Except when a program administrator is removed from the position by death or for any other unexpected cause as provided in § 20-301 of this title, a program may not be operated unless it is under the day-to-day management and operation of a certified program administrator.
A person who violates any provision of this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to:

paragraph.text: A fine not exceeding $1,000 for a first offense; and
A fine not exceeding $5,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or both for any subsequent violation of the same provision.

section.text: This title may be cited as the “Maryland Certification of Residential Child Care Program Professionals Act”.
Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Program Evaluation Act, this title and all regulations adopted under this title shall terminate and be of no effect after July 1, 2024.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the State Board of Environmental Health Specialists.
“Environmental health specialist” means an individual who practices as an environmental health specialist.

“Environmental health specialist–in–training” means an individual who meets the educational qualifications required under this title but has not yet completed the environmental health specialist–in–training program required under § 21–305 of this title.

“Environmental health specialist–in–training program” means a program of training and experience under the supervision of a licensed environmental health specialist or other individual acceptable to the Board.
“Hours of approved training” means the value given to participation in continuing education or experience as approved by the Board.
“License” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a license issued by the Board to practice as an environmental health specialist.
“Licensed environmental health specialist” means an individual licensed by the Board to practice as an environmental health specialist.

“Practice as an environmental health specialist” means, as a major component of employment, to apply academic principles, methods and procedures of the environmental, physical, biological, and health sciences to the inspections and investigations necessary to collect and analyze data and to make decisions necessary to secure compliance with federal, State, and local health and environmental laws and regulations specifically relating to control of the public health aspects of the environment including:

paragraph.text: The manufacture, preparation, handling, distribution, or sale of food and milk;
Water supply and treatment;
Wastewater treatment and disposal;
Solid waste management and disposal;
Vector control;
Insect and rodent control;
Air quality;
Noise control;
Product safety;
Recreational sanitation; and
Institutional and residential sanitation.

section.text: This title does not prohibit an individual from practicing any other profession or occupation that the individual is authorized to practice under the laws of the State.
There is a State Board of Environmental Health Specialists in the Department.

paragraph.text: The Board consists of 9 members appointed by the Governor with the advice of the Secretary, and with the advice and consent of the Senate.
Of the 9 Board members:

subparagraph.text: 7 shall be licensed environmental health specialists appointed as follows:

sub-subparagraph.text: 1 shall be employed by private industry;
1 shall be employed by the Department of the Environment;
1 shall be employed by the Department;
1 shall be employed by a local health department and be employed under the State Personnel Management System;
1 shall be employed by a local government and not be employed under the State Personnel Management System; and
2 shall be appointed at large; and

subparagraph.text: 2 shall be consumer members.

paragraph.text: All Board members shall be residents of the State.

subsection.text: The members appointed at large shall reasonably reflect the geographic diversity of the State.

paragraph.text: The consumer members of the Board:

subparagraph.text: Shall be members of the general public;
May not be licensed environmental health specialists;
May not have a household member who is a licensed environmental health specialist;
May not participate or ever have participated in a related commercial or professional field;
May not have a household member who participates in a related commercial or professional field; and
May not have had within 2 years before appointment a substantial financial interest in a person regulated by the Board.

paragraph.text: While a member of the Board, a consumer member may not have a substantial financial interest in a person regulated by the Board.

subsection.text: Before taking office, each appointee to the Board shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 4 years.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on July 1, 2012.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member may not serve more than 2 consecutive terms.

subsection.text: For each vacancy of a licensed environmental health specialist member, the Board shall:

paragraph.text: Solicit nominations by notifying all licensed environmental health specialists of the vacancy; and
Submit to the Secretary a list of at least three candidates for each vacancy.

subsection.text: On the recommendation of the Secretary, the Governor may remove a member for incompetence, misconduct, neglect of duty, or other sufficient cause.
From among its members, the Board annually shall elect a chairman, a vice chairman, and a secretary.
The Board shall determine:

paragraph.text: The manner of election of officers; and
The duties of each officer.

subsection.text: A majority of the Board is a quorum.
The Board shall meet at least twice a year, at the times and places that the Board determines.
A member of the Board:

paragraph.text: May receive compensation as provided in the State budget; and
Is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The Board may employ a staff in accordance with the budget of the Board.
In addition to the powers set forth elsewhere in this title, the Board may:

paragraph.text: Adopt rules, regulations, and bylaws to carry out the provisions of this title;
Sue to enforce any provision of this title by injunction; and
Issue subpoenas, summon witnesses, administer oaths, take affidavits, and take testimony about matters that relate to the jurisdiction of the Board.

subsection.text: In addition to the duties set forth elsewhere in this title, the Board shall:

paragraph.text: Keep a current record of all licensed environmental health specialists;
Collect and account for fees provided under this title;
Pay all necessary expenses of the Board in accordance with the State budget;
Keep a complete record of its proceedings;
File an annual report of its activities, including a financial statement, with the Governor and the Secretary; and
Adopt an official seal.

subsection.text: In this section, “Fund” means the State Board of Environmental Health Specialists Fund.
There is a State Board of Environmental Health Specialists Fund.

paragraph.text: The Board may set reasonable fees for the issuance and renewal of licenses and its other services.
The fees charged shall be set so as to approximate the cost of maintaining the Board.
Funds to cover the compensation and expenses of the Board members shall be generated by fees set under this section.
The Board shall remit all fees collected under this title to the Comptroller.
The Comptroller shall distribute the fees to the Fund.
The Fund shall be used to cover the actual documented direct and indirect costs of fulfilling the statutory and regulatory duties of the Board as provided under this article.
The Fund is a continuing, nonlapsing fund and is not subject to § 7–302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
Any unspent portions of the Fund may not be transferred or revert to the General Fund of the State, but shall remain in the Fund to be used for the purposes specified in this article.
No other State money may be used to support the Fund.
A designee of the Board shall administer the Fund.
Money in the Fund may be expended only for any lawful purpose authorized under this article.

subsection.text: The legislative auditor shall audit the accounts and transactions of the Fund as provided in § 2–1220 of the State Government Article.

section.text: A person shall have the immunity from liability described under § 5–702 of the Courts and Judicial Proceedings Article for giving information to the Board or otherwise participating in its activities.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, an individual shall be licensed by the Board before the individual may practice as an environmental health specialist in this State.
This section does not apply to:

paragraph.text: An environmental health specialist–in–training as provided for under § 21–305 of this subtitle;
A student participating in a field experience as part of an educational program; and
A qualified individual in any of the following job classifications:

subparagraph.text: Industrial hygienists as defined by the American Industrial Hygiene Association;
Certified industrial hygienists and industrial hygienists in training as defined by the American Board of Industrial Hygiene;
Health planners or natural resource planners;
Building and housing inspectors;
Geologists;
Chemists;
Meteorologists;
Laboratory scientists;

Professional engineers who are licensed in this State under Title 14 of the Business Occupations and Professions Article and whose normal professional activities are among the activities specified in § 21–101(i) of this title;
Public health engineers and water resources engineers employed by the State or a local subdivision;
Hydrographers and hydrographic engineers;
Natural resources managers;
Natural resources biologists;
Program administrators, administration directors, administrators, administrative officers, and administrative specialists;
Paraprofessional personnel, aides, and technicians whose routine duties include monitoring, sampling, and recording of data;
Persons employed by the Department of Natural Resources or related county departments who perform duties and responsibilities under the Natural Resources Article;
Persons employed by the Department of the Environment or related county departments who perform duties and responsibilities for:

sub-subparagraph.text: Erosion and sediment control, stormwater management, or oil pollution control under Title 4 of the Environment Article;
Motor vehicle pollution control under Title 2 of the Environment Article or Title 23 of the Transportation Article; or
Sewage sludge, water pollution control, or drinking water under Title 9 of the Environment Article;

subparagraph.text: Persons employed by the Department of the Environment and classified as either:

sub-subparagraph.text: A regulatory and compliance engineer or architect; or
An environmental compliance specialist;

subparagraph.text: Persons employed by the Division of Labor and Industry of the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation who perform duties and responsibilities under the Maryland Occupational Safety and Health Act;
Occupational safety and health technologists as defined by the American Board of Industrial Hygiene and the Board of Certified Safety Professionals;
Safety professionals as defined by the American Society of Safety Engineers;
Certified safety professionals and associate safety professionals as defined by the Board of Certified Safety Professionals;
Persons employed by industrial operations whose environmental services are performed solely for their employer; and
State milk safety inspectors performing duties under the National Conference on Interstate Milk Shipments and employed by the Department.

section.text: To apply for licensure as an environmental health specialist, an applicant shall:

paragraph.text: Submit an application to the Board on the form that the Board requires;

subparagraph.text: Submit verification from the applicant’s employer or supervisor on forms required by the Board that the applicant has successfully completed an environmental health specialist–in–training program; or

Provide independent written verification from the applicant’s employer or any prior work experience in the field of environmental health used by the applicant to satisfy the environmental health specialist–in–training requirement of this title; and

paragraph.text: Pay to the Board the required fees set by the Board.

subsection.text: To qualify for licensure under this title, an applicant shall meet the requirements of this section.
The applicant must be of good moral character.
The applicant must be at least 18 years old.
An applicant shall be licensed by the Board if the applicant:

paragraph.text: Qualifies for the examination required under § 21–304 of this subtitle; and
Takes and attains a passing score on the examination.

subsection.text: The Board may waive any examination requirement under this section if the Board considers the applicant to be recognized as outstanding in the field of environmental health.
An applicant who otherwise qualifies for licensure is entitled to be examined as provided in this section.
An applicant qualifies to take the examination if the applicant:

subparagraph.text: Has graduated from an accredited college or university with a baccalaureate degree in environmental science or environmental health; and
Has obtained 12 months of experience in an environmental health specialist–in–training program approved by the Board;
Has graduated from an accredited college or university with a baccalaureate degree in the physical, biological, or environmental sciences including:

sub-subparagraph.text: A minimum of 60 semester credit hours or the equivalent quarter credit hours of physical, biological, and environmental sciences acceptable to the Board which includes at least one laboratory course in two of the following fields:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: Chemistry;
Physics; and
Biology; and

sub-subparagraph.text: A course in mathematics; and

subparagraph.text: Has obtained 12 months of experience in an environmental health specialist–in–training program approved by the Board;
Has graduated from an accredited college or university with a baccalaureate degree that includes:

sub-subparagraph.text: 30 semester credit hours or the equivalent quarter credit hours in the physical, biological, and environmental sciences acceptable to the Board, which includes at least one laboratory course in two of the following fields:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: Chemistry;
Physics; and
Biology; and

sub-subparagraph.text: A course in mathematics; and

subparagraph.text: Has obtained 24 months of experience in an environmental health specialist–in–training program approved by the Board; or

paragraph.text: Has graduated from an accredited college or university with a master’s degree in public or environmental health science that includes:

subparagraph.text: 30 semester credit hours or 45 quarter credit hours of physical, biological, or environmental sciences acceptable to the Board, which includes at least one laboratory course in two of the following fields:

sub-subparagraph.text: Chemistry;
Physics; and
Biology;

subparagraph.text: A course in mathematics; and
3 months of internship approved by the Board if not previously completed.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not alter the requirement that an applicant demonstrate completion of a baccalaureate or master’s degree to qualify for examination.
The Board may waive any of the specific course requirements for an applicant to qualify for examination in subsection (b) of this section if the Board determines that an applicant:

subparagraph.text: Has obtained an equivalent number of credit hours in a course relevant to practice as an environmental health specialist; or
Has work experience that is an acceptable substitute for a course required in subsection (b) of this section.

paragraph.text: The Board may waive the experience requirement in subsection (b)(3)(ii) of this section if the Board determines that an applicant:

subparagraph.text: Has obtained at least 12 months of experience in an environmental health specialist–in–training program; and
Has the written support of the applicant’s employer.

subsection.text: The examination shall include a written examination in the physical, biological, and environmental sciences that relates to practices and principles of environmental health.
The Board shall give examinations to applicants at least once a year, at the times and places that the Board determines.
The Board shall notify each qualified applicant of the time and place of examination.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, the Board shall determine the subjects, scope, form, and passing score for examinations given under this subtitle.
The Board shall use professional examinations prepared by recognized examination agencies.
Examination papers shall identify the applicant only by a number assigned by the Board secretary.

subsection.text: Examination papers shall be filed with the Board secretary and kept at least 1 year.

paragraph.text: An applicant who fails an examination may retake the examination as provided in the rules and regulations adopted by the Board.
An applicant for reexamination shall:

subparagraph.text: Submit to the Board an application on the form the Board requires; and
Pay to the Board a reexamination fee set by the Board.

subsection.text: Unless authorized by the Board, the consumer members of the Board may not participate in any activity related to examinations under this subtitle.

section.text: The Board shall adopt regulations that include:

paragraph.text: The establishment of an environmental health specialist–in–training program for applicants to obtain the necessary experience to qualify to take the examination; and
A condition that a person may not participate in an environmental health specialist–in–training program for more than 3 years, unless granted an extension by the Board.

subsection.text: Subject to the provisions of this section, the Board may make a reciprocal agreement with any other state to waive any examination requirement of this title for an applicant who is licensed as an environmental health specialist or its equivalent in that state.
An agreement made under this section may allow the Board to grant a waiver only if the applicant:

paragraph.text: Pays the application fee required by § 21–302 of this subtitle; and
Provides adequate evidence that the applicant:

subparagraph.text: Meets the qualifications otherwise required by this title; and
Became licensed in the other state after passing in that or any other state an examination that is similar to the examination for which the applicant is seeking the waiver.

subsection.text: An agreement may be made with another state under this section only if, under the agreement, the other state waives the examination of licensed environmental health specialists of this State to a similar extent as this State waives the examination requirements for individuals licensed in that state.
The Board shall license and issue the appropriate licensure to any applicant who meets the requirements of this title.
The Board shall include on each license that it issues:

paragraph.text: The designation “licensed environmental health specialist”;
The name of the license holder;
The date of issue and serial number of the license;
The Board seal; and
The signature of the Board’s representative.

subsection.text: The Board shall issue a new license to replace a lost, destroyed, or mutilated license if the license holder pays a fee that is set by the Board.

section.text: Licensure authorizes an individual to practice as an environmental health specialist while the license is in effect.

subsection.text: A license expires on the date specified on the license, unless it is renewed for a 2–year term as provided in this section.

At least 1 month before the license expires, the Board shall send to the licensee, by first–class mail or electronic means to the last known address or electronic mail address of the licensee, a renewal notice that states:

paragraph.text: The date on which the current license expires;
The date by which the renewal application must be received by the Board for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the license expires;
The amount of the renewal fee; and
The hours of approved training required for renewal of licensure.

subsection.text: Before the license expires, the licensee may renew it for an additional 2–year term, if the licensee:

paragraph.text: Otherwise is entitled to be licensed;
Pays to the Board the renewal fee set by the Board;
Submits to the Board a renewal application on the form that the Board requires; and

Submits to the Board proof that during the previous 2–year period, the licensee has acquired 20 hours of approved training in environmental health or other equivalent education as approved by the Board.

subsection.text: The renewal license shall bear the same serial number assigned to the licensee at the time of the original registration or licensure.

section.text: The Board shall reinstate the license of a licensed environmental health specialist who has failed to renew the license for any reason if the licensed environmental health specialist:

paragraph.text: Pays the Board all lapsed renewal fees and demonstrates that training as required by the Board has been completed;
Reapplies and meets the qualifications and requirements for licensure; and
Pays to the Board a reinstatement fee set by the Board.

subsection.text: The Board shall keep a current record of each application for licensure.
The record shall include:

paragraph.text: The name, residence address, and age of each applicant;
The name and address of the applicant’s employer;
The date of the application;
Complete information on the education and experience qualifications of each applicant;
The date the Board reviewed and acted on the application;
The action taken by the Board on the application;
The serial number of any registration or license issued to the applicant; and
Any other information that the Board considers necessary.

subsection.text: The Board shall adopt a code of ethics designed to protect the public’s interest.

Subject to the hearing provisions of § 21–313 of this subtitle, the Board, on the affirmative vote of a majority of its full authorized membership, may deny any applicant licensure, reprimand any licensee, or place any individual who is licensed on probation, or suspend or revoke a license, if the applicant or licensee:

paragraph.text: Fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a license for the applicant or license holder or another;
Fraudulently or deceptively uses a license;
Knowingly violates any provision of this title, or any rule or regulation adopted under this title;
Commits any gross negligence, incompetence, or misconduct while performing the duties of an environmental health specialist;

Is convicted of or pleads guilty or nolo contendere to a felony or to a crime involving moral turpitude, whether or not any appeal or other proceeding is pending to have the conviction or plea set aside;
Provides professional services while:

subparagraph.text: Under the influence of alcohol; or
Using any narcotic or controlled dangerous substance, as defined in § 5–101 of the Criminal Law Article, or other drug that is in excess of therapeutic amounts or without valid medical indication;

paragraph.text: Is disciplined by a licensing or disciplinary authority of any other state or country or convicted or disciplined by a court of any state or country for an act that would be grounds for disciplinary action under the Board’s disciplinary statutes;
Willfully makes or files a false report or record while performing the duties of an environmental health specialist;
Willfully fails to file or record any report as required by law, willfully impedes or obstructs the filing or recording of the report, or induces another to fail to file or record the report;
Submits a false statement to collect a fee;
Promotes the sale of land, devices, appliances, or goods provided for a person in such a manner as to exploit the person for financial gain of the licensed environmental health specialist;
Willfully alters a sample, specimen, or any test procedure to cause the results upon analysis to represent a false finding;
Violates any rule or regulation adopted by the Board;
Uses or promotes or causes the use of any misleading, deceiving, or untruthful advertising matter, promotional literature, or testimonial;
Is professionally, physically, or mentally incompetent; or
Fails to cooperate with a lawful investigation conducted by the Board.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (d) of this section, any person, including a Board employee, may make a written, specific charge of a violation under this section, if the person:

paragraph.text: Swears to the charge; and
Files the charge with the Board secretary.

If a licensed environmental health specialist knows of an action or condition that might be grounds for action under subsection (b) of this section, the licensed environmental health specialist shall report the action or condition to the Board; and
An individual shall have the immunity from liability described under § 5–702 of the Courts and Judicial Proceedings Article for making a report as required by this subsection.

Except as otherwise provided in the Administrative Procedure Act, before the Board takes any action under § 21–312 of this subtitle, it shall give the individual against whom this action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Board.
A hearing shall be held within a reasonable time not to exceed 6 months after charges have been brought.

subsection.text: The Board shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with the Administrative Procedure Act.
The individual may be represented at the hearing by counsel.

Over the signature of an officer or the administrator of the Board, the Board may issue subpoenas and administer oaths in connection with any investigation under this title and any hearings or proceedings before it.

If, without lawful excuse, a person disobeys a subpoena from the Board or an order by the Board to take an oath or to testify or answer a question, then, on petition of the Board, a court of competent jurisdiction may punish the person as for contempt of court.
If, after due notice, the individual against whom the action is contemplated fails or refuses to appear, the Board may hear and determine the matter.

paragraph.text: The Board shall maintain a record of all disciplinary matters that includes:

subparagraph.text: The date the matter was referred to the Board;
A detailed description of the specific allegations;
A copy of any written evidence reviewed by the Board in evaluating the matter; and
A written summary of the final action of the Board including the date of the action and the basis for the action.

paragraph.text: The Board shall maintain an electronic database of all disciplinary matters considered by the Board that is searchable, at a minimum, by:

subparagraph.text: The date of the Board’s final action;
The name of the affected licensee; and
The type of final action taken by the Board, including no action.

section.text: Except as provided in this section for an action under § 21–312 of this subtitle, any person aggrieved by a final decision of the Board in a contested case, as defined in § 10–202 of the State Government Article, may take an appeal as allowed in §§ 10–222 and 10–223 of the State Government Article.
The Board, on the affirmative vote of a majority of its full appointed membership, may reinstate the license of an individual whose license has been revoked.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, unless a person is licensed under this title, the person may not practice as an environmental health specialist.

Unless a person is licensed under this title, the person may not use the title “environmental health specialist” or “licensed environmental health specialist” or the initials “E.H.S.” or “L.E.H.S.” after the name of the person or any other title with the intent to represent that the person is licensed to practice as an environmental health specialist.

section.text: A person who violates any provision of § 21–301 of this title or § 21–401 of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $5,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 2 years or both.
This title may be cited as the “Maryland Environmental Health Specialists Act”.

Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Program Evaluation Act, the provisions of this title and of any rule or regulation adopted under this title shall terminate and be of no effect after July 1, 2017.
